PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Treasurer. It refers to Government claims that ministerial power to dismiss members of various statutory boards for impropriety applies only to impropriety committed as a board member. I ask the Treasurer: Does section 19 (2) (e) of the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act give him power to terminate an appointment 'on the ground that it is not in the best interests of the Corporation that the Director continue in office'? Did the Prime Minister say on 2 June that the dismissal of tax evaders from government positions was a matter for the relevant Minister? Finally, given that he has both the statutory power and prime ministerial sanction, why has he failed to sack Denis Horgan?

—The Leader of the Opposition is quite correct in quoting the relevant section from the AIDC Act. I think he misrepresents, in a significant way, what the Prime Minister said in June. My recollection was that the Prime Minister, when asked a question about the role in government bodies of individuals who had been named in the McCabe-Lafranchi report, said that that was a matter that ought to be taken up with the relevant Minister. I think the Leader of the Opposition has given it an interpretation. Having been asked this question, I repeat what I said in the House the other day and what other Ministers have said in this place, that the mere naming of people in reports is not, of itself, a reason why somebody should be removed from a particular body.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that present in the gallery this morning is Mr J. B. Bolger, M.P., New Zealand Minister of Labour. On behalf of the House, I extend to him a very warm welcome.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Construction. Whilst I recognise the benefits to our road improvement programs that the Minister's Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program will have, I believe that the best roads in the world will not stop the carnage caused by the drink-driver. Can the Minister tell me whether any portion of the funds from the ABRD Program will be spent on specific road safety measures, particularly those in an effort to reduce the personal tragedy and suffering caused by drink- drivers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The funds that will be made available for road construction over a six- year period through the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program will go some of the way towards making the road system in Australia safer than it is at present. The Government will be looking to projects that improve the alignment of roads, that provide better sign posting, better services on roads and better road marking, and that provide dual carriageways on the more heavily used roads and passing lanes on many of the arterial and national roads. I will be looking very closely, when approving projects over the six-year period, at the inclusion of projects that are designed to try to overcome some of the road surface deficiencies and road infrastructure facilities that undoubtedly have contributed in the past to road deaths.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true to say that one of the worst problems facing road safety in Australia is drink driving. Over 50 per cent of deaths and 30 per cent of injuries on the roads can be attributed to drink driving. The Prime Minister announced a few days ago that the Commonwealth will be making half a million dollars of Commonwealth funds available in the hope that State governments will match that amount on a dollar for dollar basis. The Government will seek also a contribution from the private sector towards a road safety publicity program with special reference to the question of drink driving.

I hope the States will give a favourable response to the offer that the Prime Minister has made. I have no doubt that the program, developed by the Commonwealth and involving Paul Cronin, has gone a long way towards proving that a well-prepared and well-constructed education program can do a lot to create an awareness of this problem. Undoubtedly, the pilot test that took place in Tasmania has proved beyond doubt that the Paul Cronin program on drink driving was a great success. I hope that the States and sections of the private sector will contribute towards this program that should help to reduce the carnage on Australian roads.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer to the Supreme Court action involving McCabe-Lafranchi and Commercial Securities (Vic) Pty Ltd before Mr Justice Jenkinson. A judgment was delivered as far back as 14 June 1979. I refer to the fact that in His Honor's judgment he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . one of the inspectors gave evidence that the attention of officers of the Income Tax Department had been directed, at the inspector's suggestion, by an officer of the Corporate Affairs Office to a very large pile of documents then standing in an enclosed but uncovered yard . . .

Those documents were collected by officers of the Australian Taxation Office. They related to corporations engaged in tax evasion. Is it a fact that no investigations were undertaken into these companies and the promoters of tax evasion schemes, even after the Australian Taxation Office had come into possession of the documents? This occurred three years prior to the publication of the McCabe-Lafranchi report. Is it also a fact that no investigations have been carried out with respect to these companies and promoters since the publication of the McCabe-Lafranchi report?

TALK.START.PARA: —The question asked by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is a detailed one. To the extent that matters were specifically raised in the McCabe- Lafranchi report, my response of 27 June canvassed those matters on which I was able to obtain advice when the report was being prepared. I will take the honourable gentleman's question on notice. If there is some further information on the matter that I can provide to him later today I will do so.

—I direct my question to the Acting Attorney-General. Did the Victorian Parliament last week pass the Council of Law Reporting in Victoria Act which purports to restrict the publication of law reports including reports of Federal courts and State courts exercising Federal jurisdiction? Does the Minister intend to take any steps to limit this comprehensive restriction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was aware that there was such a proposal by the Victorian Government. I was not aware, however, that the legislation to which the honourable member refers was passed. It would appear that that in fact was the case. The Commonwealth has made its position clear and I reiterate it very briefly. We believe there should be the absolute and most extensive freedom in the dissemination of legal matters which are of importance to the profession by way of statutes and law reports. That has been the attitude that we have taken and we continue to take that attitude. In the particular circumstances of this case, which seem to be overlooked by some people, we say that the better legal view is that the Commonwealth has jurisdiction with respect to published judgments of State courts when the courts are exercising Federal jurisdiction. Our authority extends that far also.

ANSWER.PARA: I do intend, particularly as the honourable member has drawn my attention to the fact that the legislation has been passed in Victoria, to take this matter further. Whether the appropriate forum is the Standing Committee of Attorneys- General or some other avenue I am not at this moment entirely clear. But the matter certainly will be pursued. We certainly will be pursuing the Commonwealth 's position that it is in the interests of the profession and of the public at large that there should be the maximum possible dissemination, without restriction, in the printing and distribution of judgments and statutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer: Do the documents tabled in the House yesterday show that since 1977 the Prime Minister has known, the Minister for Industry and Commerce has known, the Attorney-General has known and the Treasurer has known of the existence and the seriousness of bottom-of-the- harbour tax schemes? Is it a fact that during all this time bottom-of-the- harbour schemes have made their promoters millionaires, including those who are active in the Liberal Party in Western Australia? In the circumstances, will the Treasurer repeat in this House his statement on AM this morning that 'the whole thing was handled in the correct manner'?

—I assume that in asking that question the honourable member for Hunter is referring to one of the pages in the bundle of documents that I tabled yesterday-the page entitled 'Sale of Companies with Current Profits'. Is that right?
—Right.

—That is correct. If the honourable member thinks that that concerns a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme he does not know much about the taxation laws of this country. Indeed, that concerns a scheme which was known as a current year loss scheme which was knocked out by legislation of this Government early in 1978.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of reports that an important human rights group within the Soviet Union-the Helsinki monitoring group based in Moscow-has, as a result of pressure from the Soviet authorities, been compelled to disband? Is he further aware that this action has been strongly condemned by members of a bipartisan United States of America congressional commission which was established to monitor the Helsinki Accords? What is the Australian Government's position in relation to this recent example of a failure on the part of the Soviet authorities to respect fundamental human rights and freedoms?

—My attention has been drawn to the statement referred to by the honourable member. On 8 September Mrs Yelena Bonner, who is the wife of the very well-known Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov and who is a founding member of the Helsinki group set up in 1976 to monitor Soviet performance in relation to the Helsinki Accords, issued a statement advising that the group had been forced to disband as a result of harassment by the Soviet authorities. We view this development with grave concern, as did the United States body to which the honourable member referred. The Soviet Union freely undertook a series of obligations in respect of human rights when it signed the Helsinki Accords. For the Soviet authorities to bring pressure on an organisation which has carefully monitored their performance and to compel it to end its activities is yet another indictment of the Soviet Union's regrettable record on human rights. We made known to the Soviet authorities our concern about abuses of human rights in the Soviet Union and, in particular, about the fate of the dissidents. I repeat here an appeal to the Soviet authorities to abide by their international human rights obligations and allow the Helsinki group to continue its legitimate and respected activities.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Why is it that those documents which appear to be missing from the taxation papers tabled yesterday are: Firstly, all those legal opinions obtained from Queen's Counsel and others which are described by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship and Painters and Dockers Union as establishing clearly that legal proceedings could have been taken against bottom-of-the-harbour schemes under existing law; and, secondly, all those memoranda and letters written by the officers of the Attorney-General's Department which the Costigan report described as giving totally inadequate explanations as to why such proceedings could not have been taken?

—The reasons that the legal opinions referred to by the honourable gentleman have not been tabled are the reasons provided by the Solicitor-General , a person whom I hope honourable members on both sides of the House respect not only for his legal ability and personal integrity but also for his political neutrality. He stated a plain and proper legal view about the publication of those particular opinions. I stress to the honourable gentleman that indeed these legal opinions are not all on the one side of the argument. I think that is an important thing that is lost sight of. Not all of the legal opinions would necessarily suggest the unambiguous conclusion. The fact of the matter is that the Solicitor-General who is behaving in a totally proper and impartial manner in this matter has advised that the tabling of those opinions would indeed be prejudicial for the reasons set out in my tabling statement yesterday. I do not believe that in the light of the very full disclosure on the large number of documents tabled relating to this matter the implied criticism in the honourable gentleman's question can be sustained.
—Can the Prime Minister inform the House what effect the Victorian Budget will have on the Commonwealth Government's approach to the economic problems of the country?

—The Victorian Government's Budget last night was an interesting document because it was reminiscent of socialist and Labor policies in previous years. It is worth noting that if the Federal Government had increased taxation in its Budget at the same rate as Mr Cain did in his Budget, by over 23 per cent in one year, Australians would have had to pay $4.8 billion extra-about $17 a week extra from every Australian household. It should be remembered that under the Commonwealth Budget many families with two children and a dependent spouse will be $17 to $18 a week better off. If we had done what Mr Cain has done the family would have been $17 a week worse off. Quite plainly Mr Cain's big spending, big tax budget-that is what it is-is reminiscent of the policies of the Whitlam years. His increase in outlays was over 24 per cent-an increase of 13 per cent in real terms. If the Commonwealth had increased its expenditure by 24.1 per cent, as did Mr Cain, it would have been spending an extra $4.2 billion. When we tie that in with what the Leader of the Opposition said in his response to the Commonwealth Budget we come to figures around $4 billion to $5 billion. That shows quite plainly that the Australian Labor Party has learnt nothing in terms of financial responsibility and what is really in the interests of Australian families.

—Did the Prime Minister know in July 1977 that tax avoidance schemes were-I quote from the documents tabled yesterday-'being sold to company brokers at a far higher rate than previously'? Why, after his initial enthusiasm up to February 1978, did he not press for urgent action on this matter? Why has he remained completely silent on his knowledge about these matters throughout the debate on the Costigan report? Why did he allow to go uncorrected his Treasurer' s statement of 12 September 1982 that, to the best of his knowledge, nobody in the Government knew about these matters before February 1982?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's indignation is very much misplaced because I did advise the then Treasurer in late June or July of 1977 of 13 tax evasion schemes of which I had been advised by a person from the public, a person who abhorred the practices. I brought them to the notice of the Treasurer with a letter which asked for urgent action and the preparation of legislation. I think the papers will also show that the Australian Taxation Office did not have sufficient evidence in relation to some of those particular proposals to act forthwith. When the present Treasurer took office early in 1978 I drew to his attention also the fact that that list existed.
—It is now 1982.

—Oh, I know that. But in 1978 and 1979 overwhelmingly the proposals outlined in that particular document were legislated against. In relation to one of the schemes, a court decision, as I am advised, made legislation unnecessary. Let me nail in the most categoric terms that any claim by any newspaper reporter, any newspaper, any radio station or any television station which indicates that those reports indicated that I had known of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes as a result of that list is totally and utterly false. So many journalists have put out the same report that, whether or not it came from the office of the Leader of the Opposition, I ask: How did they all make the same mistake? How did they all come to the same false view?

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever the jackals from the Opposition might say, the particular device that was described in that report was legislated against- effective from 8 April 1978. That gives the lie totally to the allegations contained in the honourable member's question.

—The Minister for Transport and Construction will be aware that the Empress of Australia which carries passengers, cargo and motor vehicles between Tasmania and the mainland of Australia is nearing the end of its economic life. What steps are being taken by the Government to find a suitable replacement vessel, whether from the private sector or the public sector?

—The Commonwealth Government has been aware of the importance of a passenger sea service between Tasmania and the mainland. We have maintained that service since the Fraser Government came to office in 1975, and it has been maintained with the assistance of a subsidy, the subsidy going to the Empress of Australia. On behalf of the Government I have called for statements of interest from Australian shipowners for replacement services in the Bass Strait to take place as soon as possible without subsidy. The statements of interest are now to hand. They are being examined by the Department of Transport and Construction and, in the near future, we will be discussing with the Tasmanian and Victorian governments the applications that have come to hand. We certainly wish to see the continuation of a passenger and cargo service across the Bass Strait but operated in a commercially competitive way without assistance of subsidy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Treasurer. I refer to repeated statements by him that he was not aware in 1978 of the seriousness of the bottom -of-the-harbour schemes and that such schemes were therefore given a lesser priority than other tax avoidance. Is it a fact that in minutes to him from the Commissioner of Taxation in 1978 on 13 February, 11 April, 24 May, 1 June, 11 July, 20 July, 21 August and repeatedly for the rest of the year he was told that these schemes were 'emerging', a matter for 'increasing concern', 'a worrying problem', 'widespread', 'even more serious', 'more extensive' and 'very widespread indeed', that there was 'a most pressing need' for action and that legislation was 'required urgently'? In the light of this clear and unequivocal advice, why has the Treasurer persisted in trying to downgrade the importance given to this matter by the Commissioner of Taxation in 1978? I ask him why he stated on 27 June 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: It was not until 1979 or 1980 that the full extent of such schemes really became apparent to the Australian Taxation Office and the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman was kind enough at the end of his question to come to the nub of what I said earlier, and I stand by it. I repeat what I have said on earlier occasions: The full extent of these schemes was not known until the times that I mentioned.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind honourable gentlemen that as late as November 1979 the finite revenue estimates provided to me by the Commissioner of Taxation were less than $50m. If one contrasts that with the amount of revenue that was at stake in the Curran scheme, the expenditure recoupment scheme, family trusts and all the other tax avoidance measures against which the Government took action and also the action to rewrite section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, my statements are proper and stand without contradication.

—I refer the Treasurer to the legal opinion of Mr A. P. Webb which appears at the back of the documents that the Treasurer tabled yesterday. Does the Treasurer stand by his repeated statements that he was unaware that there was convincing legal evidence to the effect that the law before December 1980 was adequate to deal with prosecutions in connection with bottom-of-the harbour schemes and other tax avoidance schemes? Is it a fact, as indicated in the documents he tabled yesterday, that he saw the advice dated 5 September 1978 by Mr A. P. Webb of counsel? Is it a fact that that advice was that criminal prosecution was open under section 86 of the Crimes Act and that the problems of evidence could be overcome? Is it a fact that Mr Webb advised that the Commissioner of Taxation could recover the lost tax? In the light of this advice , why did the Treasurer not test this case in the courts?
—The simple answer to the honourable gentleman's question is that my attention was drawn to that legal opinion only in June of this year.

—Is it a fact that the Treasurer was advised in February 1978 in relation to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes that 'the remedial measures may need to extend to making directors and shareholders personally liable for a company's tax'? Since this does not relate to criminal legislation, why did the Treasurer not follow the practice he announced in April 1978 in announcing the intention to legislate and to backdate the effect of the legislation to the date of the announcement? Can the Treasurer advise the House whether this would have prevented the enormous bottom-of-the-harbour tax rip-off which he says boomed in 1978, 1979 and 1980?

—The answer to that question is that subsequent to receiving that advice-if one reads that minute one will see that that advice is by no means precise, finite or conclusive-the Commissioner, on 24 May, in addressing the straw company problem in terms that I had previously disclosed to the House, said that he had come to the conclusion that what was needed was the development of a criminal offence. I make the very clear distinction between an announcement procedure in respect of non-criminal matters and the desirability that criminal liability should always date from the time of royal assent. I make no apology at all for not adopting the process of legislation by announcement in respect of criminal matters. I think it would be a sorry day if a criminal liability could be imposed by a ministerial announcement, which is the implication in the honourable gentleman's question.

—I address my question to the Acting Attorney-General. He is no doubt aware that an enormous amount of commerce in Australia is carried out in proprietary companies. He would be aware also that to form a proprietary company it is necessary to have $2, two directors and two shareholders. In view of the wide-ranging use of proprietary companies, would he and the Government give consideration to ensuring that the capitalisation of these companies is such as to bear their responsibilities and that to do that may require some gearing within the companies' structure? Also, having determined that, would he like to pursue that matter with the ministerial council, where I am sure he would find some welcoming ears?
—I do not know very much about $2 companies, but I will certainly consider whether the matter should be brought before the National Companies and Securities Commission to see what can be done.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Treasurer, follows a comment which he made today, namely, that he was not aware of the full extent of the operation of straw company tax evasion methods until about 1979-80. I ask whether he recalls a letter from the Commissioner of Taxation of 20 July 1978 about straw companies which, amongst other things, stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . this practice is very wide spread indeed . . . the procedure adopted apparently includes falsification of documents and misappropriation of funds . . . a most pressing need for Submission No. 2290 to be dealt with by Ministers and for the examination that it recommends to be carried out.
I also ask whether he also recalls a letter to Mr Besley from the Commissioner of Taxation in which the Commissioner stated:

The fact that the Submission has been before Ministers for some time does not, in my view, detract from the urgency of the matter. It is important that there be the speediest examination and resolution of the problem. Legislation to counter tax avoidance schemes and arrangements will be of limited effectiveness if 'straw company' evasion is not checked in some way.

Does he recall other correspondence included in this folio which expresses alarm about the extent of these practices in Adelaide, subsequent correspondence pointing out that these sorts of practices are rampant in Queensland, among other States, and particularly rampant in Victoria, and that very large sums of money which should go to public revenue are being syphoned off for the benefit of promoters? In these circumstances how much worse did the situation have to become and how much more alarm did the Taxation Commissioner have to display to the Government before the Treasurer was convinced that action should be taken? Why should there have been two years of this sort of distress and plaintive complaint on the part of the Taxation Commissioner before the Government finally acted?

TALK.START.PARA: —This line of questioning turns upon my saying that I did not know the full extent. I put it to the honourable gentleman and to the House--
—Well, what is the full extent? Don't you think this is bad enough?

—I put it to anybody who is prepared to listen that that comment embraces not only details of the schemes that have been cited by the Leader of the Opposition but also the magnitude of revenue at threat then advised to me. It also involves a consideration of all the circumstances of the Government's campaign against tax avoidance during those years. I put it again to the Leader of the Opposition and to the House that the statement I made was that the full extent was not known until 1979-80. Indeed there would be many who would argue that in revenue terms the full extent of these schemes was not known until well after December 1980.

—I ask the Minister for Transport and Construction whether funds from the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program would be made available to the New South Wales Government for the Tweed by-pass if it asked for them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of representations have been made to me on the so-called Tweed by-pass. The honourable member for Richmond-the Deputy Prime Minister-and the honourable member for McPherson have written to me on several occasions about the matter. I have had other representations as well. But it will be up to the New South Wales Government to submit a program for my approval under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. There have been discussions between officers of my Department and the State road constructing authorities on the extent of this current year's program and the six-year program as a whole.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the Victorian authority has completed preparations of its six -year program. It has had discussions with my officers and will be formally submitting the program for my approval within the next two weeks. South Australia is well advanced in the preparation of its six-year program. I believe that Queensland will be submitting its program in the very near future. I expect to receive the New South Wales program within the next three weeks. There have been extensive and very co-operative discussions between the Commonwealth and the various State road authorities. I understand that quite a number of projects , including by-passes, have been considered by the New South Wales Department of Main Roads. I will certainly approve any such submission when it comes to me from the New South Wales Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to his answer to me in respect of the Webb legal opinion and his statement that he did not see until June of this year a legal opinion which was provided in 1978. I ask the Treasurer: Does he agree that that opinion was provided as a result of a number of matters arising as a result of the impending introduction of legislation, namely, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1978? Does he agree that the advice given in the Webb opinion charted a strategy which would have been immensely important to any Treasurer concerned to pursue the tax avoidance operations which were then currently a matter of concern to the Government? Does he concede that it was a grievous error for this opinion not to be brought to his attention? Can he explain to the House why it was not brought to his attention and whose fault it was?

—I suppose I could say that it was a grievous error and a great pity that it was not brought to my attention. But let me make it clear that that opinion was not commissioned by the Commissioner of Taxation.
—But they had it.

—I invite the honourable member for Melbourne Ports to read the terms of that opinion. That opinion was plainly provided to people who were seeking advice and comfort regarding their entry into certain arrangements. In those circumstances it is hardly surprising that the opinion was not rushed on to my desk.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Aviation, concerns the incident in recent days referred to as the great plane robbery. I ask the Minister: In view of the fairly frequent security checks on regular fare paying passengers, what measures are in place to conduct security checks on the travellers downstairs? More to the point, what assurances have been given to regular fare paying passengers that, in the cargo holds of aircraft in which they are travelling, there are not devices or desperadoes that may conceivably occasion them a mischief?

—The question raised by the honourable member for Wide Bay of course relates to an incident that was widely reported in the media yesterday. This incident related to a very ingenious operation that had been planned by some people to obtain funds that were being shipped by Trans Australia Airlines to, I think, four separate destinations. I have already raised the question asked by the honourable member for Wide Bay with the Department of Aviation. The airlines have the responsibility for security on their own aircraft regardless of whether an airline happens to be domestic or international. I have asked my Department to review the circumstances of that incident to which the honourable member has referred to see whether the Government, through the Department of Aviation, will be able to take some action to strengthen further the security arrangements that already exist. I hasten to repeat that security on aircraft is the responsibility of the airlines. The airline involved, of course, was Trans Australia Airlines. I have sought advice in my capacity as both the Minister responsible for TAA and the Minister responsible for the Department of Aviation.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. Is it a fact that, of all the taxation measures of the Government introduced since 1978, according to the Treasurer's statement of 27 June about 42 could be described as anti-avoidance measures? Is it also a fact that about 22 of them were directed explicitly at deliberate, unambiguous avoidance schemes such as expenditure recoupment, trust stripping, trading stock and sales tax? Has the Treasurer any reason to dissent from the Government's estimates, made at the time when these measures were announced, that revenue lost in these blatant schemes was between $2 billion and $3 billion? If the Government is proposing retrospective legislation against bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, why is it not legislating retrospectively to recoup that $2 billion to $3 billion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be legislating retrospectively in respect of those other schemes. I think the question of retrospective legislation inevitably brings into conflict, as so many government decisions must do, not principle and expediency but different principles. No government of Liberal principles likes retrospective legislation. We have a lot of latter day converts to retrospective legislation, but four years ago the Leader of the Opposition put it around that he was opposed to retrospective legislation. Four years ago he was apparently misreported by four newspapers in this country which stated that he was personally worried about the amendments proposed by the Government regarding the Curran scheme. It was only because the Australian Council of Trade Unions put the heat on him that he changed his view. Now he parades in this House a view that retrospective legislation is and always has been the answer to this problem.

ANSWER.PARA: Retrospective legislation puts into conflict two very important principles. One of them, of course, is the general disdain of Liberal governments towards retrospective legislation. The other, of course, is the overall fairness and equity of the taxation system. Because of the illegal behaviour of some people involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, because the benefits derived by people in those schemes have been very considerable and because of the public concern about the prevalence of those schemes, the Government has decided that special circumstances do exist whereby, on this occasion, in putting those principles into balance, the principle of paying service to the overall fairness and equity of the taxation system and the perception of people in the community regarding the fairness and equity of the taxation system ought to take precedence over the Government's general concern about and disdain for, on proper grounds, retrospective legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Defence indicate when he will be able to determine the future of the Fleet Air Arm's fixed wing element at HMAS Albatross in Nowra? Does his Department recognise the urgent need to maintain the flying and maintenance skills at that base and the equipment involved if the Fleet Air Arm is to remain an effective force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that in the shop window display by the Royal Australian Navy last Monday, attended by a number of members of this place and by about 200 other representative citizens of the Australian community, the Navy showed its undoubted technical capability and its professionalism. Similarly, I know that at HMAS Albatross there is concern about the degree to which those who are in the Fleet Air Arm are going to be given an opportunity to preserve their capabilities in fixed wing aviation. The honourable gentleman, as the local member-and a very assiduous and competent one at that-has, on repeated occasions , expressed his own interest to ensure that those who are in his electorate and who are serving aboard HMAS Albatross should be given that opportunity. I believe that there is certainly, in the analysis being undertaken by the Department of Defence at the moment, a very comprehensive scrutiny being made not only of alternative hulls but also of the equipment and armaments that should be put on whatever equipment might be decided by the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope that it will be possible within the next couple of months to reach conclusions. However, as the honourable gentleman will be aware, it is necessary for us not only to look at our own situation but also to take into account the analyses being made by the Royal Navy and by the British Ministry of Defence following the Falklands conflict. It is quite essential that we examine those very carefully and ensure that in any parallel to our own situation we reach conclusions which are within the capacity of the pocket of the Australian taxpayer and also relevant to Australia's defence needs. I can assure the honourable gentleman nonetheless that I think every member of this place respects very greatly the contribution that has been made by members of the Royal Australian Navy, including those who are members of the Fleet Air Arm at HMAS Albatross.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the honourable member for Batman intends to lodge a request for detailed information relating to the administration of the Parliamentary departments?
—Yes. I seek information in relation to the operating of air conditioning systems.
—I ask the honourable member to give his question to the Clerk. If it is in order, it will appear in Hansard. In due course I will reply and the reply will appear in Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr McVEIGH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) has presented in the House today a list of the Sports Development Program grants for 1982-83 which amount, I believe, to $3.2m. While feeling pleased for those sporting bodies who have received a share of the $3.2m , I would like to make a few remarks about the inequality of sports grants as I see them. The total amount of the sports Budget this year is something like $26. 7m, which is fairly generous. It seems to me to be an awful inequality when only $3.2m of that goes to average sporting bodies, that is, the average Joe who is interested in amateur sport. I make that point today because it was revealed this week that in very recent times the Government has had to pay about $2m in compensation to television stations for advertising funds lost because of its proposed boycott of the Moscow Olympic Games. Of course, that is only the tip of the iceberg. The full cost of that proposed and desperately ill-advised boycott is likely to be in the order of $10m. It seems to me quite strange, therefore, that the Government can find only $3.2m this year to provide some assistance to all the amateur sporting bodies in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: To add to the confusion, the Government will be receiving about $80m in sales tax on sporting goods this financial year from people who are involved in amateur sporting bodies. It is no wonder that I, like most other members of this House, am receiving letters daily from sporting organisations throughout Australia screaming about the penurious nature of the Government in not granting them sufficient funds. In mentioning this report, I register the disregard of the Opposition for the amount of money involved and also, on behalf of all those sporting bodies, say a very niggardly thank you to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 6 (2) of the Australian Science and Technology Act 1978, I present reports prepared by the Australian Science and Technology Council entitled 'New Telescopes for Australian Astronomy in the 1990s' and 'Australian Science and Technology in International Co-operation and Development Assistance'. I seek leave to make a short statement concerning the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first is a report on 'New Telescopes for Australian Astronomy in the 1990's. Australia has established an enviable international reputation for its research in the field of astronomy. Many important discoveries and contributions to knowledge and understanding of the universe have been made in this country by Australian scientists from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. ASTEC's report recognises that if this high standard of research is to be maintained, new telescopes and other instruments will be required from time to time. ASTEC has examined two projects: The construction of a radio telescope, the Australia telescope, and an Australian contribution to a multinational space telescope project, Starlab.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will have seen from the Budget announcements that the Government has decided to act on ASTECs recommendation and construct the Australia telescope. This is to be a bicentennial project to be completed by 1988. It is appropriate that it should be a bicentennial project because the telescope will enable Australian astronomers to maintain their high international reputation and build on their past achievements of which they have every right to be justly proud. The telescope is to be operated by CSIRO but as a national facility. The Australia telescope will be a large radio synthesis telescope and will be constructed at a cost of $25m over six years. The sensitivity and resolution of the new telescope will be equal to or better than corresponding instruments in the northern hemisphere. The time had come when this decision had to be made-the old radio telescope at Parkes was outdated and inadequate to enable Australian scientists and astronomers to maintain their leading position among world astronomers. It is the Government's advice and the Government's intention that the new Australia telescope will enable our astronomers to maintain their leading position in the world.

The second project examined by ASTEC is Starlab. ASTEC has recommended some public funding for Starlab and the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) recently announced that a $3.33m grant will be made available for the Starlab project over the next two years. This will enable industry to develop and acquire the relevant new technology. In two years time we will be in a position to decide on Australia's future participation in Starlab.

The second report of ASTEC to which I draw the attention of honourable members is a background report on Australian science and technology in international co- operation and development assistance. The report draws together information on bilateral and multilateral co-operation including specific science and technology agreements and on development assistance programs, where Australia has taken a significant lead. I present the following paper:
Australian Science and Technology Council-Ministerial Statement, 23 September 1982.
Motion (by Mr Viner) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In my statement in Parliament on 21 September 1982, concerning the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, I referred to breakdowns and administrative failures in a number of areas of government administration over the last decade or so. These matters are obviously of the gravest concern to all Australians. Efficient and effective public administration is vital for maintaining the kind of Australia that we want for our children. The people of Australia have a right to expect good, honest, efficient and effective administration, and the Government is determined to take every possible step to ensure that this occurs. In each instance where there has been a breakdown in Public Service administration over recent years, the Government has made an appropriate and prompt response to remedy the deficiencies that have come to notice. But the Government believes that it is vital not only to remedy deficiencies in administration as they become known but also to look more broadly at the Public Service and the demands upon it in order to do whatever can be done to prevent such breakdowns occurring.

SPEECH.PARA: The general health of the Public Service, including its efficiency and management, must be a matter of the highest concern for government. The Public Service-broadly interpreted to include departments and authorities-must be equipped with the kinds of management structures and tools which will enable it to deliver government programs effectively to the people of Australia, and which will allow it to keep up with new technology and with changes in community and business requirements and attitudes. The Government believes there is a question whether the Public Service, as presently organised, has the management tools, the flexibility and the capacities to meet the challenges that presently exist and that lie ahead. Departments and authorities must be able not only to meet the demands of today but also to anticipate the demands of tomorrow.

There are three evolutionary changes which present challenges to public administration at the present time. The first is changing technology and the so- called information explosion. The Public Service needs to be able to cope with the significant technological changes and the growth of information which have been and will be taking place, including the relevance of computer technology to public administration. Governments and their agencies must be able to be responsive to, and to take advantage of, new methods of gathering, processing and applying information. But it is not just a matter of applying new technology to growing information. It is also a matter of knowing what information is needed, and in what form it is needed, to enable departments, authorities and Ministers to carry out their functions efficiently and effectively, and also a matter of being able to take practical steps for satisfying these requirements.

The second challenge is posed by the increasing demands on the public sector flowing from a greater involvement by government in areas such as social welfare , health, education and national development, plus many other areas of concern to the community. The increased scope and the wider activities of government obviously enlarge the responsibilities of public administration enormously and create difficulties in relation to adequate communications, accountability and control.

The third challenge, I regret to say, arises from a deterioration in what I might call the 'business ethics' of a minority. There was a time when the administration, in its relationships with business, could assume that a high degree of trust was appropriate. The Service did not have to be geared to handle cheating on a large scale. Of course, there have always been those in the community who have been prepared to get away with as much as they can without too much regard for what might be regarded as honour, let alone the law; but in the past this has not been an element which has put significant stress on the Service itself. As recent events relating to taxation, meat substitution and health schemes show only too clearly, there are those outside the administration -and I stress again that they are very much a minority-who are prepared to act ruthlessly in what they perceive as their own interests, without regard either to the interests of the community or to the observation of the law.

It is that third challenge which has been particularly instrumental in leading the Government to the view that at this time there is a need to look closely at the management tools, the flexibility and the capacity of the Service as presently organised. There have been a number of administrative breakdowns which have flowed from the Service's inability to respond speedily and adequately to the challenges posed by those who seek to behave unethically or even illegally. Those in the community who cheat on their obligations to others or attempt dishonestly to evade the law, whether by evading taxation or meat inspection regulations or any other laws or regulations, not only bring dishonour on themselves but also impose real strains on the Public Service of this country, and on the social and economic fabric which is vital to our way of life.

It is a particular tragedy that small numbers of failures by individuals who have fallen to temptation to give favours or seek favours have brought the Public Service into a degree of disrepute. The Public Service itself wants to respond to the criticisms that have been made against it. They are not criticisms that are made against the Service as a whole, but the Service as a whole is touched by them. Many public servants feel that the reputation of the Service has been badly tarnished by recent happenings and that it needs to re- establish the high reputation that it feels it has earned in the past.

I would not wish what I am saying to overshadow the very solid work that is being done in the greater part of the Public Service: It is unfortunate, but inevitable, that public attention tends to be focused on what is wrong, not on what is right. But I have said before and I say again now that I have enormous respect for the dedication and management skills of the Public Service, and for the people who staff it. By world standards we have a Public Service of high reputation. But the Public Service cannot live on its reputation and in particular it must meet changes with adequate administrative responses. It is clear that the Service needs to be a jump ahead of those who seek to frustrate it in carrying out its proper functions.

Both to assist in achieving this and to create the opportunity for the public to be reassured about the future of the Service, the Government proposes that there should be a report to the Government on aspects of the performance of the whole Commonwealth administration. Both through an examination of the underlying causes of major administrative deficiencies of the kind that have occurred in recent years, and through a wider examination of management skills and management structures throughout the Commonwealth Government departments and authorities, the review of Commonwealth Administration is to be asked to examine , report on and make recommendations in relation to the requirements for an efficient and effective Public Service in Australia and in particular to identify the demands and pressures placed upon the Public Service, and the mechanisms, procedures and management structures which are required to enable the Public Service to carry out its functions, implement Government policy and deliver programs effectively and efficiently to the people of Australia.

The Review in particular should take into account the need for the Public Service to have high standards and good morale; the need for the Public Service to provide the professional managerial component of public administration; the need for the Public Service to possess management skills and to develop management structures capable of meeting and responding to the challenges of an increasingly complex business, economic and social environment; the need for the Public Service to provide constructive and imaginative policy advice, and adequate mechanisms for ensuring the effective implementation of the Government' s policy decisions; and the need for accountability of the Public Service while maintaining the concept of a non-political career Public Service based on merit, capable of providing effective support for Ministers in relation to their administrative and policy-making responsibilities.

Although the review involves a major examination of Commonwealth administration , it is not intended that it should be a protracted one. The Government accepts that, in the interests of a timely completion of the Review, in some areas of concern it may be possible only to provide indications of further work that will need to be done to achieve the ultimate objective. It is not proposed that this Review should repeat the work done by the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, which was the first comprehensive review of government administration in over 50 years and had the broadest possible terms of reference. Nor is it proposed to duplicate the particular work done by parliamentary committees, by the Auditor-General, by the Public Service Board and by management consultants and others who may have examined, or be examining, particular aspects of the Service. This Review is to focus specifically on the management framework, the constraints which face public sector managers, and the challenges that they will have to confront in the future. The Government is looking for a report, from people of high reputation in their own business field , which assess what they see as the deficiencies, the problems and the appropriate remedies.

Mr J. B. Reid, A.O., has accepted the role of Chairman of the Review. Mr Reid is Chairman of James Hardie Industries Ltd, Vice Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd, and a Director of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Barclays International Australia Limited. He was a member of the Administrative Review Committee in 1975-76, chaired by Sir Henry Bland, and a member of the inquiry into the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories in 1978. He has been also a member of various other government bodies and currently is chairman of the Australian Bicentennial Authority. Mr Reid will be assisted by Sir Ronald Elliott, and Professor John Rose.

Sir Ronald Elliott is a Director of Brambles Industries Limited and International Commodities Clearing House Limited. He is the former Managing Director of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. Sir Ronald has been a member of the Council of the Administrative Staff College and is a Fellow of the Australian Institute of Management. Professor Rose is Sidney Myer Professor of Commerce and Business Administration at the University of Melbourne, and since 1976 has been a consultant in my private office. All three members of the Review are obviously well qualified for the task, and the Government is grateful to them for accepting this most important role.

The Review will have full access in all areas of government administration-to see and consult with whoever it determines, whether from inside or outside the Public Service and statutory authorities. The administration will have an opportunity to explain its task and its methods of carrying it out and, also, the nature of the constraints which distinguish government administration from the business world. People from outside the administration, with substantial and established reputations in the business world, will have an opportunity to say what they think the Public Service should be doing-and here the Review would be looking no doubt for positive and realistic guidance capable of being put into practical effect.

The inquiry will be assisted by a small secretariat, headed by Mr H. B. MacDonald, Deputy Secretary in the Department of Administrative Services. Mr Reid has indicated that he would expect to be able to report before the autumn sitting of the Parliament.

As I stated earlier and as no one in this House would deny, the people of Australia have a right to expect good, honest, efficient and effective administration in the public sector. With the assistance of this Review of Commonwealth Administration the Government is determined to see that they get it . I present the following paper:
Review of Commonwealth Administration-Ministerial Statement, 23 September 1982.
Motion (by Mr Fife) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

Smaller government means eliminating waste, duplication and unnecessary costs of government. It does not mean austerity. The benefits of our program are now visible for everyone to see.

I'll say they are! Standards have broken down in the Public Service because of the unreasonable strains which have been imposed upon it and because of the demoralisation which is a direct product of the Government's persistent abuse of it. That comment was a thinly veiled offensive observation about the Government' s lack of regard and respect for the Australian Public Service. The Public Service has been subjected to repeated attacks on the value and quality of what it has to offer the Australian community. Yet where does the fault rest? Look at the Public Service Board annual report of 1980-81. Under the chapter entitled ' Review of Major Developments' one reads:

1980-81 was a difficult year for the Service. Increasing workload and accountability, and the impact on the administration of new and changed legislation, tested the resources of the Service. By and large, the Service coped very well . . .

A different view of the Service is, however, part of the daily fare of anyone who watches current events. Public servants, it is said, are incompetent, idle, arrogant, pampered, strike-prone, and so on.
That is the Prime Minister for you! The Public Service Board went on to state:

Of course the Service, like many other employers, does have its share of people who may deserve such comment. That apart, public servants are used to being singled out for lampooning. But it becomes at best tedious, and at worst destructive of morale, for public servants to be incessantly the target of generalised and sweeping criticism, especially when it is only too rarely that contrary views from any quarters are expressed and given publicity.

That is the Public Service Board repudiating the Prime Minister. How does a public servant feel when he hears the sort of comment we had in 1979 from the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch)? He is reported in these terms:
. . . 11,000 less bureaucrats with their snouts in the trough . . .

Let us have a look at where the snouts are in the trough. We find people such as Denis Byrne Horgan, Syd Corser, Ronald Warren Woss, Gallus, Bruce McDonald, His Excellency-I stand to attention and am suitably deferential-the Honourable Sir Ransley Victor Garland who, if not successful anywhere else, knows how to strip companies for tax evasion purposes, and a number of others.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. The imputations made by the honourable member are totally unparliamentary and totally dishonourable.
—You protect tax dodgers, do you, Hodgman?
—No way.
—You are probably one yourself.
—I seek the withdrawal of that.
—The honourable member for Fremantle will withdraw.
—I withdraw.

—The point of order I take is that the Leader of the Opposition is making, in clear and unparliamentary terms, assertions against persons including Australia's High Commissioner which should be the basis of a substantive motion. It is totally unparliamentary and ought to be withdrawn.

—The people I referred to are all officials or are significant in the Liberal Party. I develop the point no further. There are snouts in the trough. Let us look at them; there are 17. In 1975 we were told that there would be no more jobs for the boys. Let us look at them: Dr Forbes, John England, Nigel Bowen, David Fairbairn, Gordon Freeth and Robert Cotton. The list goes on and on . We all remember Harry M. Miller who is a close confidante of the Government. I shall not outline all of them because I do not have the time, but there are 17 of them with snouts at the trough of the Public Service. They are Liberal- Country Party stooges, affiliates and former members; 17 prime porkers snorting with joy at the public trough that the Government trotted out to them.

SPEECH.PARA: What is wrong with the Public Service? I will tell honourable members one of the major problems. One of the major problems is that its capacity to function efficiently has been paralysed by quite injudicious, in fact, thoroughly ill- informed and malicious, staff ceilings. Let us look at the Auditor-General's report in the last couple of years and at the defects that he referred to as a result of staff ceilings imposed on the Public Service. These are limiting the efficiency of Public Service activities, preventing the properly scrutinised collection of revenues owing to the Commonwealth, preventing the proper scrutiny of payments made by the Commonwealth, interfering with law enforcement procedures and seriously curtailing safety procedures connected with both personal safety and property protection. For justification we go to the heart of the diversionary tactics. Things have gone bad for the Government. There is a smell of rottenness in the Liberal Party ranks which we have all identified for a long time-a sewage stench. The Government is trying to blame its deficiencies and failings on the Public Service.

Why is a Minister never, ever responsible in this Government in spite of clear evidence, in spite of indictment and condemnation by a royal commission of inquiry? One of the motivations is to try to shelve the blame for recent scandals in relation to tax on the Public Service. Undoubtedly some of it applies, but after looking at the voluminous folio of documents released by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) I am very pleased, on personal grounds and on citizenry grounds, that the Australian Taxation Office comes out of it so well. I am pleased, firstly on personal grounds, because I already had a high personal regard for the officers of that Office-this was one of my first observations when the report of the Costigan Royal Commission into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union was debated in this Parliament-and, secondly on citizenry grounds, because if we cannot have confidence in the impeccable integrity and ability of the Taxation Office then we have not got too much we can hang our hat on in this community. We find that the Taxation Office, apart from taking the proper initiatives, is crippled by staff shortages. I have a letter of 11 April 1978 to the Treasurer. It states:

We are spread very thinly with officers who have the necessary background and aptitude to develop anti-avoidance and other tax legislation. Any attempt to take on too much at any one time can be counter-productive.
I have another letter, again from the Commissioner of Taxation, of 11 July 1978 to the Treasurer. It states:

Needless to say, resources and other more urgent commitments allowing, I will continue to have my officers devote their capacities to unravelling, resisting and providing ways of countering these and any further schemes.

The facts are that if the Taxation Office had been provided with the proper personnel establishment level it could have worked more effectively and much more conclusively. This is the effect of false savings of the Fraser Government as a result of staff ceilings. According to the 1980-81 report of the Commissioner of Taxation the savings in salaries in the investigation section through staff ceilings amounted to about $1.5m. The lost revenue was $47m. It makes sense then for someone from Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to carry out an efficiency review of the Public Service after it has been established that BHP in its public declaration is totally inefficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —It cannot run its own affairs.

—It cannot run its own affairs. It institutionalises inefficiency. The Government is trying to get a scapegoat to take the heat off itself. There has been a long list of scapegoats. Whenever the Prime Minister is in trouble he will pick up a scapegoat. Whenever it has been clearly and convincingly established that the Government has been culpably responsible for a gross dereliction of duty he looks around for a victim and then punches the nearest victim in the nose, bowls him over and then abuses him for standing in the way. He has used the following scapegoats: The world economy, the unions, the Public Service, the education system, dole bludgers, State Premiers, Russians in Afghanistan, people ripping off the system-like members of the Liberal Party but on that occasion he was talking about the unfortunate Greeks-employers, Bert Kelly, Justice Woodward, Commissioner Costigan and the Liberal Party, but never the National Country Party. We have to say one thing about him. He is consistent . He is always indiscriminate.

SPEECH.PARA: I have only this to say: We all know what this is about. This is an effort by the Government to try to divert attention from its own very grave and culpable failures which have been released day after day in the most alarming manner. This is just an effort to try to engage the attention of members of the public on the Public Service and to convert them to the totally spurious belief that all of the responsibility rests with the Public Service. Most of the things the Government is talking about are matters which were covered by the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration or are being covered by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. This is a spurious proposition . We reject the Government's trying to make the Public Service a scapegoat.

DEBATE.TITLE: CROWN SOLICITOR'S DIVISION: JOINT MANAGEMENT REVIEW

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have discussed this matter with the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown). I ask for leave to make a very short statement in the course of tabling some papers.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the joint management review of the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor's Division. In answer to a question in the House on 7 September the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) indicated that consideration would be given to tabling the report of the joint management review of the Crown Solicitor's Division. That was in response to a question put to him by the honourable member for Parramatta. For the information of honourable members I have now tabled the report. Because of the size of the document and the cost of reproduction, only a restricted number of copies have been prepared and placed in the Parliamentary Library.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask leave to make a statement on another matter in the course of tabling a document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Monopoly Position of the Australian Postal Commission. My predecessor who is now the Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair, in September 1981 announced the appointment of a committee of inquiry to review Australia Post's monopoly powers. The Government's decision to establish this inquiry was made in the context of its consideration of the review of Commonwealth Functions. Individuals and organisations were invited to make submissions to the inquiry. Eighty-one submissions were received.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee of Inquiry has recommended in its report that the exclusive power of the Postal Commission to carry letters for reward should be continued with some changes. In particular, the Committee recommended that the Postal Services Act 1975 be amended to provide exemption from the statutory monopoly of the Australian Postal Commission for the carriage of letters for reward in the following cases: For letters for which a charge is levied at or above $2 for each letter carried; for letters, regardless of the amount charged, in circumstances where the Minister determines that suspension of the monopoly is warranted because the Australian Postal Commission is unable to provide a serivce; for letters between different branches of an organisation and between an organisation and its wholly-owned subsidiaries; and for letters which form inputs to, or outputs from, electronic transmission facilities.

The Committee has also recommended that the scope of Australia Post activities be widened to include operation of a postal courier service, provision of agency services on behalf of public and private sector principals, operation of electronic mail services and the underwriting of postal insurance. With regard to the financial arrangements of the Commission, the Committee of Inquiry has recommended that the Government should determine eligibility for concessions provided for registered publications, with the Commission receiving Budget subsidies for the service. The Committee also recommended that the Commission should establish a separate superannuation scheme with a benefit structure more closely aligned to private sector schemes and that the Commission should be required to pay all taxes or make payments in lieu. In addition, the Committee has recommended the removal of certain government controls on the Commission in the areas of staff ceilings, procurement and capital expenditure.

The Government will now examine the findings and recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry and will take into consideration any views on the report which the community may wish to express. It is intended that government decisions on the findings of the inquiry will be made at the earliest possible date. I wish to thank the inquiry Chairman, Mr Bradley, and the other members of the Committee, Mr Millar and Mr Garrett, and the inquiry staff for their work in producing the report. I present the following paper:
Australian Postal Commission-Monopoly Position-Report of Committee of Inquiry- Ministerial Statement, 23 September 1982.
Motion (by Mr Hodges) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond very briefly. The Opposition was handed the report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Monopoly Position of the Australian Postal Commission only about an hour ago and, of course, we cannot make a detailed response to it. I think this is an occasion when we can again feel sorry for the Government. It keeps establishing inquiries to do its work and the reports of these inquiries continue to blow up in the Government's face. The report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union must be the most celebrated example of an inquiry which blew up in the Government's face. After all, it was an inquiry which was set up to pursue the Painters and Dockers Union and, apparently, to establish some association between that organisation and its activities and the Australian Labor Party. It has completely backfired. We now find that Mr Costigan is busily pursuing tax dodgers right into the inner sanctum of the Liberal Party all around Australia. Similarly, we have had the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. Although the Government on that occasion responded by disparaging the Royal Commissioner, what resulted from that inquiry was that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) was found to be seriously wanting in relation to the administration of his Department.

SPEECH.PARA: Now we have another instance in which the Government established an inquiry, quite clearly with the object of establishing the circumstances whereby the Government could begin to flog off parts of the Australian Postal Commission and allow the private sector to take up an increasing part of the Postal Commission' s functions. The terms of reference of the Committee were:
. . . the Committee is requested to examine and report to the Minister for Communications on:
(a) the appropriateness of the present statutory functions and duties of the Australian Postal Commission; and
(b) whether there is scope for reducing or eliminating the exclusive power of the Commission to carry letters for reward.

When one considers that the author of those terms of reference was none other than the present Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair), there is no question that we were bound to conclude and entitled to suspect that there was some motive other than a sense of curiosity about the functions of the Australian Postal Commission and possible ways in which its operation could be changed.

What do we find? We find that this Committee, having done its work, has in fact repudiated the Government in respect of most of the important matters which it wanted the inquiry to pursue. For instance, the Committee's report recommends very strongly that the continuing monopoly position of the Australian Postal Commission should be maintained. It does so for the very good reason that the Opposition pointed out at the time when this inquiry was established. We argued that it is essential that the Postal Commission have a monopoly in order that a service be provided right around Australia with equal access by all people throughout the country rather than penalising those people who live in remote areas. Even more embarrasing for the Government is the fact that at the same time as this Committee of Inquiry was announced-that was at the time of the razor gang report-the Government in fact pre-empted the Committee by saying that the Australian Postal Commission would have to flog off its courier service. This service which had been established very successfully and which was running at a profit had to be flogged off by the Commission to private interests. What do we find as a result of this Committee's work? We find the recommendation that the Postal Commission should be provided with the capacity to run a postal courier service. The ideological view of the Government, symbolised in its action, that this profitable exercise of the Postal Commission should be flogged off, presumably to allow further opportunities for benevolent donors to the Liberal Party and National Country Party to have an opportunity to get the profits themselves rather than allow the profits to go to the Postal Commission and thereby help to subsidise the services which are provided to the rest of the community, has been completely repudiated by that finding from the inquiry.

I will not go through all the recommendations of the Committee. In total they amount to a repudiation in terms of what the Government was looking for. The important area in which the Committee recommends some diminution of controls over the Commission relates to removing from the Commission, to some extent, the restrictions which exist in relation to the Public Service. If that is what is necessary to ensure that this important and very successful public body operates more effectively, we have no objection to that being done. One matter ought to be referred to, however, and that is that the Committee has said that in relation to articles, the cost of carriage of which exceeds $2, there ought to be the opportunity for private competition. The Opposition makes the point that that limit seems to be too low. If one were to have that sort of premium explicitly provided for in the area in which there could be competition, one would want to express it in terms other than dollar terms. One possibility is that it should be expressed in terms of, say, ten times the normal postal rate. It is important that, if there is to be such a capacity, it ought to be set at a sufficiently high level so that the activities of the Postal Commission are not surreptitiously undermined.

There are important questions relating to electronic mail and the role of Australia Post in that area. I simply urge the Government that before acting on that matter it should consider it in the context of what Telecom Australia has to say and particularly, what was presented to the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia. I think those are important matters that have to be considered. I would welcome the opportunity in the future to have this matter brought back for debate so that the Opposition can expand to some extent on its views on the future of the Australian Postal Commission.
