TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable gentleman may proceed.

—In my capacity as Chairman of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts I wish to make a personal explanation to the House about an article which appeared in this morning's Sydney Daily Telegraph concerning medifraud. The article stated that Mr Brereton, the Minister for Health in New South Wales, is alleged to have said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Federal Public Accounts Committee has revealed such frauds in 1976 but the Federal Government had ignored them.

I wish to advise the House that I have had all the relevant reports which were tabled in Parliament in 1976 examined. So far as I am aware, there is no evidence which would support the statement in the Daily Telegraph.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a short personal explanation.
—Does the honourable gentleman claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes. Yesterday during the discussion in this House on the tabling of the Code of Practice on the Management of Radioactive Wastes from the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores I made a number of claims regarding the situation at the Ranger tailings dam in the Northern Territory. They were to the effect that the ground water was rising, creating pressure in the dam and forcing water out underneath the dam wall, and that the dam was not, in fact, constructed down to bedrock. I said that if there was a very great problem now after only one year there would be a very large problem in perhaps 15 or 20 years. I also said that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) had been informed of this over two months ago, that the information had come to me through the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Office of the Supervising Scientist and that the Minister had had a report from at least one of the authorities concerned-the Department of Mines and Energy in the Northern Territory or the Office of the Supervising Scientist-and had not in fact informed the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: After I finished my contribution the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment took the unusual step of seeking to make a reply. The Opposition gave him leave to do so and he made a further statement. Before the Minister did so, I showed him what in fact were my own memo notes. I did so out of courtesy, I would have thought, to save him perhaps from embarrassment if he were about to deny the claims. The Minister said in the reply which we had so courteously allowed him to make that I had in fact picked up a letter or a document which 'fell off the back of a truck'. In fact, I had no such letter. As I said, I referred merely to the memo notes that I showed the Minister regarding information received from the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Office of the Supervising Scientist. I repeat: I have no such letter from either office-that is, the Parks and Wildlife Service or the Supervising Scientist-nor any document from the back of a truck.

It perturbed me greatly to learn this morning from sources within the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Office of the Supervising Scientist that the Minister has now in fact instigated a sort of witch hunt over a mythical letter which he claims was sent to me by someone in the National Parks and Wildlife Service or his Department. In the interests of the establishment of integrity of the Department , the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the National Parks and Wildlife Service, I inform the House that the Minister is quite mistaken, that the material I showed him was not a letter or a document but was, in fact, my personal notes. I suggest, in conclusion, that the Minister table in the House immediately any report that he has on this very serious matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable gentleman claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes. Earlier this morning the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) took the opportunity apparently to deny or correct something which I said about him yesterday. In the process he was rather scathing in his description of my conduct and, in fact, made allegations about associations which he said I might have. Because I might have been wrong and because the Minister might be right, I just want to indicate what happened yesterday in the debate. I quoted from a speech which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made in which he likened tax dodgers to people who had received stolen funds. He said that the recipients of the funds have in their hands stolen funds. He was very critical of people for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply went on to make the point that the Minister for Defence had on an earlier occasion admitted to having been the beneficiary and having received funds which were mis- appropriated by his father and passed on to him. Indeed, the Minister for Defence had given an undertaking, had entered into a contract, to pay back that stolen money. If, in fact, the Minister has paid that stolen money back, all I want to say is congratulations. But maybe he ought to come into the House and tell us. All we know is that he entered into a contract to pay back that stolen money. Until he indicates to us that he has paid back that stolen money we are entitled to assume that he still holds it and we are entitled to draw attention to the inconsistency between the Prime Minister's view of tax dodgers and stolen money and of Ministers and stolen money.

The Minister went on to make the point that my views on this matter and my allegations in this regard had something to do with my association with the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia. I just say to the House that for the period during which the Painters and Dockers Union was affiliated with the Australian Labor Party-now, of course, it is not-it was affiliated on a State by State basis. Of course, members of the Labor Party belong to the Labor Party on a State by State basis. I am a member of the Western Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party. The Painters and Dockers Union does not exist as a union in Western Australia and has, therefore, never been affiliated with the Labor Party in Western Australia. Certainly it is not now.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Immigration-Parliament: Time Allocated to Private Members
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve today for the many hundreds of families in my electorate and indeed for thousands in other electorates who settled in this country and are unable to be reunited with members of their families overseas. In particular I grieve for those who believed the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs who said that more emphasis would be placed on family reunion when he announced in the House of Representatives on 29 October last year the new immigration policy to come into effect on 19 April 1982. In his statement the Minister said that the new system would:

SPEECH.PARA: Strongly favour skilled applicants and those with family in Australia.

He continued that most applicants have to say 'yes' to one of two questions: Have I close family ties with an Australian resident who can help me settle, or have I skills or personal qualities that will benefit Australia? Despite references elsewhere to the need for a job skill in demand the overwhelming emphasis in the Minister's announcement was on the substantial concessions given to family reunion. The Minister's statement was calculated to lead many thousands to believe that the Liberal Party had finally accepted the unanimous views of the ethnic communities that family reunion has to be given the highest priority in our immigration program. The fact that tens of thousands of applications were lodged soon after 19 April, the commencement date for the new immigration policy, shows clearly that the Minister's statement aroused high expectations amongst new settlers in Australia. Little did they know then what a cruel deceit the Minister's statement was. As with everything that this Government announces, people have yet to learn that there is a great difference between the Fraser Government's rhetoric and its actions.

I state quite clearly here, so it will not be open to misrepresentation, that I do not support unlimited or uncontrolled entry into Australia. I am also not in favour of a large influx of people especially when we have experienced, thanks to the Fraser Government, the worst economic slump since the Great Depression. As a matter of fact, it is the Liberal-National Country Party that set the migration target of 130,000 arrivals this year to enlarge the pool of unemployed to keep wages down. It is this conservative Government which accepts tens of thousands of refugees and brings in skilled workers while Australian tradesmen find it difficult to get a job. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges) then races around the country saying that unemployment is caused by migrants who take the jobs of Australians. How low can you get? The Minister is blaming immigration, which it is his job to administer, for the economic mismanagement of this Government. The Minister wants to have it both ways-he wants to bring in an excessive number of people from overseas to boost unemployment but then he turns around and blames the migrants, many of whom are the first victims of his Government's economic policies, for the depression.

I hope that in a few months' time when we become the Government we will put a brake on the unprecedented high influx of people during the current economic depression and return to a regulated immigration policy by setting the number of immigrants to the capacity of our economy to absorb. But at the same time we will not continue the Fraser Government's deceit; we will give the highest priority to family reunion. I know that honourable members opposite are itching to ask me how on earth I can advocate more family reunion and a lesser annual intake of migrants at the same time. I can tell them that there is no contradiction here whatsoever. We can have a much higher content of family migration inside an even reduced immigration program just as easily as the Fraser Government can reduce the intake under the family migration category while enlarging the overall intake. The family migration under this Government has fallen from 26 per cent to a mere 17 per cent of total intake in the last few years.

As I said before the Australian Labor Party will give the highest priority to family reunion when it comes to office. It will also do a more positive thing. It will get the Australian economy moving so that a vigorous immigration policy can be pursued. Let us get back to the cruel hoax perpetrated on ethnic communities in Australia. Since the new family migration scheme commenced on 19 April approximately 30,000 applications have been lodged with only one regional centre, in Melbourne. At the same time the Minister did not ensure that his Department was equipped to deal with such numbers of applications. Not enough staff are employed to process the applications and I suspect that this is done on purpose so that relatives in Australia will have to wait two or three years or longer before they get an answer. By the time the few clerks sift through the applications many migrants will have abandoned any hope of seeing their brothers , sisters or parents again.

To make things worse the Department does not have enough sponsorship forms on hand. My office was inundated with requests for forms and I had great difficulty in obtaining them. On two occasions I had to send telegrams to the Minister with my request for sponsorship forms. Even then it took more than a fortnight to receive the forms. I can imagine how long it takes to get forms if one does not wire the Minister for them. While the many migrants who went to all the trouble to fill out the forms are awaiting hopefully the Department's yeas or nays to their request to bring out their relatives, little do they know in what a shambles the Minister's Department is. Some people were lucky enough to receive an acknowledgement of their application in which the Department advised them to wait patiently and not even to make inquiries as to what happened to their applications as the Department has no staff to answer their inquiries. What a department the Minister presides over!

I do not think that one has to be a genius to perceive that the slowing down of the processing of applications is a deliberate tactic by the Minister to reduce family migration. I wish that the Minister-I am glad to see him in the House- would come clean on this and tell the truth to the thousands of hopeful migrant families that the new family migration system introduced by his predecessor was a hoax and that under the new system it will be even harder to bring a relative out than under the old discredited Numerical Multifactor Assessment System. Honourable members opposite can argue that we have to reduce our immigration intake because of the economic crisis Australia is in. I have no quarrel with that. I reiterate that I am not advocating a higher intake. I am saying that the highest priority should be given to those intending migrants who have close relatives in Australia. The Government is accepting up to 20,000 refugees a year . These are mainly Indo-Chinese refugees. I accept that we have some humanitarian obligations but I do not think that the Fraser Government can argue on this score, because although accepting refugees from Vietnam it refuses to accept relatives of people who live in South America under military dictatorships such as those in Chile, Argentina or Uruguay where they are threatened by the secret police and concentration camps.

Like many other members, I have received scores of complaints from Latin American migrants whose families are maltreated by the authorities in their own countries. Yet the Fraser Government's selective humanitarianism prevents them from joining their families here. Why does the Minister not allow relatives of Lebanese living in Australia to come here-Lebanese who are under threat of massacre and who are being killed in scores of hundreds every day? After all, charity starts at home. If we have any humanitarian obligations, our obligation is first to those people who have successfully settled here and whose relations are in distress in their respective countries. We should keep in mind that all the boat people we received here will also press-quite rightly-for the right to bring their close relations to Australia too.

Finally, there is another category of migrants that the Government is so keen to recruit; namely, people who come here to take up jobs required by some industries. While the Government was quick to oblige the bosses, many tradesmen who were recruited came out here only to find that their jobs were no longer here by the time they arrived. Even if such people find jobs, let us not forget that they too leave families behind and they too have brothers and sisters who might not be boilermakers or electricians. What will the Minister say when they naturally ask the Government to allow their families to be reunited with them in this country? I have stated time and again that the best migrants for this country are those who have relatives who have settled here successfully before them. The family support provided to them will help their absorption into our community and will help to create a happier nation. I call on the Government for once to be humane and understanding and to accept the Labor Party's policy of high priority to family migration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — This is the second time in the space of a fortnight that I have been listed to speak in a grievance debate so that I may have the opportunity to bring up something of interest to my electorate and to the nation. It is the second occasion on which the time I have to deliver my speech in the grievance debate has shrunk to two or three minutes. That brings me to the text of my grievance today. While the Standing Orders provide for honourable members to grieve, the time allowed to them has been shrinking. This morning is a typical example of Government Business displacing time allocated to private members. This happens not only on Grievance Day; it also happens at Question Time and in the adjournment debate in the evening. The encroachment of Government Business and of other matters such as personal explanations seems to grind down, to shrink, the time available.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just had a look at the Standing Order under which this House is operating; that is Standing Order 106. I was wondering whether in my grievance I could suggest to the powers that be that the time allowed for grievances be a set time and that, if necessary, the time allowed for Government Business be shrunk and not the time allowed to private members. As I understand Standing Order 106, it does not give the Parliament any leeway to extend that time to what might be an acceptable period. I notice that nine honourable members were on the list of speakers today. That would require a grievance debate lasting for an hour and a half. I had some good material to speak about. It is the second time in a fortnight that I have been unable to deliver my speech in the Grievance Debate. It seems that I cannot get back into the debate unless I talk about the Ord River or the Burdekin Dam!

In the last few moments available to me I suggest to the Leader of the House ( Sir James Killen) and to those who have responsibility for the Standing Orders that Standing Order 106 be reviewed and amended so that something is done about the time allocated for this debate. I believe one hour should be the minimum period. I turn to the adjournment debate when one half hour is allowed to private members to say what they wish. I notice that the tendency again has been for Government Business to encroach into that time. Again our time has been whittled away. Another inconsistency is that in time allocated to private members an Opposition member is allowed the first speech and is followed by a Government member. It appears to me that the rules and regulations weigh very heavily in favour of Opposition members and against Government members. I suggest to the House that all this needs very close scrutiny.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The belated and inadequate response of the Government to the problems of medical fraud and overservicing.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is compelled to bring this matter before the House, given the present attitude of the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) to the medical fraud and overservicing problem. He made the following statement to the Parliament last week:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I am absolutely not going to be stampeded into making stupid, fast decisions . . .

That might have been an acceptable explanation and not the feeble excuse that it is if in the past seven years the Government had acted with speed and dispatch in recognising the problem and magnitude of doctor fraud and overservicing. But that is not so. One could describe the response to the problem of this Government over seven years as a crab-wise approach at the pace of a snail. There is overwhelming evidence for that statement. Indeed, when we look at the approach of Mr Hunt, Mr MacKellar and now Mr Carlton to this issue we see that there is not the slightest danger of being trampled on by a horde of stampeding Ministers.

Again, the Minister's comment might have been an acceptable explanation and not the feeble excuse that it is if the Government had acted with any resolution once it had recognised the magnitude of the fraud and overservicing problem. But again this is not so.

The paucity of the Government's response is the most characteristic feature of its response to medical fraud and overservicing to date. The Minister said that he would not be stampeded into making stupid and fast decisions because he was waiting on the interim report from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts due, we hope, in November. Let us hope it comes before the Parliament rises or before we are sent off for an election. I will deal later with the insubstantial nature of that part of the excuse. One should notice that even the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), now notorious for his blindness to the corruption in the meat export industry, acted with vigour immediately the magnitude of the problem was brought to his rather blinkered vision. It can be said that in due course he acted promptly. At least he did not wait for a royal commission to report before he acted. As the estimates given both to the Public Accounts Committee and to others indicate that up to $12m in overpayments a month is occurring, a more vigorous response than we are getting from the Minister is demanded, particularly in light of the Government's past reactions.

First, let us look at its belated recognition of the problem simply by examining its response. In April 1977 it is true that there was legislative provision for medical services committees of inquiry to deal with overservicing but none of these committees met until June 1978 and in some States no references were made to these committees until five years after the legislation was introduced. Again, in April 1981 the Fraud and Overservicing Detection System-FODS-was established and for the first time an effective system for monitoring doctor fraud and overservicing was set up. But that was some six years after this Government came to power and several years after there was fairly massive evidence about the extent of doctor fraud and overservicing. In April 1982 the Health Legislation Amendment Bill imposed medical sanctions on doctors found guilty of two or more fraud charges. They were to be denied access to medical benefits for three years. It is interesting that the sanctions were presented but that nothing much was done about making more effective both the detection and the conviction of doctors for fraud cases.

The first question that we need to ask is: Why, apart from the medical services committees of inquiry, was nothing done until the 1980s? Why was no significant action taken until the 1980s apart from the setting up of the medical services committees of inquiry? Did the Government and the Department of Health have no inkling that funds and government were being milked by over $100m annually? The answer to that is unambiguous. They should have known. If the Department was doing its duty and the Minister for Health was acting responsibly they could not have avoided knowing. Medibank, by the end of 1976, recognised a problem of some magnitude. In 1978 the Department of Health learnt of a 1977 Medibank estimate of fraud and overservicing payments of approximately $100m. In 1979 the private funds constantly expressed to the Government disquiet over the extent of medical fraud and overservicing. But both the Department and Ministers had reason for knowing much earlier. The efficiency and scope of the original Medibank had clearly indicated the problem to them in 1976. Prior to Medibank there was no monitoring of doctor fraud and overservicing through the private funds. There was a naive manual monitoring of the pensioner medical scheme. Interestingly, in that period before Medibank, the vast majority of prosecutions in the medical field were of patients, not of doctors. Doctors, apparently, were not the problem although as there was no effective monitoring of doctors there is no way of verifying this.

Medibank Standard came in in July 1975. There is now a well built up Liberal mythology about that. Medibank Standard was introduced into a veritable medical Garden of Eden, into the best possible of medical worlds with the best possible levels of servicing. It was said that overnight a significant minority of doctors were bitten by the overservicing and fraud serpents and fell into evil ways. That is very much a fantasy as I will show in a moment, but it was trumpeted by former Ministers for Health. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), the present Minister for Transport and Construction, used always to talk about the Labor Party stuffing the doctors' mouths with gold. If he really believed that it is surprising that for four years he took no significant actions about this process of, in his own wards, stuffing doctors' mouths with gold. The next Minister for Health, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), believed that bulk billing was very much the source of the doctors' fall. Such views, even if the Ministers were mistaken, should have made them suspicious of the doctors. But of course, these views are nonsense. They assume that doctors were innocent and virginal until 30 June 1975 and were seduced and corrupted on 1 and 2 July 1975. The Director-General of Health, who I am afraid is not always particularly percipient in these matters, was quite percipient on this point. He noted, 'fraud is as old as Hippocrates himself'. In fact that oath was designed to deal with some early medical problems. More specifically, the Australian Medical Association submission to the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts points out:
Any system of medical care, in which a third party is responsible for paying the whole or part of the cost of a medical service, is potentially open to abuse .
It does not matter whether the third party is a private insurance body or a public fund. If one has a fee for service payment plus public or private insurance the system is open to abuse.

Let us put the fantasy aside. Medibank in fact made two contributions to this problem. First of all, it undoubtedly expanded the possible scope of fraud by enabling fraudulent doctors to rip off the poor as well as the rich. The aim of Medibank was to extend health cover right across the board so obviously, whereas in the past doctors no doubt ripped off the rich they now had the opportunity of ripping off the poor as well. More importantly in relation to this argument Medibank provided the first computerised payment system and, with it, the widest possible population from which to extrapolate and therefore to detect fraud and overservicing. Medibank was therefore very soon aware of the problems of fraud and overservicing. Indeed, within six months an officer was sent to Canada to examine Canada's fraud and overservicing and monitoring provisions. By the end of 1976 Medibank recognised that there was 'a problem of some magnitude in fraud and overservicing.' The Department of Health sometimes uses as an excuse the fact that the Health Insurance Commission which ran Medibank was separate from the Department of Health. That is a kind of bureaucratic response. It is formally true but there were constant links between the Health Insurance Commission and the Department of Health. Indeed, for much of the period about which we are talking the Director-General of Health was also the Chairman of the Health Insurance Commission. There was no doubt in the evidence that there were constant contacts back and forth about these problems. The destruction of Medibank in late 1976 undermined the immediate potential for an effective monitoring system because it did away with that superb data basis. One of the great ironies of this whole issue is that this Liberal Government, in its ideological obsessions, got rid of Medibank, destroyed that invaluable data basis and, then, three or four years later, had to begin all over again to create an effective data basis on which to base an effective monitoring system. From October 1976-that is, from the end of Medibank Standard-to November 1978 there was a clear loss of control in the Department of Health. There was a rather inefficient, laissez-faire attitude to the whole issue of monitoring and control as the system slipped back towards the private sector. Of course the whole problem for the Department of Health was exacerbated by continual major changes in health insurance arrangements. It was very difficult to keep one's eye on the doctors if at the same time there were constant changes in the health insurance arrangements. In those two years 1976 to 1978 the data basis built up in the Medibank period was sacrificed primarily for ideological reasons.

From November 1978 the Department of Health began to realise its mistakes and began again to create the data basis which had been abandoned two years before. But it must be said that the top echelon of the Department of Health-the evidence for this is overwhelming-was a rather aging elite, quite unsympathetic to the sort of technology required for monitoring in the late twentieth century. It tended to ignore the problems thrown up by the data base in the hope that somehow they would go away. I think it has also to be recognised that it was mostly a medical elite whose members seemed quite incredulous that their fellow professionals should so blatantly milk the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were also inefficient.

—As well, probably. Presiding over these four years of virtual inaction from 1975 to 1979 was the then Minister for Health, the present Minister for Transport and Construction. From which party does that former Minister for Health come? Of course, he comes from the chook raffle party, the National Country Party. We know about Country Party Ministers. It is about time that it was said in this House that the Country Party Ministers are like slugs. The slime of their incompetence, their inabilities, their dereliction of responsibilities trails through every office they inhabit. There is no doubt in my mind that when this scandal is fully exhumed and exposed much of the responsibility will rest on the present Minister for Transport and Construction.

SPEECH.PARA: Let it be said of the succeeding Minister, the honourable member for Warringah, Mr MacKellar, that as the Australian Medical Association pointed out in evidence a distinct change came over the whole business with the change from Mr Hunt to Mr MacKellar. I think we have to give the honourable member for Warringah credit for at least recognising the problem. He did not like talking about it very much . He left the AMA and the ALP to draw the whole issue to the attention of the public and he did not, in fact, do very much about it. He brought FODS to completion, he improved marginally the MSCIs and he introduced medical benefit sanctions on doctors convicted of fraud. At least he deserves the credit for recognising that a problem existed after four years of governmental refusal to recognise this massive fraud on the public.

But there is still no real sense of urgency in the Department of Health in regard to the problem. The quality and quantity of officers in claims review and investigation remains disappointing. The training of medical counsellors is inadequate. Too often the training required seems to be just chummy chats. There is no sense of overall cohesion and direction in the Department of Health in relation to medical fraud and overservicing. Some regional offices are active. For example, the Western Australian office seems to be active although it is plagued by problems from the notorious Crown Solicitor's Office in that State. Other offices are relatively inactive-for example, that in my own State of South Australia-while other regional offices, for example, in Victoria, seem to have developed elaborate bargaining activities with the most blatant offenders. There is no overall cohesion, no overall national policy, no effective responsibility from the State branches up the line to the central bodies. The MSCIs are simply log-jammed. To date they have completed 31 referrals. At present they are working on another 30, with something like 80 referrals pending. That log-jam simply has to be broken. I believe that the whole approach of the MSCIs has to change.

The need to examine critically the health legislation, the schedules, the policy and the claiming documents to remove ambiguities and legal loopholes has been recognised for at least three years; yet nothing has been done. For at least a year the Government has had proposals before it-a range of options-so that the magnitude of individual doctor fraud could be brought before the courts after conviction but before sentencing. Again, the choice has not been made as to which line to follow. The Opposition has no desire to stampede the Minister; it desires him simply, in the face of this sorry saga, to take some immediate actions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand that the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) would feel obliged to bring this matter of public importance before the House on this occasion because there has been a lot of publicity in the Press and generally arising out of the inquiry being held by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into the payment of Commonwealth medical benefits. Some of the publicity has been quite unfortunate in the sense that all those decent people who are doing good doctoring around the country and whose services are very much appreciated by their patients feel that they are under some form of attack.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I should say right at the start that over the next three months, in the course of which I am sure this controversy will continue-certainly at the time when the Public Accounts Committee report is presented, my colleague the honourable member for Bonython will have to raise an even larger stink in the Parliament than he is doing now-I will stand up for and defend the integrity of the good doctor. Fortunately, most of the doctors in the community are good doctors. Here I draw a very substantial distinction between the honourable member for Bonython and his parliamentary leader. The Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Hayden) has been saying things around the country which would indicate that there is some sort of class warfare or anti-professional warfare against doctors . I deplore this. On a most unfortunate occasion in Victoria, at the Preston and Northcote Community Hospital on Friday, 18 September 1981, the Leader of the Opposition made a gross and unfair attack against the medical profession generally. I am not accusing the honourable member for Bonython of doing this because he, in his address to the Australian Medical Association and in various other statements, has been careful to draw a distinction between good and poor professional practices. I shall quote one sentence to indicate the tone of that address by the Leader of the Opposition, which brings in a very unfortunate flavour to this kind of debate. He said:
In short, in an imperfect market environment the health care system is rigged by doctors to satisfy their pecuniary aspirations.

He did not say 'some doctors' or 'bad doctors'; he said 'doctors'. I make it absolutely clear to the doctors in the community who, for the most part, are obviously people of the greatest integrity and who perform an absolutely essential service to keep the health care services of the country alive, that they have the respect of their patients and, despite the furore, of most of the public. I think it is important for me as the Federal Minister and for my State colleagues-although one of them, I am afraid, has fallen down on this aspect in the last 24 hours-to support the good doctors.

Having said that, I refer to the matters that the honourable member for Bonython I believe quite properly raised. I do not think anybody could stand by and listen to the evidence that has been given before the Public Accounts Committee inquiry over the last few weeks without asking very serious questions as to how long substantial fraud and overservicing might have been going on in regard to the payment of medical benefits and how quickly the public sector reacted to it. Indeed members of the Opposition have a particular interest-even greater than ours, I suspect-in worrying about how the public sector might react because their policy requires a substantial extension of the activities of the public sector in the provision of health care and, certainly, in health insurance. They extended the scope of the Government very substantially indeed between 1972 and 1975 and in doing so, of course, expanded the areas in which fraud or overservicing could occur. I notice also that in the policy that they have been putting up for future elections-this has been promoted around the countryside by the honourable member for Bonython-they want to extend bulk billing. They say in their policy that where the doctor agrees bulk billing will be available to everyone so that the patient does not have to claim a refund for the cost of medical treatment. That of course would tend to remove one of those checks in the system which have at least some modifying effect on the capacity of people to indulge in fraud or overservicing.

Let us make clear the difference between fraud and overservicing because we will make very grave mistakes if we do not draw that clear distinction. Fraud occurs when a service is just not provided but a benefit is asked for in relation to an alleged service. That is a clear case in which somebody seeks to defraud the taxpayer-the person paying medical insurance-and it is downright criminal. There is absolutely no doubt about it. Those cases are matters for police action and prosecution.

The second area, overservicing, is much more difficult to determine. Although it is possible, under existing systems, to look at computer profiles which are prepared by the Department of Health to see a pattern of servicing which appears to be different from the average, it is not possible from that computer profile to see whether that additional servicing was done in the interests of the patient, according to the professional judgment of the provider, or whether it was done in order to attract further income. In many cases it is very hard to draw a distinction between those two activities. The conscientious doctor will want to see a patient again, having prescribed some medicine or some course of treatment, to ensure that that course has been followed, or out of a genuine concern for the welfare of the patient. Another doctor would assume that the patient's friends or relatives or the patient himself would do all the right things and would go back to the doctor and make a further request if there were any difficulty later. I think we have all encountered doctors who, quite satisfactorily and helpfully from the point of view of the patient, have made another visit or suggested that patients come back to the surgery to be looked at or have a discussion about a course of treatment.

There is an understandable concern amongst good doctors and highly professional people that the general public will not make this distinction. When there is a lot of Press activity, publicity and accusation, it becomes even more difficult to make this distinction. Therefore, I urge everybody who is talking about this matter to make it clear that it is not always the case that overservicing is caused by an attempt by a doctor to get more money out of the system. It may well be a wise professional judgment.

Having said that, I go on to deal with what I think we ought to do. I said last week-I stick by this statement-that I will not be rushed into making immediate decisions on the basis of unfolding evidence or accusations which might be ill- considered. I realise the frustrations and concerns of my friend opposite but it would just not be sensible of me to do that. Since taking over this portfolio four months ago, I have treated this matter as one of the major issues I have to look at, in common, I might say, with many others. I have very grave concerns about our care for the aged program and our general policies in relation to nursing homes. I think there are a lot of difficulties in those areas. I believe about six or seven other major issues require a great deal of my personal attention in order to achieve a satisfactory solution. But I have certainly devoted a fair proportion of my time, which is very much occupied in all respects, to this problem in order to gain a detailed personal understanding of it and of the underlying requirements.

I have also had a look in detail at what has been done over the last few years in order to respond to the various stages of disclosure of the problem. I made available to the Public Accounts Committee material from the Department which will enable members of that Committee to come to a conclusion about the response by officials and Ministers. No doubt the Committee will be doing that. Its report is only about eight weeks away. When I inquired about the matter a few weeks ago I was advised by the Chairman of the Committee that, given the nature of the inquiry and the complications of the matter at which the Committee was looking, the Committee did not think it would bring down a report until well into next year. I expressed concern about that because my firm conclusions about the new steps I might take will be ready, I believe, by mid-November. It would be singularly unfortunate if I had to go ahead and act on those views without the advice of the Public Accounts Committee.

The Public Accounts Committee, for which I have the greatest respect, has brought in reports in the health area in the past. Within the last four months I have read ones that relate to my departmental responsibilities and, indeed, have acted on certain areas mentioned in those reports which still required action. I believe that the fact that the Committee is bipartisan is very useful in that nobody will be able to say that that Committee has covered up anything or that it did not address itself to the main issues. I suspect that the aspect that will be difficult to distinguish-I think this has been properly raised by my friend the honourable member for Bonython-is the extent to which bodies in the public sector will react to changing circumstances. It is a matter which is of grave concern to all members of this House. It was reflected in the statement made this morning by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) when he referred to the very great difficulties of public sector administration in reacting to the complexities of the modern world.

My friends opposite have a very substantial interest in this matter, as we do; they even more so perhaps because they have a more optimistic view than we have of the capacity of public administration to deal with the nation's problems. We believe much more in private sector provision on the understanding that the public sector is, by its very nature, cautious in reaction. It does not react very quickly to market forces, external forces of any kind, or even criminal forces. It is relatively slow to react in a proper way in many respects because it has to worry about the public purse. Sometimes the very restraints on it which are designed to protect the public purse also prevent it from reacting where there is a threat to the public purse from other directions, such as crookedness or some other means.

It may well be that the Public Accounts Committee will take the view that the reaction was slow. Some of the evidence suggests that. I certainly am unable, given the number of hours in each day and the number of things I have to worry about, to read each piece of public evidence or each submission to that Committee every day. I just cannot do it. Therefore, I have not been able to form a balanced view-as that Committee will in some eight weeks' time-as to what the response of the public sector has been. I merely say at this point that it would not surprise me if that Committee found that that response had been slower than people might have expected. I must say that I would be astonished if it were found that the public sector had responded much more rapidly to changing external circumstances than one is wont to expect of the local grocery store, the local drycleaner and so on. It is not the normal procedure for the public sector suddenly to offer one-hour drycleaning when previously it has been offering it on a 24-hour basis, or to make improvements to meet the requirements of customers when there is a monopoly provision. There are also a number of rules which are designed to protect the public purse but which require departments to go through the Public Service Board and to obtain other approvals before they do various things.

Quite apart from all that-I am not denying that the honourable member for Bonython may suggest some things once he has had a chance to examine the report of the Public Accounts Committee-there may well be quite reasonable suggestions that things might have been done earlier. It will be interesting to observe the relationship between the Department and the Ministers. From my examination of ministerial correspondence going back over the years, I have no reason to believe that my two ministerial predecessors, the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) and the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), failed to act on matters that were brought to their attention. The Public Accounts Committee will be able to examine that material and make its judgment. At the time that material comes before the Parliament and the House, I am sure that my honourable friend opposite will wish to raise the matter more substantially. I certainly will not draw back from responding much more substantially than I do now.

In the meantime, I merely say that I am very active in the area. I certainly see at least three areas where further action over and above that taken by my predecessors will need to be taken. I certainly am not limiting my examinations to the areas looked at by the Public Accounts Committee. I think I have a wider duty than that. Certainly it is a duty to this House and the Australian people which I hope to be able to live up to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Benefits: Private Enterprise
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Retirement Benefits: Private Enterprise
The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth our concern that:
1. The Income Tax Assessment Act (the Act) and its administration is inadequate in providing retirement benefits for employees in private enterprise;
2. The Commissioner of Taxation (Commissioner) denies deductions necessary to index retirement pensions;
3. Deductions for the self-employed and employed are inadequate;
4. The Commissioner has exercised his discretion improperly by negating a choice the Act allows on investment in Government Securities;
5. The Commissioner's constant alterations to guidelines and lack of communication has created great uncertainty;
6. The Commissioner is acting arbitrarily, and without proper notice in restricting trustee's investments with employers;
7. The Commissioner seeks to apply new actuarial guidelines retrospectively to July 1981.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, take action to remedy these inadequacies and in particular we pray that action be taken:
(i) To ensure that the Commissioner exercises his discretion only with proper regard to legal principles;
(ii) To ensure that the Commissioner does not delegate to auditors part of his function of administering the Act;
(iii) To enact legislation allowing proper levels of retirement benefits to be provided;
(iv) To ensure that retirement benefits are regulated by a Department with a primarily social welfare function.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Falconer and Mr Mildren.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
That Family Radio Ltd represents the largest single interest group in the community-i.e., Christians-who do not have a voice in public broadcasting commensurate with their representation.
That prime time access to existing broadcasts by Christian groups is virtually non-existent, and access at other times is fast disappearing.
That, by comparison with other capitals, Brisbane is entitled to at least one more category 'S' FM Broadcasting Licence.
That there appears to be no prospect of the release of further category 'S' FM licences in the near future for Brisbane.
That satisfactory fulfilment of the aims of Family Radio and its expansion can only be achieved by broadcasting in its own right under licence.

That Family Radio has a responsibility to the large support groups which have contributed substantially to its development, to achieve the aims in broadcasting and community work for which it was established.

That there is an urgent need for the kind of service and support that Family Radio can provide to other community groups through the particular type of integrated programming proposed by the company under a full-time licence.
And that pruned government resources are obviously insufficient to advance the development of public broadcasting as originally intended.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will support Family Radio's application for a broadcasting licence and will enable more category 'S' FM licences to be made available in Brisbane.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aid for Disabled Children
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled: The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the association known as Ansua Queensland (A New Start for the Under Achiever) helps children who have learning difficulties, behaviour problems and/ or delayed development caused by inadequate motor sensory integration. Positive assistance is offered by parental counselling and provision of specific therapy and remedial educational programmes.

That Ansua Queensland has grown out of community need. The present limited resources of Ansua make it impossible for Ansua to meet the ever-increasing demands made on the organisation by the community. Ansua provides positive help and support services, not available elsewhere, for parents and their children.

That Ansua Queensland's success in this regard is indicated by the growing numbers of people throughout Queensland waiting to receive assistance for their children: and requests for the establishment of Ansua centres on the Atherton Tablelands and in Mt. Isa, and for regular servicing by Ansua staff of a number of coastal and country centres.
That the Federal Government has offered no form of assistance to Ansua Queensland in helping children to overcome their learning difficulties, even during the international year of the disabled.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will recognise the successful work of Ansua Queensland and assist Ansua Queensland in meeting the growing needs of learning disabled children in the Australian community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Government Spending
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in 1978 the United Nations Secretary-General called upon all nations to allocate 0.1% of defence spending for work on PEACE through arms control and disarmament; to date, Australia has not responded positively to this call.
That defence spending in Australia this year is estimated at approximately 4 billion dollars.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Australia allocate 0.1% of defence spending for work on peace.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Assent reported.
Bill presented by Mr Wilson, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ELECTORATE: (Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 is an omnibus Bill, gathering together those social security and welfare initiatives of the 1982-83 Budget that require legislation. Part VI of the Bill contains the major initiatives it deals with in the form of amendments to the Social Security Act 1947. Part II amends the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, and Part V the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970. The Bill also deals, in Parts III and IV, with consequential amendments to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and the Defence (Re-establishment) Act 1965, and makes minor amendments to the Social Services Amendment Act 1979 in Part VII and the Social Services Amendment Act 1981 in Part VIII. There are further minor amendments to the main Acts in the other parts of the Bill. Since these minor amendments have no policy significance and do not involve expenditure, I do not propose to discuss them in detail.

The major initiatives embodied in this Bill consolidate and extend the steps taken by the Government in last year's Budget to direct available increases in welfare expenditure to those in the greatest need. In 1981-82 we identified three groups as being in need of particular help. These were families with three or more children, pensioners who pay private rents, and those single unemployment beneficiaries over 18 years of age whose benefits are not automatically indexed. Our assistance to them, through increased rates of family allowance for third and subsequent children, increased supplementary assistance and an increased single rate of unemployment benefit, represented, in our view, the best use of the increases in expenditure we were able to make at that time over and above the increases to which we were committed by the regular twice- yearly consumer price index-linked increases in most standard pension and benefit rates. In the 1982-83 Budget we have again introduced measures that will assist all three of these groups, as well as taking further steps to alleviate some of the pressure points in the system-particularly those that result from inflation. We have also enhanced the incentives for recipients of social security payments to improve their own positions, and so become less dependent on the Government.

This year's Budget provides for an increase in social security and welfare expenditure by the Department of Social Security from the $9,997m in 1981-82 to $11,471m. After allowing for the additional pay-day last year this is an effective increase of 18 per cent. This is a somewhat larger increase than we have seen in this area in recent years. A large part of the 1982-83 increase- some 75 per cent-is accounted for by the guaranteed indexation provisions I have already mentioned, increases in the estimated number of pensioners and beneficiaries the Department of Social Security will assist during the coming year, and other cost increases that are unavoidably built into the system. This Bill embodies most of the major initiatives, apart from some increases in overall funds available for certain subsidy programs that account for the remainder of this year's increase. I now turn to explaining the main initiatives contained in the Bill. A detailed explanatory memorandum has been circulated for the information of honourable members.
AGED OR DISABLED PERSONS HOMES ACT 1954

Clause 6 of this Bill amends the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 to increase the rate of personal care subsidy for frail aged people. This subsidy helps organisations providing accommodation for elderly people to meet the cost of employing staff to provide additional services for frail aged residents, such as assistance with bathing or dressing, room cleaning, personal laundry, supervision of medicine, or for a staff member to be available at all times. At the end of June 1982 a total of 780 hostels were receiving the subsidy, helping to meet the cost of additional services for approximately 21,700 frail aged residents.

This Bill increases the subsidy from $80 to $120 for each eligible person for a four-week period-or from $20 to $30 a week-with effect from 6 July 1982. This rise represents an increase of 100 per cent in the subsidy since October 1980, when the rate was last increased-from $15 to $20 a week-and will help to ensure that a high standard of care continues to be provided for our frail aged citizens. The estimated expenditure on this subsidy for 1982-83 is $35m-an increase of 57 per cent over last year's outlay.
DELIVERED MEALS SUBSIDY ACT

The subsidy for meals-on-wheels services is increased by an amendment to the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970. Clause 22 of the Bill will increase the subsidy available from October 1982 from 45c to 55c for a meal where a vitamin C supplement-in the form of fresh fruit or fruit juice-is provided, and from 40c to 50c for other meals. This is an increase of 22 per cent and 25 per cent respectively. At the end of June 1982, 738 organisations were receiving a Commonwealth subsidy for the provision of meals-on-wheels and some 9,650,000 meals were delivered in 1981-82. This compares with 8,947,000 meals delivered in 1980-81. Since the Commonwealth began providing subsidies for meals-on-wheels in 1970 it has spent nearly $23m on this important form of help for elderly people at home, and our increased assistance this year demonstrates the value we place on the effective operation of meals-on-wheels services.
SOCIAL SECURITY ACT 1947

The other main Budget initiatives requiring legislation all involve amendments to the Social Security Act 1947 and are dealt with by Part VI of this Bill. These amendments make a number of important adjustments to the system of social security pensions and benefits, and family allowances. They also introduce several significant new initiatives in the social security field. I propose to deal with these measures as they affect the major client groups of the Department of Social Security, rather than following the strict sequence of clauses in this part of the Bill.
INITIATIVES FOR THE UNEMPLOYED

The single rate of unemployment benefit for people aged 18 years and over who have no dependants will be increased by $6.30 a week, bringing that rate to $64. 40 a week-clause 77. This rate will be equal to half the married rate of unemployment benefit, taking into account the automatic CPI-linked increases that will come into effect in November, which will increase the standard rates of benefit to $77.25 for a single person over 18 years with dependants and $128. 80 for a married couple. The rate of benefit for single unemployed people and sickness beneficiaries aged 16 years and 17 years will also be increased by $4, giving them a total of $40 a week. The new rates will take effect from each individual's first pay-day in November 1982-clause 105.

At the same time, to encourage unemployed people to take advantage of opportunities to earn extra income and gain job experience by casual work, they will be allowed to earn more without losing their entitlement to benefit. The more generous income test that will apply from November 1982 is given effect by clause 83 of this Bill. It will mean that everyone who receives unemployment or sickness benefit will be able to have $10 a week of private income without affecting their rate of benefit at all. The amount currently allowed is $3 a week for single people under 18 years and $6 for everyone else. At the same time the partial taper introduced by the Government in 1980 will be extended so that beneficiaries who have more than $10 a week private income will retain 50c a week for every dollar of extra income up to an income limit of $60. The effect of this is that the maximum rate of benefit will be reduced by only half the amount of income the person has between $10 and $60. This will represent a substantial increase in the amount that can be earned before benefit is reduced by a full $1 for every $1 of income. At present the upper limit is only $40 for single people under 18 years and $50 for others.
Sitting suspended from 12.58 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I explained to the House that the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act to increase the rate of personal care subsidy for frail, aged people from $20 a week to $30 a week. It will amend the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act to increase the subsidy paid to meals-on-wheels services from 45c to 55c a meal with a vitamin C supplement and from 40c to 50c for other meals. It will also amend the Social Security Act to increase the single rate of unemployment benefit for people over 18 to an amount equal to half the married rate of unemployment benefit that will apply from November this year. It will increase the rate of benefit for single unemployed and sickness beneficiaries under 18 years of age by $4 a week. I also stated that a more generous income test designed to encourage unemployed people to take advantage of opportunities to earn extra income will apply from November 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: PENSIONERS

Most pensioners will benefit from the automatic CPI-linked increases in the rates of pension that will come into effect in November and will increase the single rate of pension by $3.10 to $77.25 a week and the married rate by $5.20 to $128.80 a week. In addition the Government has recognised that many pensioners who have a small amount of income apart from their pension have been hard hit by inflation, and that some adjustment in the amounts of private income pensioners can have without affecting their entitlement to a full pension should now be made. From November 1982, single pensioners will be able to have $30 a week of private income and couples $50 a week before their pension is affected. This change is embodied in clause 36 of the Bill for age and invalid pensions. It will also apply to widow pensioners and supporting parent beneficiaries. This is the first adjustment in these income limits for several years and will increase them from their current levels of $20 a week for single people and $34. 50 for couples.

The effect of these changes will be that some 430,700 pensioners with private incomes above the existing free areas will receive higher pensions. About 70 per cent of these will receive an increase of $5 a week if they are single or $7.75 a week for a married couple. Some 16,000 people who are not now entitled to a pension will become eligible for a small part pension of up to $5 a week. This initiative will result in an increase in the disposable incomes of these pensioners, who will be further assisted in this regard by the new pensioner tax rebate scheme which is being introduced to protect pensioners with a modest income from being taxed.

Clause 59 of the Bill increases the income limit for pensioner health benefits. These benefits are available to social security pensioners, including supporting parent beneficiaries, and to sickness beneficiaries, and repatriation service pensioners. We are proposing to increase the limits for these benefits, which were last adjusted in 1979, because we are concerned that a number of pensioners may have lost entitlement to fringe benefits because their private incomes have risen above the existing limits through no action of their own. We are also concerned that some pensioners may be placing themselves at a disadvantage by arranging their financial affairs so as to keep their incomes below the current limits to qualify for a card. The increase in the income limits should help people in both these categories, and should encourage pensioners to enjoy the full advantage of any private assets they may have.

People who qualify for pensioner health benefit cards are entitled to a range of Commonwealth concessions, the most important being free medical and hospital treatment, free pharmaceutical and telephone rental concessions. The income limits at which entitlement to pensioner health benefits ceases will rise from November 1982 to $54 a week for a single person and $90 a week for a married couple, compared with the current limits of $40 and $68. A new uniform limit of $20 for each dependent child in a family on top of the base limits is also to apply. The additional income limits for children currently vary between $11 and $17 a week. The effect of the changes will be that the new limit for a single person with one dependent child will be $74 a week, and for a couple with one child $110 a week. For each extra child the limit will rise uniformly by $20 a week.

Clause 59 also provides that the higher limits will apply to eligibility for pensioner funeral benefits. People who receive sheltered employment allowance have special income limits for pensioner fringe benefits. For a married couple with no children, this will be increased to $90 a week, the same as for other married pensioner couples. For single people receiving sheltered employment allowance, the limit will remain at its current level of $68 a week, still $14 higher than for other pensioners and beneficiaries. However, the increase to $20 a week in the additional limit for each child will apply to both these groups. In addition to these measures, the supplementary assistance or allowance payable to pensioners and beneficiaries who pay private rent is increased by clauses 39, 50 and 80 of the Bill. Supplementary assistance or allowance is available for pensioners, supporting parent beneficiaries, and long term sickness beneficiaries-that is, those of six or more weeks standing-who have little or no income apart from the pension or benefit and pay private rent or board and lodging. Last year the maximum rate or payment was increased by $5 to $8 a week. This year it will be further increased by $2 to $10 a week.

Clause 89 of the Bill increases the incentive allowance paid to recipients of sheltered employment allowance in lieu of supplementary assistance to the same level of $10 a week. For these people the allowance is free of any income test and does not take into account whether rent is paid or not. As I said at the beginning of this statement, pensioners who rent private housing are recognised by the Government as having a particular need for assistance-hence our further effort to help them in this year's Budget. This new increase will particularly benefit pensioners with less than $16 a week in private income who pay more than $26 a week in rent. Some State housing authorities also pay rental subsidies to private tenants. To recognise these State initiatives in the housing area and to ensure that private tenants receive the full benefit of them, clauses 29 and 74 of this Bill exempt such rent subsidies from counting as income for the pension and benefit income tests. This exemption will apply, to give one example, to people receiving rent relief subsidised under the Commonwealth's Mortgage and Rent Relief Scheme through State and Territory Governments.

A further small but important change is made by clause 47 of the Bill. From November 1982 women living overseas who qualify for a wife's pension may, when their husbands die, qualify for a widow's pension without having to return to Australia. The position of women in these circumstances has been of concern for some time and has been raised on a number of occasions by the Opposition spokesman on welfare matters, Senator Grimes. I am pleased that we have been able to take steps to resolve this problem in this Bill.
DISABLED PEOPLE

The Bill reflects the special needs of disabled people in several ways apart from the increases in general income limits for pensions and income limits for pensioner health benefits that I have already referred to. In particular it introduces a series of measures that will be of special assistance to disabled people who are in the work force or who want to work.

Clause 90 of the Bill adds a new Part to the Social Security Act 1947, establishing a 'mobility allowance' of $10 a week for severely handicapped people who are in employment or undertaking vocational training, and who are unable to use public transport because of their disability. This benefit, which will be available from April 1983, will cost an estimated $18m in a full year. It will be free of any income test or income tax. The benefit will not be available to those receiving the benefit of sales tax exemptions on new motor vehicles, or who receive the benefit of a car under the repatriation gift car scheme.

It has been designed specifically to recognise the additional travel costs incurred by disabled people who undertake employment or vocational training and the fact that such people are often unable to take advantage of the sales tax exemptions on new motor vehicles. The scheme also recognises that participation in the work force by such people is often precarious, by providing a three month period of grace during which they will continue to receive the allowance even though they have lost their employment or ceased training. The Government has decided to introduce such a scheme as quickly as possible to meet pressing needs in this area, but it will be kept under close review to make sure it is effective in its operation.

From 10 March 1983 a new form of income maintenance payment will be introduced for people who undertake a Commonwealth rehabiltation program and who otherwise would be eligible for another social security pension or benefit.

The new rehabilitation allowance established by clauses 97 and 98 of the Bill will be at the same rates as the person's social security pension or benefit, unless he is receiving a sickness, unemployment or special benefit which is less than the invalid pension rate. In that case, the person will be treated as an invalid pensioner in setting the rate of the rehabilitation allowance. The rehabilitation allowance will be provided under the same conditions as invalid pension-that is, income tested, but income tax free-and will attract the same fringe benefits. It may be paid during the rehabilitation program and for up to six months afterwards.

The current rehabilitation training allowance will be restructured to reflect this initiative, requiring consequential amendments to the Compensation ( Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and the Defence (Re-establishment) Act 1965. The training allowance will be paid as an additional benefit to people undertaking rehabilitation training who receive the rehabilitation allowance. It is expected that some 4,500 people out of the 6,000 accepted annually by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service will be eligible for rehabilitation allowance, which will involve a net cost of about $1m in a full year. It is obvious that single or young unemployment beneficiaries and young sickness beneficiaries undertaking rehabilitation programs will be particularly assisted by this benefit.

There are also a number of measures in the Bill designed to remove the anomalies previously existing in the treatment of handicapped people attending different categories of special therapy and training services. For example, the incentive allowance paid to people in sheltered employment, which I have already mentioned, will be increased from $8 to $10 from November and will also be extended, by clause 33, to invalid pensioners undertaking activity therapy and adult training programs in centres financed under the Handicapped Persons Welfare Program. This allowance will be paid under the same terms as to recipients of sheltered employment allowance. Further, to improve the incentives for invalid pensioners to participate in activity therapy and adult training centres, the higher income limit of $68 a week for fringe benefits that applies to single sheltered employment allowees will also apply, from November 1982, to single invalid pensioners participating in the programs of such centres-clause 60.
FAMILIES

I turn now to the very important measures contained in this Bill for the assistance of families. Our initiatives in this area have been designed bearing in mind the extra costs that all parents undertake in bringing up children and the particular difficulties faced in this area by families with low incomes. To help in meeting these extra costs, clause 65 of the Bill will increase the rate of family allowance by 50 per cent for the first and second children in a family from the endowment period commencing in October 1982. This will bring family allowance for the first child to $22.80 a month and for the second child to $32. 55 a month. The increase, which is one plank of the Government's general tax relief measures in the 1982-83 Budget, will cost some $375m in a full year and will consolidate the increases for third and subsequent children introduced in last year's Budget. While it will be of particular benefit to the 1.6 million families in Australia who have one or two children all 2.1 million families with children will gain.

In addition to this general assistance for families, the Bill will introduce, from 1 May 1983, a tax-free family income supplement for low income families, apart from pensioners and beneficiaries, of up to $10 a week for each dependent child who does not already attract an education allowance or similar payment. This not only reflects our recognition of the particular cost burden borne by low income families who are bringing up children but also helps to alleviate the unfair and clearly undesirable situation in which an unemployment beneficiary can be better off financially than a person in similar family circumstances who is in employment but earning low wages. Clause 62 of this Bill inserts a new Part V in the Social Security Act 1947 setting out the conditions under which this benefit will be payable.
Briefly, the main features are:

The scheme will be closely aligned with the disadvantaged persons health scheme for low income earners. The maximum rate of allowance of $10 per week for each eligible child is equal to the additional pension or benefit paid for the child of a pensioner or beneficiary. The allowance will be income tested on the joint income of parents and will be paid to the main breadwinner. People with an income less than the amount of the threshold will be eligible for the maximum rate of allowance for each child. The threshold is the amount of income which a married couple with no children may have before they cease to be eligible for a health care card. If the scheme were operating from November, the threshold would be $184 a week; but, because the threshold will increase as a result of consumer price index-linked increases in the benefit rate which affects the eligibility level for health care cards, it will be higher when the scheme comes into effect.

In determining eligibility, the maximum rate of assistance will be reduced by half of any income in excess of the threshold. To illustrate how benefit will be calculated, using the November threshold of $184, a family with three children and income of $200 per week would be eligible for a maximum payment of $30 less half the difference between its income, $200, and the threshold, $184. That family would therefore receive a payment of $22 a week. Entitlement will generally be determined for a six month period. Like the disadvantaged persons health scheme there will generally be no decrease in the rate of payment throughout that period if income during any four week period is less than 25 per cent higher than the income on which the original assessment is made. Entitlement will be redetermined at the end of the six month period on the basis of the basic threshold. Of course, a person may seek an increase at any time if his income falls.

The legislation allows a three month period of grace in which claims for the supplement can be made. Thus, if a person is initially unaware of the availability of the new benefit, he may get full payment from the date of its introduction provided that he claims by 1 August 1983. Because the family income supplement is a completely new benefit aimed at assisting low income families who are mainly in employment, the Government will monitor it closely to ensue that it meets its objective of relieving hardships among low income families who are not pensioners or beneficiaries. Families with a severely handicapped child who is cared for at home will also be assisted by an increase in handicapped child's allowance of $12 a month to $85 a month from November 1982-Clause 72.

Finally, we have taken the opportunity to remove two unintended anomalies in the treatment of sole parent pensioners and beneficiaries. Currently where a widow pensioner receives maintenance of more than $6 a week for a child the excess is treated as the pensioner's own income for income test purposes. While it is clear that the same principle should apply to supporting parent beneficiaries, there is doubt that the legislation as drafted achieves this intention. The amendment contained in Clause 54 of this Bill will clarify this situation and ensures that maintenance payments received by all sole parent pensioners and beneficiaries will be treated in a consistent manner. This provision will take effect from February 1983. The other anomaly relates to the payment of supporting parents benefit to some individuals who are themselves counted as dependants of another person for the purpose of the payment of a pension, benefit or allowance. From November 1982, it will no longer be possible for a supporting parent beneficiary to count as a dependant in this way-Clause 27. However, there is a savings provision which exempts existing recipients of pensions, benefits and allowances from the effect of this change.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this Bill provides for important new developments in our social security and welfare programs and gives help in direct and realistic ways to those groups in the community whom we recognise as being in particular need of assistance, including disabled people, aged people and families with low incomes. I commend the Bill to the House.
