DEBATE.TITLE: DOCUMENTS RELATING TO STRAW COMPANIES AND THE CRIMES (TAXATION OFFENCES) ACT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed from 22 September, on the following paper presented by Mr Howard :
Straw Companies and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980-Ministerial Statement, 22 September 1982.
and on motion by Sir James Killen:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'the Government no longer possesses the confidence of the House and the people of Australia because of its culpable negligence in failing to collect tax revenue, thereby increasing the burden on the community, and because of its failure to prosecute the persons it knew to be conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth'.

The motion will be seconded. We have only a very short time in which to debate this matter. It arises because the Senate by a resolution required the Government to table some 22 documents. The Government belatedly attempted to answer that request yesterday by tabling eight of those documents and a whole lot of other documents which do not appear to have any continuity of purpose. The documents are in a massive tome of 500 pages. They are in what is called chronological order. The only difficulty about this chronological approach, of course, is that there is nothing to show what happened in between the actions shown in each document in that tome. For example, we know nothing of the verbal replies by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). We know nothing of the conversations that took place between the Minister and his Department. We know nothing of what transpired between the Ministers when they were in Cabinet. In other words there is no memo, no letter or no communication from the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) as to what was proposed to deal with straw companies and the massive evasion of tax.

There could be no more important matter in Australia at present than the failure of a government to carry out its responsibilities. In accordance with good administration, Ministers are supposed to be able to understand what their departments are doing. Certainly the Treasurer should be able to guarantee that all tax due and payable is duly collected. The Prime Minister has a responsibility to guarantee that the Cabinet functions efficiently and effectively. When there is crime, when there is fraud, the Government should certainly apply the law.

In the few moments available to me, let me make this point: A few of the documents certainly indicated again the complete disarray of this Government as shown in its inability to understand its obligations in terms of implementing the law. There has been massive tax evasion. The Government knew of it. As the Government had cognisance of that and did nothing about it, it must have had some close association with the people who got the benefit. That is the great indictment from what has happened. We are dealing, in my view, with billions of dollars. There has been a massive increase in indirect taxation to make up for the amount that has not been collected in company taxation. I made the point the other day, in another debate, that from the fuel tax alone-that is an indirect tax-the amount collected was $13.3 billion. In my view there was no need for that when one looks at the evidence before us here today. The incredible aspect about these matters is that they have come to our notice not because the Government has introduced any legislation to protect itself or made any explanation to protect itself but because of other avenues of information.

Let me deal with the information in chronological order. Not the least of the information was contained in the McCabe-Lafranchi report, made under the provisions of the Companies Act, which was presented to the Victorian Parliament this year. If honourable members look at the volume of documents in front of them, they will see that there is a reference to the fact that the Victorians are going to do something about the matter. Why, in the name of fortune, would the Commonwealth Government have to leave it to a State government to do something about the matter? We can look at what McCabe and Lafranchi were able to say under the terms of their investigation. They say that, way back in the 1970s, a person known as Brian Maher established what is called a corporate consultancy and a dealership.

The Treasurer has come in here time and time again and said: 'I have a splendid record. I have passed a number of pieces of legislation that have prevented all this'. That is utter rubbish. What is the good of passing a log of legislation and not dealing with this matter of straw companies? The Treasurer, in an answer to a question today, got half smart because he is a lawyer and said that the questioner did not know what he was talking about when he talked about company stripping. The real issue would have been the matter of straw companies. That would have been the issue because it was mentioned in the same memo of the Commissioner of Taxation. I will quote it to honourable members later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—I ask the honourable member to remain quiet for a change. The Government introduced amending legislation in 1978. What did McCabe and Lafranchi have to say about that? They said that that had no effect of curbing the sale of companies as a means of tax avoidance. In 1978 that was no new matter; it was an old matter. As the McCabe-Lafranchi report indicates, what was the point in passing all this legislation, including the tax avoidance legislation of 1980, if nothing was ever done about the crime?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the notice that the Government had of this matter and why all members of the Government must bear some responsibility. I will quickly come to the point. I acknowledge that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) raised the matter in 1977, and in doing so he was really referring to straw companies as well. He wanted something to be done. It is an indictment of the Prime Minister that since 1977 nothing has been effected. Why was there not a prosecution? That is the issue. Is it because Maher is protected? Is it because Maher still has not been investigated? Is it because Maher says to the tax investigators who go to see him: 'Why should I talk to you when I pay $50,000 a year to the Liberal Party?' Is that a criterion? I suggest that it should not be, but it shows up in the few papers which have been tabled.

I have before me a note from the Taxation Commissioner in February 1978 which talks about emerging practices whereby a company that has a tax liability is stripped of its funds so it is not in a position to meet its tax liability. The Government knew of that. When the Treasurer answered the question today he was not prepared to admit that the emergence of straw companies was really the issue in the questioner's mind. The Government had all this information about activities in the early 1970s. It is in the McCabe-Lafranchi report. The Government knew that the Taxation Office in Perth was not even prepared to give to the McCabe-Lafranchi inquiry Maher's letter in which he concocted the conspiracy. The guilt of the Taxation Office is enormous from the point of its failure to give the investigators the letter which clearly would have been exhibit one in any conspiracy trial.
Let us look at what happened after that. I pick the issue that quickly comes to mind. We have an array of dossiers from the Taxation Office. One note from the Taxation Commissioner states:

I also mention we are becoming increasingly concerned about practices whereby companies that have a tax liability are stripped of assets so there is nothing left to meet tax assessments. There is no readily apparent solution to this problem.

This is very surprising. One of the documents that the Senate asked to be tabled was the opinion of Brinsden, Q.C. We are not going to have that document tabled. The Government is not game to give it to us because the opinion was given to the Government in 1975-three years before-that it could certainly have launched prosecutions. Mr O'Reilly said that he was getting very worried, that the Government had to do something about penalties and that he thought the Government should talk about a minimum penalty or even gaol sentence. He also said:

In making this suggestion I mention that my officers have been pressing the Crown Solicitor to investigate whether prosecution action could be taken under the Crimes Act or the Companies Act against people involved in two cases of ' straw company' evasion.

The Treasurer is a lawyer. These matters were before the Cabinet and there are a number of lawyers in it. Certainly they would have had a chance to get some advice from the Solicitor-General. They never went to the Solicitor-General at any stage before this year. It was useless going to the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack), who made the stupid remark the he did not know that there was anything wrong and that he would not expect to do anything until he was told that something was wrong. Some officers of the Taxation Office knew that there was a lot wrong; the Crown Solicitor knew that there was a lot wrong; the Attorney-General said that he did not know; and the Solicitor-General was not asked.

I refer now to Cabinet submission No. 2290 of 6 June 1978. It was on the basis of that submission that there was going to be something done about these companies that stripped their assets. Why is it that this Government was not able to do anything until 1980 at the earliest when it had Cabinet submission No . 2290 of 6 June 1978 stating that something should be done? That is an indictment of the Government. We have been denied access to all the information. I refer now to a letter written on 7 November 1978 by Mr O'Reilly to his Treasurer asking him why there was a delay as the matter had been before Cabinet . He said that they were not getting anywhere, that there was no legislation. He said that he was concerned as millions of dollars in tax were being missed and suggested that something be done about it. He said that the draft had been in existence for a long time. We also have before us a note written by the worthy Treasurer, I assume, saying: 'I still have reservations. I can see problems. Can we get the Solicitor-General's advice?' It is a note on the bottom of a letter. I do not know whether it is the Treasurer's.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is.

—The Treasurer did not get the Solicitor-General's advice because if he had he would have launched a prosecution. The Treasurer is a lawyer and knows what constitutes crime. How can he excuse himself for so many years? How can the Cabinet excuse itself? Perhaps the Treasurer was doing his best but was overcome by the other heavyweights in the Cabinet. That was made very clear the other day by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony), who said that we really ought to be able to forgive the Treasurer now and again, saying that the Treasurer, against enormous difficulties, with pressure from vested interests, with pressure from within his own party and elsewhere, has seen his goal and gone straight for it. The Treasurer went for it via the Cape of Good Hope. He had no intention of getting to this issue. This is an indictment of this Government. I have not got time to deal with all of the issues; but one of the tabled papers, in referring to revenue implications, states how one promoter is known to have stripped over 1,150 companies in Victoria. These companies had tax liabilities in the year prior to the strip totalling $14m. The real indictment of the Treasurer is that he had the opinion of Mr Webb, Q.C., in 1978 but he denies that. Today in answer to a question he said that he knew nothing of it. In 1979 this Treasurer appointed Mr Webb to his Taxation Advisory Committee. Does he mean to say that he knew nothing about Mr Webb's opinion in 1978? Where did that come from? That opinion talks about proposed legislation. Mr Webb Q.C. is properly saying: 'Indict these people as criminals under the Crimes Act and you will get a conviction'. It was never done. We are looking at people in government who deliberately prevented the revenue being collected, who have shielded these corporate crooks for reasons we cannot understand-except for their party affiliations-and who have guaranteed that the rest of the Australian community has had to bear enormous increases in tax. They do not deserve to remain in government.
—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the very outset on behalf of the Government I completely reject this censure motion moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen). Perhaps the greatest fallacy of his argument was demonstrated in the closing moments of his remarks when he said that just because I appointed a very reputable and worthy Melbourne Queen's Counsel by the name of Mr Arthur Webb to the Taxation Advisory Committee, it followed automatically that every legal opinion that Mr Webb had ever given should have been disclosed to me. Does the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, himself a lawyer , know so little about his profession that he does not realise it would be a gross breach of professional ethics on the part of Mr Webb to have done that?

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the main thrust of the charge made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition against me and against the Government today. I take the opportunity of saying a few things about my stewardship of the Government's campaign against tax avoidance over the last four or five years. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has sought to denigrate the fact that the Government took two and a half years to get the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act developed. Does he not realise that that legislation was radically different from any legislation we had previously had in our tax law? Did he not realise that for the first time we were introducing major criminal penalties into our tax law? Does he really dismiss so lightly the concerns that we entertained about matters such as onus of proof? Had he been in my position, would he have blithely said: 'Yes, reverse the onus of proof; force the accused person to demonstrate against a criminal charge that that person is not guilty'? Are those the sorts of things that any responsible Treasurer in any government or any responsible Minister in any government should, in fact, ignore?

Even his colleague the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Evans, who has been leading the campaign on this issue, said, when this legislation was introduced into the Senate, that he welcomed it. But he said that it was unprecedented legislation to deal with an unprecedented problem and he believed it would be unprecedentedly successful. He said it was harsh legislation. He said that it was rough legislation. Even my colleague the honourable member for Gellibrand ( Mr Willis) during the second reading debate on the legislation in this place sought an assurance from me that innocent people would not be subject to criminal penalties. I remind the honourable gentleman and the House that even in December 1980-after this legislation had been subjected to very careful scrutiny -strong representations were made against it by responsible bodies in the community. Will Opposition members brand all of those bodies as allies of the tax evasion industry? Will they brand all of them as irresponsible and as crooks ? Will they say that the Law Council of Australia, which has as its vice- president at the present time a reputable member of the Australian Labor Party, was an ally of the tax avoidance industry? On 4 December that body in a telex to me said:

The Law Council of Australia wishes to express very grave concern at the implications of the above Bill . . . There is grave concern at the introduction of legislation which potentially has a much wider operation than the prevention of the practices outlined by the Treasurer in his second reading speech.

That was on 4 December 1980 after a process of consideration and distillation through the Government-the delay and the humbug that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would criticise-yet the Law Council of Australia was moved to say that the Bill was being introduced in haste and would have potentially wider consequences. The Law Society of Tasmania said:
We protest strongly against the Crimes Taxation Offences Bill which threatens criminal proceedings against professional advisors . . . We request that you delay the passage of this Bill . . .
The Law Society of New South Wales said:

The Society is deeply concerned at the haste with which a Bill of such wide reach is being introduced. The Bill as proposed goes beyond the defects sought to be remedied and may place in jeopardy the persons conducting genuine business transactions.

So even in December 1980 very responsible, unimpeachable bodies representing responsible opinion in this country were expressing concern about the legislation. That is a point of view that the honourable gentleman completely ignored in his remarks. Throughout the whole time that I handled the processing of this Bill the matter was handled in accordance with proper procedure; it was properly handled by me. The matter was referred to the Taxation Advisory Committee, a body which was established by the Government in December 1979 representing private legal and accounting practitioners. The establishment of that Committee had been warmly supported not only in the professions and throughout the Government, but also by the Opposition. The honourable member for Gellibrand on 4 April 1979 said this:

The measures proposed by the Treasurer in respect of setting up an advisory committee meet with our approval. It is true that the establishment of such a committee was recommended by the Asprey Taxation Review Committee . . . the establishment of an advisory committee-
I ask honourable members to listen to this:
to assist the Treasurer in providing tax avoidance legislation which does not disrupt commercial transactions any more than is absolutely necessary is a sensible policy and we support it.

They are not my words. That is the honourable member for Gellibrand, Ralph Willis, the Opposition shadow Treasurer, saying that it is a good idea to have a Taxation Advisory Committee. We established that Committee in December 1979. Its main function was to vet upcoming taxation legislation to see that it did not have unintended consequences. It is therefore only natural, in accordance with the bipartisan approach to the Committee, that we should refer this legislation to the Committee early in 1980. As a consequence of referring this legislation to that Committee it entertained major reservations about it. It indicated that there was concern that there would be normal commercial transactions. Amongst other things, it expressed concern that innocent third parties would need to be protected, that there was a risk that the innocent might be convicted and that the onus of proof was being put upon the accused to an excessive extent.

Of course, two years later with all our combined and unilateral outrage it is easy to dismiss things like onus of proof and the rights of the accused and to say that those things are of no account. Yet they were of great account then and it will be a shameful day for Australian government if the onus of proof and criminal liability are thrust aside in the way in which the Opposition suggests that they should have been. I believe that it would be a very shameful day for this country if in fact that were to occur. I believe that if one examines the record, if one takes into account the nature of the legislation and if one looks at the matter objectively it can only fairly be concluded that the period involved was not one for which I or the Government can be indicted in the terms moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

This matter goes beyond the circumstances of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act . This whole debate invites us to try to put the tax avoidance issue back into perspective. One would imagine from what has been said by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that tax avoidance was discovered by McCabe and Lafranchi. One would imagine that the only tax avoidance scheme that I have had to grapple with , or that any taxation officer has had to grapple with, was the bottom-of-the- harbour tax avoidance scheme. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and no doubt other Opposition speakers will have some pleasure in reading from some of the documents that were tabled yesterday. Let me take them to a minute from the Commissioner of Taxation to me of October 1980 when the legislation was about to be introduced. Even in October 1980 the priorities of the Commissioner of Taxation placed work on a new section 260 ahead of work on straw companies and trusts. Even in October 1980 the Commissioner of Taxation was saying to me that getting a new section 260 was the most effective anti-avoidance measure that the Government could be taking-which, of course, was true. In a minute to me of 22 October 1980 he described work on the new section 260 as being 'the central anti -avoidance project'. That was in October 1980. Mr O'Reilly wrote to me saying that even then the central anti-avoidance project was the work on section 260. Those who might seek to use other words of the Commissioner from amongst the documents I tabled yesterday should ponder the significance of that statement contained in the Commissioner's minute to me of 22 October.

Perhaps one of the most shameful things about this debate is the way in which the Leader of the Opposition has sought to convey the impression that $10,000m to $15,000m has been lost through the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. I put the Leader of the Opposition and any honourable member opposite to the proof of that proposition. The latest estimates of the Commissioner of Taxation concerning these schemes are of the order of $400m to $500m. It is a very large sum of money. It will be the subject of the recovery legislation that will be introduced. Even in late 1979 the best and most finite revenue estimate that the Commissioner of Taxation could give me in respect of these schemes involved a figure of $40m to $50m.

I say to the House that I believe that the introduction of the new Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the new general anti-avoidance provision which replaces the emasculated section 260, is far and away the most important legislative achievement of this Government in the tax avoidance area. If the Opposition does not accept my remarks on that, let it look at its own policy statement of 1980 issued by Senator Evans and the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) in which they said that one of the most important things that could be done would be the writing of a general anti-avoidance section. That was successfully achieved in May 1981 and it represents, in my view, the Government's most successful legislative exercise in the anti-avoidance area during the whole time it has been in office. I can remember saying on an earlier occasion that attitudes towards tax avoidance have changed over time. One has to go back, as I did this morning, to 1978 when the Leader of the Opposition was having his doubts as to whether to support our amending legislation striking down the Curran schemes. Unless he was misquoted on four occasions by the Press of this country, at that time he had his reservations. If one goes back through the newspaper columns of the time, if one looks at the shift in editorial opinion, one finds that there has been a change of attitude. In August 1981 the Sydney Morning Herald stated:
It has only been in relatively recent times that public opinion has hardened against tax avoidance.
It stated further that some regard could be paid to the role of the Treasurer:
. . . who played a leading role in persuading the public that tax avoidance was not something worthy of grudging admiration.

That particular remark was not a Liberal Party public relations handout. That newspaper in 1978, when I introduced the Curran amendments, criticised the Government very trenchantly regarding the application or starting date of those Curran amendments. It was a good example of the way in which public opinion had changed over time. I believe that this Government has played a major role in bringing about a change of public opinion on tax avoidance and tax evasion matters.

Looking forward on this subject, I think that there are a number of things that all of us can learn from this debate about tax avoidance. I think that the first thing that we can learn is that whatever the strict letter of the law may be, a number of people in our community have gone into tax avoidance arrangements out of greed and out of the desire to increase very large incomes. Secondly, the excessively literalist approach of the High Court of Australia during the 1970s contributed to the growth of tax avoidance. I believe the complicated nature of the Income Tax Assessment Act, with a plethora of concessions, has also played a significant role. I also believe that the commercially unreal approach of the Labor Party to many normal family and commercial arrangements has fostered a hostility to those arrangements which is not justified by the circumstances. The final lie that I wish to nail completely is the proposition that in some way the Liberal Party is the supporter or the friend of the tax avoidance industry. Never in the whole time that I have been Treasurer in this country has any legislation in this area been held up. Never has action not been taken by me because of a concern about the impact of that legislation on members of my party . I nail that for the complete and utter distortion of the truth that it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to observe the different reactions of Ministers in this Government when they are in trouble. Minister Sinclair said that it was not him, Minister Nixon said that it was all lies, Minister Newman said that he did not hear anyway and Minister Howard says that he is sorry. Well, just being sorry will not wash. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) could possibly sustain a defence only if we accept that he was entitled to disregard the continual and increasingly urgent advice of the Commissioner of Taxation and if we accept that there was absolutely nothing else he could do except to proceed along this tortured path of trying to find criminal penalties to knock out the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. I do not accept that either of those two propositions are true.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first instance we know that at least as early as the middle of 1977 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the then Treasurer were aware of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes or at least their predecessors. In February 1978 the Treasurer was advised by the Commissioner of Taxation of the emergence of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and the serious threat that existed. Indeed, he was given a remedy for dealing with them-a remedy on which we have had to wait four and a half years for the Government to legislate. Still it has not brought in the Bill. I refer to the remedy of making directors and shareholders liable for the unpaid tax. In May 1978 the Commissioner of Taxation told the Treasurer of widespread tax evasion and the need for severe legislation. He was told that prosecutions could have been launched and may have succeeded under the existing law. In June 1978 he said that the 'matter is even more serious'. He said that there were criminal activities involving 900 companies in Victoria.

In July 1978 he said that it was even more extensive than he was previously aware. Later in July he said that 130 companies had been dropped down the drain in two weeks. He said that there was therefore a most pressing need for action. It was only at this point that the Government-reluctantly-was prodded into any action at all. The matter was shoved off to a couple of departments for their consideration. In December 1978 the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, was asked for his view. In February 1979 an increasingly frustrated Commissioner of Taxation said that these schemes 'continue to flourish'. He said: 'The matter is taking on more urgency'. He reported that one tax dodger's newsletter had now described the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme as the ultimate tax avoidance scheme. In February 1979 even Wal Fife, the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, was gripped with the urgency of taking some action. God knows, if Wal Fife is gripped with anything it must be serious indeed! By July 1979-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Sir James Killen

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable gentleman is under the clearest of obligations to address the Minister in a proper fashion . He has, throughout his speech-

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very proper point of order.
—The honourable member for Fremantle should use the correct titles.

—I will, Mr Speaker. By July 1979, that is a year after the matter was first taken to Cabinet, even the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, had accepted the need for action. But by November 1979 nothing had happened, and the poor old Commissioner of Taxation, who by then was nearly berserk with frustration, had to write to the Treasurer saying:

SPEECH.PARA: These activities are criminal in nature and fraudulent . . .
He wrote:
This activity is occurring on a large scale, daily . . . I am having to write off large amounts of assessed income tax because companies have been stripped of assets.
He mentioned that over 1,150 companies in Victoria with tax liabilities of $14m were being stripped. Mostly importantly, in the ultimate paragraph of his letter , he stated:
Unless something effective is done along the lines proposed, we may almost as well not bother with anti-avoidance legislation. I say that advisedly.

That was in November of 1979. What could the Treasurer have done when faced with the urgency-the accepted urgency-of the Prime Minister in 1977 and his own accepted urgency at various times through this matter? In the first instance the Treasurer could have launched proceedings under the existing law. The Commissioner of Taxation, in May 1978, had said that prosecutions under the existing law may be possible. Surely it was worth a try. Even if they had not succeeded, at least these tax dodgers would have been on notice that the matter was to be taken before the courts and they would have thought twice about entering into these schemes at that time.

The next thing that the Treasurer could have done was to announce his revulsion about these schemes and his intention to legislate to wipe them out. The Treasurer said that he could not do that; he could not put the tax dodgers on notice that he was going to change the criminal law because he could not then back-date that criminal law. He said that if they were given that notice it would be an invitation to get up to their necks in these sorts of schemes in advance of the date of assent of that sort of criminal law. That is what he said -or that is what the Commissioner of Taxation says he said. The point is that he could have announced it because, in any event, things could not possibly have got any worse; people were getting into these schemes at an accelerating pace. Even if the Treasurer had put them on notice it is unimaginable that they could have got into these schemes any more rapidly than they already were.

But the most effective action that the Minister could have taken, and refused for years to take, was to announce that he intended to recoup the money that was being defrauded under this scheme. That was retrospectivity which the Government had already embraced; it was retrospectivity on which it could have embarked. That would have put all these tax dodgers on notice that, even if they were not guilty of criminal offences, they certainly would not have been able to hang on to the tax they obtained in this fraudulent manner. That is what the Commissioner of Taxation meant when he said that unless the Government was prepared to act on this matter it might as well give up the fight against tax avoidance. It is a necessary ingredient of the government's strategy of knocking out tax avoidance schemes case by case that it acts early and puts people on notice by announcing that it will act against these schemes. If the Government does not act early, by the time it makes the announcement it will be too late. That is exactly what the Commissioner of Taxation meant when he said: 'Unless you act against the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes you can tear up all your intentions about stopping tax avoidance anywhere'. These three clear possible actions existed for the Treasurer to take, but what was the Government doing during all this sorry, tragic time? It is significant that the first time this matter was taken before the Cabinet, the Cabinet was meeting in Perth. I dare say it took a few submissions from Horgan, Mitchell and Corser to see what their views were about how to wipe out tax avoidance. In any event whether it took those submissions or not, it is no wonder that, having met in Perth, the Cabinet members decided to defer any consideration of this matter. I wonder, by the way, what the Cabinet got up to in terms of its entertainment that night. Maybe the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) had one of his officers arrange for the Cabinet to tour some of the red light districts of Perth.

But the urgency of which the Prime Minister says he was possessed was certainly not evident during any of this time. The urgency of which the Commissioner of Taxation was possessed was certainly not mirrored in any of the action which was taken by the Government. For 18 months the matter was pushed from Minister to Minister and from department to department. The Treasurer said he had to deal with difficult questions such as that of the onus of proof. I remind the Treasurer that he settled the question of the onus of proof in July 1979. That ceased to be a reason for delay, a contentious matter or an unresolved issue, and yet another 18 months passed before the legislation finally hit the deck.

The legislation ran into its first obstacle when it went to the back bench committee. We can see the members of that committee squirming around the place now displaying their abhorrence for tax dodging, but at that time many of them thought-indeed many of them still do-that it was just terrific and that governments should not take action to clamp down on the illegal activities of their financial backers in the business community. The back benchers' committee brought this matter to a screaming halt. So the Treasurer then had to dream up some new elaborate delaying device. That is when he thought of the Taxation Advisory Committee. He did not have one at that time so he had to set one up. It is true that we welcomed the establishment of that Committee but we now know the qualifications which the Treasurer was looking for when he decided to choose people who could advise him on these important matters. Just the other day he said:
I would have thought that the authority of people to speak on this subject--
he was talking about tax avoidance-
had something to do with their practical knowledge and understanding of what has gone on in the tax avoidance industry.

From that we are to assume that the people chosen for the Tax Advisory Committee were those who could give him expert advice based on their personal and practical knowledge of what was going on in the tax avoidance industry. Perhaps the sort of people that the Treasurer appointed were those on which the Prime Minister decided. He said:

. . . I think those high priced lawyers and accountants who have devised and promoted tax avoidance schemes do more damage to the basis of this society than a thousand Gallaghers in this world, or a thousand Builders' Labourers Federations--

Are they the sort of people whom the Government appoints to provide it with expert advice? In any event, it is interesting to note that the postal address for the Taxation Advisory Committee is care of Price Waterhouse & Co. That may well be a branch office of some or the other tax avoidance empire. Indeed, Mr Webb's involvement with this Committee is important because the Treasurer said today that Mr Webb was providing advice to tax dodgers. In fact he was telling those tax dodgers that it might be possible for them to be prosecuted under existing law. It is intriguing indeed why Mr Webb did not convey that important piece of information to the Treasurer after his appointment to this exalted position.

By now there had been years of delay. Behind the tortured facade of concern by the Treasurer we find sophisticated procrastination. He had been told time and again that his weaponry against tax dodging was fatally restricted, and yet all this abbreviated warrior could do was shuffle paper and dream up new reasons for delay. It is only now that we discover the reason for the Treasurer moving his Parliament House office so close to the Parliament House post office. I thought it was for the view, but I now realise that his staff were getting hernias dragging all the fruitless correspondence to the letter box. He did everything except the one thing which was really necessary, and that was to bring legislation into this place. Meanwhile, bottom-of-the-harbour schemes flourished . The Treasurer was to tax avoidance as Nero was to pyromania; he was standing back and gleefully observing what was happening.

I will not say that the Treasurer alone was to blame; we are censuring the whole Government. Durack, the Attorney-General, also is admittedly involved in this. He administered a department which failed to prosecute clear cases way back in 1976 and since. When the Cabinet submission got to him for consideration he managed to bail it up for eight expensive months. Then of course there is Minister Fife. He was, I must confess, convinced about the urgency of the matter , but what did he do about it? Dear old W. C. Fife, with those exquisitely expressive initials in his name, had become known as the Minister for misfortune . He is the Minister who had to defend Harvey Bates and the Narcotics Bureau about two weeks before the Bureau was wound up because of its total incompetence . Last year he went around Australia as Minister for Education like some maniacal iconoclast opening buildings so that he could then close the institutions who owned these buildings. Now he is Minister for Aviation and it is no wonder that Australians are losing their enthusiasm for air transport. He is the Minister for misfortune and disasters. All that the Attorney-General could do during this whole period when he was centrally involved in the delay was to blame the Commissioner of Taxation. If these documents prove one thing, it is that the Commissioner of Taxation was the only person in the Government who not only was possessed with the importance of taking action but also was proposing realistic action time and time again. The great pity was that the Attorney-General and his Department were doing nothing about it and the Ministers in the Cabinet who represented those departments were doing nothing as well.

During this whole period of hiatus, during this important few years when the Government was doing nothing, pondering the various difficulties of the legislation that it finally brought into this House in 1980, the number of companies involved in this scheme was escalating enormously. The number grew from 500 in 1977 to 1,412 by 1980. Had the Minister acted in any of the three ways which I have proposed, very few, if any, of those companies would have gone to the bottom of the harbour and the hundreds of millions of dollars of tax might have been claimed by the Treasury to which it rightly belongs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding the speech made by the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), the Opposition presents this censure motion moved in the form of an amendment by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) as a serious motion involving grave allegations which require a critical and an analytical response. After carefully examining all the documents tabled in this House yesterday evening by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and after listening to the arguments advanced to date in this debate by the Opposition, I have to say that the motion stands condemned for intellectual dishonesty as does the Opposition for bringing into this Parliament a motion which has no substance to back it and no merit whatsoever, legal or moral, upon which any fair minded and right thinking person could make a finding of guilt either against the Treasurer of against this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Paradoxically, this motion has been brought into this House and, although it does not name him, it is specifically directed against the present Treasurer who has demonstrably done more to tackle the cancer of tax evasion and malpractice than any other Treasurer since Federation. The censure motion is intellectually dishonest and, therefore, unjust. It is based on innuendo, exaggeration and smear. The motion is gravely unjust in that it is non-specific. It imputes by innuendo culpable negligence, yet it does not dare to provide the particulars. It breaches a fundamental rule of law that a man who is charged is entitled to know precisely the details of the charge he has to answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, we are not in a court of law and well you know it.

—Not only does it violate that presumption but also does it clearly violate the presumption of innocence. I say, for the benefit of the honourable member for Fremantle who has just interjected, that these are not mere legal technicalities; they are fundamental and basic principles of the rule of law in a parliamentary democracy. The Treasurer of this country, no less than the most lowly citizen of this nation facing the most trivial charge, is entitled to be accorded the ordinary principles of natural justice encapsulated in the time honoured Australian colloquialism 'a fair go'.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not live in the Soviet Union. This is Australia. It is not Russia. The Australian Labor Party does this Parliament a great disservice and it does this Treasurer a grave injustice in today pursuing the tactics which, to its discredit, it has resorted to over and over again during the past few weeks. The people of Australia who are the ultimate jury in this matter will deal harshly with those who falsely allege and maliciously pursue such a flimsy case so lacking in substance and merit.

What are the charges against the Government and the Treasurer? Last night, outside this House, we heard the incredible allegation of a 'cover up'. The truth, as I will prove, is the absolute reverse. Rather than cover up, this Government has displayed more openness and frank disclosure than any government since Federation, not just over the past few weeks but over the past 7 1/2 years . By legislative reform, this Government has enabled the citizens of Australia to gain more access to the workings of government than ever before. We are an open government and we are seen to be so by the overwhelming majority of Australians.

Yesterday's tabling of documents by the Treasurer in this Parliament represents an historic first. Without being forced by any law presently existing or about to come into force-namely, the freedom of information legislation-this Government and this Treasurer have tabled in this Parliament every single document requested in Senator Evans's motion save only those in respect of which the second law officer of the Commonwealth, the Solicitor-General, has certified that it would be contrary to the public interest and specifically the administration of justice. Does not the Opposition have even the slightest understanding of these words, in particular the words 'the administration of justice'? Where is the cover up? Over 80 documents extending back over five years and contained in a book the size of a major city telephone directory of 443 pages do not look like a cover up to me. Indeed, it is a very antithesis of a cover up.

The Opposition's false allegation of a cover up can only relate to the documents which have not been tabled and, in so doing, the Opposition impugns the integrity of the Commonwealth Solicitor-General, Sir Maurice Byers, Q.C., appointed by the Whitlam Government, a distinguished lawyer who has enjoyed the unqualified confidence and support of governments of all political persuasions, a statutory office holder and a man against whom not one word of personal criticism has been uttered in this Parliament since the day he took office.

The Opposition's tactics are disgraceful and shameful and will be seen to be so . By innuendo and implication, not by a direct and specific charge, the Opposition is effectively challenging the Solicitor-General's advice, his considered opinion, his certificate and his integrity. In public presentation, the Opposition attacks this Government but, in truth, its baseless allegations on the question of a cover up constitute a sordid attack on Sir Maurice Byers. If the Opposition is not attacking the Solicitor-General, on what basis does it allege that there has been a cover up?

This Government and this Treasurer have produced in this Parliament everything that it is proper to produce on the best legal advice in the land without seriously endangering the administration of justice and without prejudicing proceedings-both criminal and civil-which are in train. So much for the baseless allegation of cover up, unless the Opposition is now prepared to reveal itself in its true colours and publicly to challenge the clear and explicit advice of the Solicitor-General. In any event, how anybody could allege a cover up in the face of over 80 documents tabled-over 40 of them being communications between the Commissioner of Taxation and the Treasurer-is absolutely beyond me. The Treasurer has provided in this Parliament just about everything except the private telephone numbers of members of his staff. Yet the Opposition has the audacity to allege within this Parliament and outside that the Treasurer is guilty of a cover up. If truth and credibility were measured in snow flakes, the Labor Party would just about dead heat with the Simpson Desert.

I turn now to the charge of delay-a false, untrue and unjust charge against an honourable Treasurer of this country. In a very detailed analysis, my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), who will follow me in this debate will outline in detail the chronology of this matter and prove beyond all reasonable doubt that if there was a delay-which is denied-it certainly was not at the instance of, nor in any way caused or contributed to, by the actions of the Treasurer. On this matter the people of Australia should know that a careful analysis proves beyond any doubt that the Treasurer's hands are clean. In many cases he acted within hours, as the record shows. I instance some specific examples: Firstly, on 2 June 1978, the Treasurer received a very detailed draft Cabinet submission. Within 96 hours, that Cabinet submission was settled and it was lodged. Was this delay? Was this procrastination? Did this prove culpability ? Secondly, on 20 December 1978, just five days before Christmas, with all that that entails in terms of pressure and activity, the Treasurer saw, settled and despatched a very detailed letter which has been tabled to the Attorney-General within four hours. Does this prove procrastination? Does this prove delay? Does this prove culpability? Thirdly, on 31 July-within a mere 12 hours-the Treasurer approved a detailed revised draft of a very detailed Cabinet submission on the very complex reverse onus provision and lodged it with the Cabinet office on that very same day. I ask the Parliament and the people of Australia: Was this delay? Was this procrastination? Does this prove culpability? The Opposition's case against the Treasurer on the ground of delay is in tatters and the Opposition knows it.

I turn now to the Opposition's grave allegations that billions of dollars have been permanently lost to the revenue and that the people of Australia have, as the Opposition says, been ripped-off to the tune of up to $15 billion. These allegations, unsubstantiated as they are, constitute a deliberate and concerted attempt at massive public deception by the Australian Labor Party. The documents tabled do not talk in terms of billions of dollars or in terms of hundreds of millions of dollars. The documents talk of figures such as $1m, $6m and $23m. Where is the proof of billions of dollars being lost? Where is the evidence to support these highly exaggerated claims brought into this Parliament by members of the Australian Labor Party without one iota of evidence to back them up? As my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) so clearly pointed out in this House last week, on the Labor Party's figures the amount of revenue allegedly lost is greater by far than the highest amount of revenue which could have been collected, if everybody had paid, on the assessment of the man best qualified to indicate that figure-that is, the Commissioner of Taxation.

In other words, the Opposition's allegations of evasion exceed the maximum amount that could be payable in a Utopian situation in which everybody pays 100 per cent. Again the Opposition has come into this Parliament and made false and unsubstantiated allegations against the Treasurer of this nation. I think the people of Australia outside this Parliament are getting a bit sick and tired of this. People in the wider community who make false allegations are liable to sanctions under the processes of the law, whether they be criminal or civil proceedings. The Opposition, by bringing into this Parliament wild and exaggerated allegations, unsubstantiated by any evidence whatsoever, demeans itself and this institution. The Opposition will deservedly earn the contempt of the overwhelming majority of Australians for its concerted efforts in recent weeks to smear and denigrate, to slander and defame, to indulge in character assassination on an unprecedented level and to substitute, for the most precious principle of law and justice, suspicion for proof.

The Opposition earns no credit by acting, as the Treasurer so correctly said, in apparent total ignorance of the basic and fundamental principles of the law. The Opposition throws aside suggestions about the question of reversal of the onus of proof and says that it is nothing but a mere trifle. It would act like a totalitarian regime which the state is pre-eminent and the individual's rights are totally subservient. I put it to the House that there is more of Moscow than there is of Westminster in the speeches of members of the Opposition. This motion is comtemptible and shameful and will be rejected by this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion. This debate, reduced to its essentials, is simply this: Are the laws by which there is an obligation on the community to pay tax fair, equitable and just? The answer is no. Equally, are those laws effective, efficient and enforceable? Again, the answer is no. Let me quote what my colleague the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) said the other night in the House when dealing with the prosecution aspect of the Government's record. My colleague said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . On 16 September the Treasurer stated:
Until such time as a court of this country demonstrates that a person involved in that-
I assume that the Treasurer was referring to the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes-

could have been effectively prosecuted under the previous law, the opinions given by the Solicitor-General, whom I respect enormously as a lawyer, and the opinion given by Mr Costigan represent not declaration of the law, but opinions by them about the law.
My colleague then said:

. . . but the fact is that this Government failed to take any action. It sent nobody for trial. It did nothing about the matter. On 13 September in a hearing before Estimates Committee A the Crown Solicitor, Mr O'Donovan, said:
Let me say categorically that, before Mr Costigan's report was published, there was no instruction or request to my knowledge given in my office for a prosecution under the 1980 Act.

This Government has absolutely no excuse for its failure to do nothing in this massive tax loss area. It has failed to take account of the fact that some of the laws were and still are outmoded. The existing laws are ineffective, inefficient and above all unforceable. The Government is culpable of the charge that it has, in fact, failed to enforce the existing laws. Let us look at what the tax baron from Queensland, Brian Maher, has had to say. An article appearing in the National Times on 1 July 1978 stated:

He noted also that the recommendations of successive inquiries into taxation, the Ligertwood and Asprey committees (and later Mathews) had been ignored by Federal treasurers. Here then was a certain growth industry, as long as inflation reigned, in which the Government was unlikely to meddle while its tax receipts multiplied.

How many recommendations of these reports, which highlight in so many areas the need for tax reform, have been placed on the statute book? The answer is simple- none. This country has had throughout the business community over at least the last two decades persistent debate over the need for a Federal companies and securities takeover law. The new national companies and securities takeover codes are ineffective, inefficient and unenforceable. It is a charade, as any study of the McCabe-Lafranchi report clearly testifies. The McCabe-Lafranchi report and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union reveal something more sinister; that is, that the laws were in place but because of sheer incompetency they were not enforced. The culpability lies in the fact that Ministers responsible have failed to test the laws. Equally they have failed to act in a number of areas to update the machinery so essential if existing laws are to be made effective and efficient. Under this Government-let it be said so that people understand it clearly-tax has been made optional for the rich. As my good friend, Professor C. Stone, in his book entitled Where the Law Ends, said:
We have arranged things so that the people who call the shots do not have to bear the full risk.
For years I have repeatedly made this claim:

Some tax evasion schemes are so blatant and unreal that they constitute obviously a fraud on the revenue. I feel it is about time that some thought was given to taking actions against the nefarious characters who sell the schemes, on the grounds that they are conspiring to defraud the revenue. Possibly, action of this type could be taken under the Crimes Act.

Certainly bottom-of-the-harbour schemes are well within that category. I direct the attention of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to section 231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which is the tax avoidance provision. It has been on the statute book since 1915. The Treasurer ought to have applied his mind to section 5 and section 86 of the Crimes Act. Before I deal with that matter, I return to the celebrated case of Slutzkin. Let us remember the time frame. The Slutzkin case occurred in 1977. I stated in the House:

The Slutzkin case constituted a dividend stripping arrangement. Slutzkin was a taxpayer closely associated with one Rosenblum who was a director of the company which per- formed a dividend strip. The whole scheme was effected at the same time shares were transferred, considerations paid and assets stripped by the stripping company, Cadez. Cheques were exchanged between the parties and banked simultaneously. In view of the evidence a Supreme Court judge had no hesitation in finding against Slutzkin.
Shortly after that, on 1 July 1978, an article appeared in the National Times headed: 'Brian Maher has a fine eye for tax avoidance: it's made him a millionaire'. The article states:
One day about 10 years ago, Brian Maher, car salesman, was drinking with a mate , one of Sydney's best-known company liquidators, who gave him the following advice.
This was in 1968-

'You're mad paying taxes. Why don't you diversify into loss companies. I'll show you how and I'll supply you with the stock. That way I'll be able to sell my loss companies and you'll be able to make a quid'.

Today, his company, Commercial Securities Ltd, employs about 70 people around Australia. He estimates that the top 10 tax-avoidance companies, of which his is one, have about 20,000 clients and made collective profits of $50m.
As a result of that I put the following question on the Notice Paper to the Treasurer in September:

(1) Has . . . the Commissioner for Taxation given consideration to prosecuting Mr Maher under section 5 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act for aiding and abetting offences against the Income Tax Assessment Act or under section 86 of the Crimes Act for conspiracy to commit an offence or to prevent or defeat the execution or enforcement of tax legislation.
(2) Is he satisfied that the Commissioner for Taxation is doing everything possible to ensure that Mr Maher, as well as his clients, are paying their fair share of the tax burden?
The Treasurer thanked me for drawing his attention to the article. I bet he did! He stated:
Because of the secrecy provisions of the income tax law, the Commissioner of Taxation is unable to divulge any information relating to the affairs of Mr Maher or any other person.
The Commissioner informed me, however, that all available administrative means are used to enforce the taxation laws.
Before I go back to that matter, I will quote a pertinent question. This was asked by the former honourable member for Hindmarsh on the same date:
Will he allow members of the Parliament to see the reports given to the Government since 1 January 1976 on tax avoidance schemes including his estimate of the loss to revenue of such schemes?
The Treasurer replied:

Wherever possible revenue effects have been stated in respect of matters on which the Government has, in its vigorous program of action against tax avoidance, already taken action. When further action is taken on other matters at present under consideration this information will be given to the extent that it is available. It is not customary to make Cabinet Submissions and kindred confidential reports available to members.

Let me say at the outset that the Treasurer has misled this Parliament. The Commissioner of Taxation has persistently pressed the Treasurer to take action under both sections of the Act. The Treasurer has failed to do so. The more important thing is not the question of the Mahers, the Horgans and people like that. The thing for which this Government stands indicted, and specifically the Treasurer, is simply this: You tell me now in this chamber under what sub- section of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, you are prevented from notifying this Parliament on taxation schemes. You had the responsibility--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will address the House through the Chair.

—The Treasurer has a responsibility on receipt of that question-in view of the article, which was quite lengthy, of the activities of Maher and his nefarious schemes-to ask Mr O'Reilly, the Commissioner of Taxation: 'Is this a fact? Are these schemes, in fact, in operation? If they are, what action do you intend to take to block them?' The second question I would have asked as the Treasurer is: 'Mr O'Reilly, are the tax laws, company laws, liquidation laws and bankruptcy laws capable, effective and efficient? Can they be enforced to block that massive rip-off?' Did the Treasurer ask that question? I doubt it. In 1978 the Treasurer had an obligation to apply his mind to that problem. He failed to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have another look at the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Royal Commissioner Costigan deals with the questions I raised in 1978. He stated that the Treasurer could have used the Crimes Act, but he failed to do so. What an appalling indictment it is. In Interim Report No. 4 Costigan stated:
However, the general Criminal Law also applies with equal force irrespective of whether the victim of the fraud is the revenue of the Commonwealth.
In this case I say that the Commonwealth is the creditor. The report continues:
It has long since been the law that all frauds affecting the Crown and the public at large are indictable at Common Law as cheating. That was established as early as 1973 in Rex v Bembridge . . .
Costigan continues:

To add emphasis to this point, attention is drawn to section 86 of the Crimes Act of the Commonwealth. This section specifically provides that it is an offence to conspire with intent to defraud the Commonwealth. It also proscribes a conspiracy to defeat the operation of a law of the Commonwealth.
The Income Tax Assessment Act is a law of the Commonwealth, and conspiracy to defeat its operation is as much an offence as conspiracy to defeat the operation of any other law.
Let us have a look at what Costigan had to say about the Crown Law officers. He stated:
It is sufficient in law for there to be reckless disregard of the financial liability or prospective liability for intent to defraud to be established.

I say to the Treasurer that his difficulty at that time was to find, within his Department, a one-armed lawyer. He had too many two-armed lawyers. The advice he was getting on the one hand was this and on the other hand that. Let us have a look at the question of misfeasance. On this matter Costigan stated:

As long ago as 1870 it was determined that where directors improperly invest or pay away companies' monies, they are liable in misfeasance and that has been re- affirmed many times over the last one hundred years.

The Treasurer could have and should have used section 231. He could have applied section 5 of the Crimes Act. I do not have the time to quote what Spry said, but honourable members ought to read Spry in a recent paper delivered at a seminar. When dealing with section 231-he is not one of our supporters-this is what he had to say:

It might have been thought that the various provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Crimes Act to which reference has been made here are sufficiently broad to render illegal most, at least, forms of tax evasion. It is perhaps curious, therefore, that when recently it became apparent that tax evasion on a large scale had been taking place which involved the removal or dispersal of assets of companies in order to prevent the recovery of tax the Commonwealth chose, instead of invoking these provisions, to have the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act 1980 enacted.

There is yet to be a prosecution in that area. The other question I want to ask the Treasurer is this: What is he going to do to the merchant bank people who have been involved in the conspiracy-they would have to be involved-to facilitate 'Round Robin' cheques? Is he going to apply the law as it is in sections 263 and 264 of the Income Tax Assessment Act? I will be interested to know. The other question I would like to ask is: Why, in the intervening period, have there been no prosecutions pursuant to the new National Companies and Securities Act? There are at least six provisions and at least six areas where people ought to have been prosecuted for failure to comply with the Companies Act. I will conclude with a very telling article. It is a question that really sums up the Treasurer's incompetency. It was a question I asked but it was ruled out of order in March of this year. It sums up this Government and its dilemma. It states:

Can the Treasurer confirm that in the administration of taxation he is guided by the advice of Napoleon to Marshal Kleber that 'to squeeze the poor is safe, but to squeeze the rich beyond accepted limits is decidedly dangerous'.

That is the dilemma of the Treasurer, and of every honourable member opposite. Let me tell the Treasurer this: In 1979 he gave me an undertaking for 400 staff in the Taxation Office. The following year he reduced this by implementing staff ceilings. He saved $1,250,000 but he lost $45m in revenue. This is not the mark of a competent Minister; it is the mark of incompetency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing that is perfectly obvious is that the telephone book is not to the liking of the Opposition. One can see this being considered and a few thoughts have been exchanged between those mighty people who are the leaders. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) says: 'My God, those fellows are for real after all. They have really been trying to do something. What are we going to do?' On 17 August the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) said: 'I had a nice little motion in this House on 17 August and I think I will recycle that.' That is what is being done. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was putting the same sort of arguments as he put then. What was he back to? He was back to the McCabe-Lafranchi report, he was back to billions of dollars, back to the usual assertions which are completely groundless as he knows and which he did not try to establish. As for the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) with his talent of a very minor kind for vilification, that is how he employed it, and that was all he was interested in.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us see what the Opposition is saying. It is continuing, despite the release of almost 400 pages of documents, to conduct a campaign of misrepresentation and vilification of what the Government has done and is doing in the area of tax avoidance and evasion. Specifically, it is deliberately misrepresenting to the Australian people this Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the efforts they have made over the years to stamp out tax avoidance and evasion. Let me, at the outset, nail that misrepresentation. It has continued, yet one of the documents which has been produced is the best possible evidence to establish what a lie that misrepresentation is. It was not referred to but I would not have expected it to have been referred to. On 15 July 1977 the Prime Minister wrote to the Treasurer and said:

I would like to draw your attention to a paper which Dale Budd passed to Andrew Hay a couple of days ago. The paper, which was prepared by a person outside the government, sets out a number of tax avoidance schemes which are said to be in current use.
I believe that the document should be examined most urgently and that if the schemes are correctly described we should be looking to appropriate legislation at the earliest possible date.

That was from the Prime Minister, the person whom the Opposition has the effrontery and dishonesty to describe as a supporter of tax avoidance and evasion. Let us come to the document which the Opposition did go to-it would not have understood it anyway-and recall what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Lionel Bowen) said. He said that the document referred to bottom-of-the- harbour schemes yet he did not go to the document. He knows very well that had he gone to it he would have found that that was not so. Let us go to page 84 of the document that the Prime Minister sent forward to the Treasurer. That is the only page which mentions any scheme which could possibly be described as being close to a stripping operation.That part of the document referred to the sale of companies with current year profits. It sets out the details of those sales and concluded in paragraph 3 in the following terms:
The company broker, once acquiring the company with company profits, injects tax losses into the company to avoid the existing company tax liability.

That scheme was legislated against in 1978 but nobody from the other side who spoke had the honesty even to refer to that fact. Let us turn to the Treasurer. It has been said that the Treasurer has been dilatory. Many things have been said of him, particularly by that disgraceful object, the honourable member for Fremantle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will withdraw the reflection.

—I withdraw. Let us go to what the Commissioner of Taxation had to say on 11 April 1978. He referred to the person who, it is said by the Opposition, is soft on tax avoiders, has not bothered to act against them and would like to keep his good friends off the hook.
—I warn the honourable member for Port Adelaide.
—The Commissioner of Taxation said:

SPEECH.PARA: You mentioned to Mr Boucher this morning that you would like to give consideration to the adoption of a practice whereby, as tax avoidance schemes come to the surface, you would make an announcement foreshadowing remedial legislation which, when enacted, would apply from the date of the announcement.

Does that sound like the action of a person who does not want to stop tax avoidance as soon as it arises? Of course it does not. What did Mr O'Reilly, the Commissioner, go on to say? Later on-it is recorded on the same page-he said:

I feel that I must temper with some words of caution the natural enthusiasm that we all share for taking the earliest practicable action against tax avoidance by, for example, the 'early announcement' practice you have mentioned.
He went on to give reasons why this practice should not be followed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Reluctantly, I interrupt the honourable member for North Sydney. The honourable member for Port Adelaide disregards the exhortation from the Chair not to engage in conversation with members in the Speaker's Gallery. The visitor will be required to retire if the honourable member persists in defying the Chair.

—What does that make perfectly clear? It makes clear that the Commissioner was not willing to travel at the same rate as the Treasurer wanted to travel in acting against tax avoidance. The documents which have been tabled are internal documents. They would never have been disclosed save for the motion of the Senate and the Government's response to that motion. To any fair-minded person-I certainly would not include the Opposition in that category-they established beyond any doubt that both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been determined and dedicated to eradicate tax avoidance and evasion. One can only thank the Opposition for having caused those documents to be presented to the Parliament. One of the reasons that the Opposition did not like the telephone book was that it demonstrated beyond doubt the kinds of actions the Government was taking.

SPEECH.PARA: What have we heard from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition? He has said: 'Well , now, let us look at the evidence'. But when it came to looking at the evidence he was remarkably shy. He made the usual allegation that billions of dollars have been lost. Of course, as is usual, he made no attempt whatsoever to substantiate that allegation by reference to any document, any set of facts or even an opinion. It was something plucked out of the air and it is directly contrary to the assessment made by the Commissioner of Taxation. What else did the Deputy Leader of the Opposition say? He said that the Prime Minister was aware of a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme in July 1977. That is patently untrue.

We had the usual story about Perth. We know perfectly well that the details of the Perth case were not known to the Treasurer. That is apparent from the report of the Costigan Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. It is apparent to anyone who bothers to read the telephone book because there is nothing there which could ever alert the Treasurer or any other person to what was allegedly taking place in Perth in relation to the test case. If there was, no doubt there would have been a reference to it from honourable members on the other side of the House, having culled through the documents overnight. The question might be asked: Does the Opposition accept the figures put forward by the Commissioner of Taxation? He assessed in rough terms a loss of tax liability of around $350m. Does the Opposition impugn the integrity and the competence of the Commissioner as well?

The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) said that I would refer in some detail to some of the steps in the sequence of events. Time does not permit reference in detail to the sequence of events but some points need to be drawn out. The first of these is that, as soon as a submission was received by the Treasurer relating to the emergence of matters that needed to be looked at, it went straight in. That was on 6 June 1978. There was no delay whatsoever. After a ministerial decision was made that the matter should be considered urgently, on 23 August 1978 that consideration took place. Anybody who looked at the consideration by the three departments involved-that is, the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Australian Taxation Office-would realise that there were deep differences of principle as to the proper approach towards remedial legislation. I say in passing that anybody who looks at the file of documents will realise that not once was it put to the Treasurer that existing remedies should be pursued in place of remedial legislation.

After problems were raised which occupied some three and a half months of work within the three departments, the Treasurer sought the advice of the Attorney- General's Department. I am sorry to say that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is unwell and is not in a position to answer to this House. I expect that one would find, if one looked, that there were great differences of view within the departments as to the resolution of an extremely difficult question. At the forefront of the problem was the question of a reversed onus which had originally been put forward by the Taxation Office. The advice was finally given in July 1979. Within two days of the letter of advice coming from the Attorney- General through the Commissioner of Taxation the Treasurer approved it. It was lodged on the same day. Within four days there was a Cabinet decision. So much for delay there. What then took place? Two and a half months was spent on drafting while the papers were with parliamentary counsel. There is no delay there. What then took place? The Government members taxation committee did not like the proposed legislation, as was the case with many people in this country. Many lawyers, many organisations and many ordinary citizens did not like the legislation. What then happened? There was a reference to the Taxation Advisory Committee which one of the honourable members of the Opposition in passing, in his usual and inimitable style, sought to vilify. That Committee had before it the recommendations that came from the Taxation Office for a period from 1 February 1980 until 26 November 1980.

If one wants to look at the degree of urgency that the Taxation Office thought the matters merited then it is worth while taking in these dates. On 1 February 1980 the Treasurer wrote a letter that had been prepared by the Taxation Office asking the Advisory Committee to look at certain matters. The Advisory Committee responded to that letter on 28 February 1980. That response was then put to the Taxation Office. The Taxation Office gave that due consideration. I am not critical of the Taxation Office but it was not until 10 June 1980 that the Office replied-that is after some three months or more. I am not critical of that but it does throw some light upon this supposed immense urgency, upon this supposed extraordinary problem, upon this matter, which it is said, was going to bring taxation avoidance falling to the ground. Of course, this did not take place. What took place then? The Advisory Committee replied. Then there was a final response from the Commissioner of Taxation on 31 October.

The legislation was put into this House. There were amendments to it. Why were there amendments? There were amendments because people found parts of the legislation obnoxious. Some were very concerned about it. Who in this House would have been satisfied with the original proposals which were put up by the Taxation Office? The legislation which was proposed originally was radical. The legislation which was introduced was very far reaching in its consequences. It attracted the widest of criticism throughout the community by people who were concerned with justice-not justice as between the state collecting revenue and getting it in but justice as between citizen and citizen, justice in the courts. It was because of the very deep reservations that the Treasurer held throughout that this matter was looked at so closely. I for one do not apologise for one moment for the Government's taking its time. In making the judgment that the Treasurer did he had to come to an honest, just and decent balance between the needs of the state and the rights of the individuals. No doubt that kind of balance would not be made by the Opposition. When the day comes when we overlook the need to make that balance then we will have lost a very great deal indeed.
Motion (by Sir James Killen) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Lionel Bowen's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the right honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—I do. I understand the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) has again misrepresented me in this place. I did not hear his remarks but I understand that he made some comment about my being a holder of stolen funds. That statement is as false as it was before the suspension for lunch. I believe that the honourable gentleman should know from the statements that I have made in this place that there is no basis on which he could make that slur on me or my name. I reject it absolutely and accuse him of a total falsehood, as I did before lunch.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FIFE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aviation and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Federal Affairs and Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

It is now just over five years since the Ombudsman Act 1976 came into effect and the Commonwealth Ombudsman commenced operations. Professor J. E. Richardson was the first Ombudsman appointed with jurisdiction over the administrative actions of central government agencies in a federal system.
