During the first five years, the Ombudsman received complaints from around 50,000 people, including 13,300 written complaints, about the administrative actions of Commonwealth departments and authorities. I am advised that the Ombudsman has processed around 44,000 of these complaints. All honourable members will have developed an understanding and appreciation of the work of the Ombudsman through his comprehensive annual reports to Parliament and, for many members, through his investigation of around 300 complaints which members of parliament have raised with him on behalf of constituents. Two further enactments of this Parliament, the Complaints ( Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 and the Freedom of Information Act 1982, have recently expanded the Ombudsman's jurisdiction.

The present Bill has two purposes. First, it will implement the Government's decision that a statutory office of Defence Force Ombudsman, to replace the non- statutory office established in 1975, should be created and conferred on the Commonwealth Ombudsman. Second, it will make various other amendments to the Ombudsman Act in the light of operational experience to date. In both areas of the Bill, the Government's decisions have been based largely on reports and recommendations of the Administrative Review Council, a statutory advisory body established by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975. I take this opportunity to commend the Council for its contribution to the development of Commonwealth adminstrative law. The Council's report on the Government's proposal for a statutory office of Defence Force Ombudsman was tabled in the House on 4 June 1981 and, on 10 June 1981, the Minister for Defence tabled a statement indicating that the Government accepted the report's recommendations. An edited version of the report by the Council working party which reviewed the Ombudsman Act and the Ombudsman's jurisdiction was tabled on 2 June 1981. I now seek leave to table a copy of the full report of the Council working party.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Further copies have been placed in the Parliamentary Library. The Government has accepted virtually all of the Council's recommendations on the Ombudsman Act and jurisdiction. I seek leave to table a paper detailing the Government's response to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The Council's recommendations on the Ombudsman's jurisdiction over Commonwealth companies and commercial and trading authorities remain under examination, though I hope to be able to announce the Government's decision on these in the near future. The Council's report on the statutory Defence Force Ombudsman favoured conferring the proposed jurisdiction on the Ombudsman because a small and separate Defence Force Ombudsman organisation and the existence of two ombudsmen with overlapping jurisdictions would impose significant administrative difficulties and an unnecessary extra cost. The Council proposed, nevertheless, that a special Deputy Ombudsman (Defence Force) be designated to assist in day to day Defence Force Ombudsman work and that a separate part of the Act create the jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill, in consequence, aptly identifies the Defence Force Ombudsman's distinct character. The Government sees the creation of the statutory office as an important advancement in conditions of employment for service members. Servicemen and service women differ from most other Australians in that their relationships with their employer can extend into almost every aspect of their lives. It is in the nature of Defence Force service that members do not have the advantage of external grievance mechanisms typical in civil employment. Recognising this before a deputy ombudsman is appointed or designated for the Defence Force jurisdiction, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)) will consult with the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair).

The Defence Force Ombudsman's basic function is to investigate, either on complaint being made or of his own motion, administrative actions related to or arising from a person's service in the Defence Force. Although most complaints will come from current or former Service members, other persons, such as their dependants, will also be able to lodge complaints if they are affected by actions which are within the Defence Force Ombudsman's jurisdiction. In recognition of Service members' special position, the Defence Force Ombudsman's jurisdiction is defined by service in the Defence Force, whereas the Commonwealth Ombudsman is excluded from investigating matters arising in Commonwealth civilian employment. There are, however, some exclusions from this jurisdiction which parallel exclusions from the Commonwealth Ombudsman's jurisdiction. In addition, the Defence Force Ombudsman is excluded from investigating action taken in the conduct of disciplinary proceedings, and action relating to the grant or refusal of honours and awards-but not awards for service in a particular area or for a particular period.

Review by the Defence Force Ombudsman will complement, rather than compete with , existing internal redress procedures: For effective management in the Defence Force, officers should usually hear and have the first opportunity to remedy the grievances of those under their command. Thus the Bill provides that the Defence Force Ombudsman shall not investigate a complaint by a serving member of the Defence Force unless the member first seeks internal redress and a period of 28 days elapses, though he may investigate earlier in special circumstances and may also further investigate a complaint where he and the complainant are not satisfied that the redress granted is adequate. The legislation applies most of the procedural provisions in the Ombudsman Act to the Defence Force Ombudsman- such as those concerning the conduct of investigations. To avoid artificial jurisdictional difficulties, special provision is made for handling complaints which involve both the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Defence Force Ombudsman jurisdictions or which are not directed to the appropriate Ombudsman. As well, transitional provisions in the Bill provide for the transfer to the statutory office of any unfinished business of the non-statutory office.

The remainder of the Bill, as I have mentioned, makes a number of amendments to the Ombudsman Act based on the Ombudsman's operational experience to date, drawing on the review of the Administrative Review Council. The main theme of these amendments is that the Ombudsman, primarily an independent officer with the statutory formal duties and powers essential to vigorous investigation and reporting of defective administration, should normally operate less formally than is appropriate for other administrative review mechanisms, such as courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Professor Richardson has developed this theme in his annual reports and has explained in these reports the informal operating procedures which he has built up with the co-operation of Commonwealth departments and authorities. The Government endorses these developments and believes that, where possible and proper simple and prompt remedies for complainants should be recognised and facilitated by the Ombudsman Act.

Accordingly, several amendments are made which give the Ombudsman greater discretions and flexibility by modifying formal procedural requirements in the Act. In particular, the Bill includes amendments which recognise that the Ombudsman may accept and resolve oral complaints, unless there is need to investigate formally; simplify the Ombudsman's discretion not to investigate formally certain complaints; streamline the requirements for the Ombudsman to notify the Minister and agency head of his decision to investigate a complaint or otherwise; and give legislative backing to the Ombudsman's practice of making informal inquiries. The last amendment will also clarify that the Ombudsman may inquire informally to establish that a matter is within his jurisdiction before investigating formally. In amendments which are similarly to facilitate his role in encouraging better and more accessible administration, the Bill also gives the Ombudsman greater discretion to disseminate information or comments on his investigations to Commonwealth agencies, the Parliament, other persons with an interest in the outcome of investigations-for example, parliamentarians-and, where special circumstances so warrant, the public at large.

Other amendments variously strengthen or widen the Ombudsman's role commensurate with developing practice and with the Government's intentions when the Ombudsman legislation was introduced in 1976. These amendments will provide a sounder statutory basis for co-operative investigation by the Commonwealth Ombudsman and his counterparts in the States and Northern Territory where both Commonwealth and State and Territory activities or undertakings are involved; empower the Federal Court to determine issues arising in relation to the Ombudsman's powers and jurisdiction when normal consultation processes cannot otherwise resolve them; expand the circumstances in which the Ombudsman can cause matters to come before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; and clarify certain doubts that have arisen regarding the Ombudsman's jurisdiction over particular types of action, including action preceding or succeeding action by a Minister, or over particular types of Commonwealth bodies. More detailed information on the provisions of the Bill is set out in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated. I foreshadow the Government's intention that the Committee stage of the Bill be taken in a Legislation Committee of the House. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Scholes) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

On 9 September the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) tabled in Parliament the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission containing its recommendations for the calendar year 1983, in response to the Government's guidelines. The Bill gives effect to the Government's decisions on the Commission's financial recommendations for 1983, all of which have been accepted . As announced in the Government's guidelines statement, the Bill also provides for additional funds for 1982 programs, to help meet unanticipated cost increases arising from recent teacher salary determinations. The overall level of Commonwealth expenditure on schools programs in 1983 will be about $1,241m, an increase of 3.9 per cent in real terms over 1982-all amounts being in 1983 outturn prices. The value of most programs will be at least maintained in real terms. For some programs there will be significant real increases.

Part II of the Bill contains provision for programs in government schools. To assist the States to overcome the financial difficulties which the Commission reported were facing government school systems, general recurrent grants for government schools will be increased by 2 per cent in real terms in 1983. Funds for the capital grants program for government schools will be maintained at the same real level as in 1982. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that 10 per cent of the funds be distributed on the basis of certain indicators of the need to provide new pupil places. In addition, a general clause has been included in the Bill indicating that prior to the granting of funds to a State, the Commonwealth Minister must be satisfied with arrangements to identify projects to which Commonwealth funds are to be applied.

Part III of the Bill contains provision for programs in non-government schools. General recurrent grants to non-government schools have been increased in accordance with the policy which ties Commonwealth per capita grants to non- government schools to movements in the average cost of educating a student in a government school. The increases in commitments to non-government schools are also a result of increases in the subsidy rate to schools with the lowest recurrent resources-group 3-from 38 per cent to 40 per cent of average government school standard costs. This fulfils the Government's commitment in the 1980 election to provide three levels of assistance for non-government schools equal to 20 per cent, 30 per cent and 40 per cent of the average cost of educating a student in a government school. Almost 95 per cent of the increase in Commonwealth general recurrent grants in 1983 will be directed to those schools assessed as having lowest recurrent resources. On average such schools operate at recurrent resource levels some 30 per cent below those of government schools.

The Government endorses the Commission's intention to implement fully the previous decision to give consideration to income as well as expenditure in the assessment of non-government schools' subsidy categories and expects that the income checking procedure introduced on a limited basis in 1982 will be applied to all non-government schools eligible for group 2 or group 3 grants in 1983. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that eligibility for grants under the Short Term Emergency Assistance Program be extended to include any non-government school suffering a financial crisis caused by a sudden disaster.

In accordance with the Government's acceptance of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs recommendation that funding for new arrivals should be adjusted according to the number of newly-arrived students, this element of the English as a Second Language Program in 1983 will be funded on the basis of a per capita grant of $880. This is essentially the same per capita amount in real terms as in 1982 and has been calculated to provide a program of intensive English language instruction for a period of up to six months. The final cost of the program will therefore be determined by the actual number of eligible newly- arrived students. For the general support element of the English as a Second Language Program a further adjustment has been made to the distribution of program funds among the States to accord with the results of a recent national survey of students of non-English speaking background. Funds for the general support element for non-government schools have not been allocated on a State-by -State basis in the Bill. However, the Government intends that the allocations to Catholic schools in the various States and Territories will be in accordance with the recommended distribution in the Commission's Report. For non-Catholic schools, the Government intends that State planning and finance committees should continue to be responsible for recommending the distribution of funds.

A significant new policy development encompassed in this Bill is the provision for the participation of children of below school age in the Special Education Program. This also applies to the children in institutions and severely handicapped children's programs which are joint programs for both government and non-government schools. Joint programs are dealt with in Part IV of the Bill. The allocation for the Severely Handicapped Children's Program has been increased by 25 per cent or $0.7m in real terms. The same real level of funds will be provided for the Professional Development Program for 1983, including funds for education centres.

Allocations of grants for 1983 for the various programs for the States and the Northern Territory, are detailed in Schedules 1 to 11 of the Bill. These grants include provision of a prospective allowance for cost increases up to the end of 1983, in accordance with established Government policy. Grants for current programs for calendar year 1982 are adjusted under Part VI and Schedule 12 to help meet unanticipated cost increases arising from recent teacher salary determinations. The additional cost of these adjustments is $45m.

An amendment has been made to the relevant clause in Part V of the Bill to enable the Commonwealth Minister to delegate all or any of his powers under the Act, other than that of delegation. This will improve the administration of programs and the Minister will consider carefully which matters should be retained for ministerial decision. The provisions of this Bill demonstrate the Commonwealth's continuing commitment to high standards in all Australian schools , whether government or non-government. The increased overall level of support will enable further real improvements in the recurrent resource levels of all schools in Australia. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Scholes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) tabled in the Parliament on 9 September the report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for 1983. This report was in response to the Government's guidelines for financial assistance for capital and equipment programs for universities and colleges of advanced education, and capital, equipment and recurrent programs for technical and further education institutions. The primary purpose of the States Grants ( Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill is to amend the States Grants ( Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981 to implement the Government's decisions for 1983 on the financial recommendations made by the Commission, all of which have been accepted. Higher education recurrent grants for the 1982-84 triennium were determined by the Government in 1981 under the existing fixed triennial arrangements; however these are adjusted in the Bill to take account of recent Government decisions.

The capital grants contained in this Bill total $137.6m, of which $34.7m is for universities and advanced education. For TAFE, the 1983 capital grants amount to $102.9m. The Bill appropriates $58.8m for the 1983 equipment program for universities and advanced education and $10.1m for TAFE special equipment grants . Recurrent grants for TAFE for 1983 contained in this Bill amount to $88.3m.

Under the principal Act, certain institutions of higher education do not have recurrent grants appropriated for 1983 and 1984. Consolidation arrangements were recommended by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and required by the Government's decisions arising from its Review of Commonwealth Functions. Consolidation arrangements have now been made for 26 of the 30 colleges of advanced education listed in the RCF decision. These include an amalgamation of the Institute of Early Childhood Development and Melbourne State College which has now been agreed by the Victorian Government. Funds have therefore been included in this legislation for the new amalgamated institution for 1983 and 1984. Acceptable proposals have yet to be made in respect of Armidale CAE, Newcastle CAE, Milperra CAE and the State College of Victoria, Hawthorn.

In its report the Commission has noted the progress being made towards integration of the activities of the University of Newcastle and Newcastle CAE under a single governing body and towards consolidation of activities of the SCV , Hawthorn. It has suggested an appropriate approach to the consolidation of the activities of the Milperra CAE. However, at Armidale, the university has maintained its opposition to integration of its activities with those of the college, notwithstanding the college's preparedness to meet the Commonwealth's conditions for consolidation. The Government strongly supports the view of the Commission, which stated:

. . . higher education in Armidale and the surrounding region would benefit from an amalgamation of the University and the College. It regrets the attitude which the University has taken on this matter. The University's attitude prejudices the improved provision of higher education in Armidale and the region , and puts at risk future funding.

The shift in Australian demography has required fundamental changes in the structure of higher education as so much of that system related to teacher education. The consolidation of these remaining institutions will complete the comprehensive reorganisation of higher education which was recommended by the CTEC and supported by the Review of Commonwealth Functions. It is essential that we enter calendar year 1983 with a reorganised system which will provide improved and expanded opportunities for higher education.

In the circumstances the Government has decided that recurrent funds for all the institutions concerned, including the two universities, be put aside in a national unallocated grant. These funds will be allocated by the Minister, after advice from the Commission, when acceptable proposals are recommended in respect of the institutions which have not yet met the Commonwealth's requirements on consolidation. This means that acceptable proposals will need to be available by the end of 1982. The Minister is anxious for the institutions and State Governments concerned to produce acceptable proposals before the end of the year so that he can make these funds available.

The Commission, in preparing its report, also considered the future of the Orange Agricultural College. The Government supports the Commission's recommendation that separate funding for the Orange Agricultural College should continue in 1983. It expects that the College will enter into an appropriate consolidation arrangement by January 1984. For this reason the Bill includes the 1984 recurrent funds for the Orange Agricultural College in the National Unallocated Grant for Higher Education.

The higher education recurrent grants include provision for up to an additional $4m in 1983 and $8m in 1984 to assist institutions to meet increased superannuation costs. These grants will assist with the cost of the new national superannuation scheme developed by the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee and the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations. This new scheme is designed to replace existing arrangements which give inadequate benefits to many staff. In addition, the grants will assist with the problem of meeting increased costs resulting from membership of State government superannuation schemes with a view to limiting these costs to the level of the new AVCC-FAUSA scheme.

Additional recurrent grants of $0.2m in 1983 and $0.3m in 1984 have been included in the Bill for the University of Melbourne to assist with the development of graduate teaching and research in management education. This results from the Government's consideration of the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Management Education, the Ralph Report. The provision of up to $4m as the Commonwealth contribution towards the construction of a building for the new graduate school of management at the University of Melbourne will be finalised following the Government's consideration of further proposals to be developed for the establishment and management of the school. These proposals will include the active co-operation and involvement of the Australian business community.

Following the Government's consideration of the evaluation of post-arrival programs and services for migrants by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, the Government decided that 15 per cent of TAFE particular purpose grants will be allocated for implementing programs of advanced English language instruction for migrants. An additional amount of $1.1m is being transferred to assit in meeting these costs. The Commission will be consulting with the States on the implementation of this program and will report in November on the most appropriate method of giving full effect to the decisions within 12 months.

Technical and further education capital grants include financial assistance for the construction of seven major building projects and the design of a further two building projects under the new three-year $60m National Priority Projects Program. The first instalment of this new three-year program which is included in the Bill will be $12.2m for 1983. This level of activity recognises that expenditure on new projects is inevitably less in the first year than occurs in later years. However, the Commission's recommendations provide for the full expenditure of the $60m allocated over the three years 1983 to 1985.

At this stage all money amounts in the Bill are expressed in 1982 outturn prices. These will be adjusted to 1983 outturn prices at a later stage. The Government has been giving consideration to the recent report of the Academic Salaries Tribunal. It had also been awaiting the 17 September decision by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on Commonwealth Public Service salaries, since these salary levels are taken as the basis for funding non-academic salary costs. The Government will now consider both decisions and will determine the prospective allowance for tertiary education grants for 1983. The Government's decisions on these matters will be incorporated in the Bill at the Committee stage. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Scholes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF FORT QUEENSCLIFF, QUEENSCLIFF, VICTORIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Redevelopment of Fort Queenscliff, Queenscliff, Victoria.

This proposal is for the provision of new and upgraded facilities at the Army Command and Staff College, Queenscliff. The existing buildings are not functionally suitable for their present purposes and are unduly expensive to maintain. The facilities will be provided both within Fort Queenscliff and at Crow's Nest, an adjacent site some 400 metres from the Fort. The elements of the work comprise: A new military instruction facility; alterations to existing buildings and engineering services; living accommodation; a quartermaster store and ration store; a transport compound; and associated roads, car parking, landscaping and engineering services. The estimated cost of the proposal at September 1982 prices is $8.3m. I table plans of the proposed work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up much of the time of the House. The fort complex at Queenscliff is one of the historic areas of Australia. Whilst I have not had the opportunity at this stage to study the plans I hope that the Government is taking cognisance of the historic classification of the fort and the area in which it is located. It is a very important military establishment and, in addition, one of Australia's most historic military buildings. In fact, like so many of our early historic military structures, it was built to fight the Russians. It fired the first shot of the First World War.

SPEECH.PARA: We welcome this proposal to upgrade the facilities at Queenscliff. I trust that the plans and the ultimate works will be undertaken in accordance with the historic nature of the buildings and will maintain the history and the significance of the area. I trust that the Fort will not be sacrificed to modernisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his comments. I will take them into account.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPLACEMENT OF OPERATING THEATRES AT REPATRIATION GENERAL HOSPITAL, DAW PARK, SOUTH AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Replacement of operating theatres and refurbishment of the surgical wards at the Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park, SA.

This proposal is for the construction of a new operating theatre building and the refurbishing and extension of existing pavilion wards 5, 6, 7 and 8. The new building will contain four operating theatres with theatre sterilising and support facilities. The Committee has endorsed the need for the work and reported that the design is satisfactory. The Committee has further recommended that wards 1 and 2 also need upgrading and that this work should be undertaken immediately after completion of the work covered by this motion. The Government agrees with the recommendation to upgrade the standard of accommodation in wards 1 and 2 and understands that the Department of Veterans' Affairs will be seeking the inclusion of this work in the 1984-85 capital works program.

In its report the Committee said that the Department of Veterans' Affairs should have corrected the deficiencies in the standard of facilities at the hospital earlier. The main reason for the delay in bringing the proposal forward for government approval related to the need for and relative priority of capital works projects in all repatriation hospitals. The majority of the buildings in these hospitals were constructed in the early 1940s and, by the late 1960s, the Department, faced with significant changes in medical technology, treatment procedures and accommodation standards, proceeded progressively to upgrade the aging facilities in all institutions. Throughout the 1970s, against a background of expenditure restraint, major capital improvements programs were initiated on a priority basis in many of the repatriation general hospitals throughout Australia. With the endorsement of the future role of the hospital at Daw Park by the Repatriation Commission, following a review in 1978, the Department proceeded with planning to upgrade the facilities at the hospital as quickly as possible including a new medical ward, construction of which commenced in July this year. With the completion of the work referred to in this motion, the standard of surgical facilities will be comparable with the most modern available in this country.

In paragraph 32 of its report the Committee indicated that it would like to be assured that the provision of laminar flow air conditioning to only two of the four operating theatres will not diminish the overall efficiency of the operating theatre complex. It is now generally accepted that the installation of laminar flow or controlled directional air flow systems in operating theatres is essential for major orthopaedic surgery, particularly surgery involving joint replacement. In view of the expense associated with the installation of these units, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, in defining its needs, was careful to ensure that what was proposed was consistent with the work load projected for the facilities. The Department has concluded that two units are adequate to meet current and projected demand and will not impede the future operational efficiency of the complex.

In paragraph 42 the Committee noted that, following a recent overall reduction in staff ceilings throughout the Commonwealth Public Service, ward 8, a female ward at the hospital, was closed. As a result of the recent Budget announcements , the hospital will be allocated an increase in staff to enable a ward to be reopened. Finally the Committee has reported that it was gratified to find overwhelming support from ex-service organisations for the proposal and for the retention of Repatriation General Hospital, Daw Park, as the primary facility for the treatment of veterans and war widows in Adelaide. The work is estimated to cost $6.5m at April 1982 prices. The Committee has recommended construction of the work in the reference. If the House agrees to support this motion planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HODGMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 22 to 24 (1982).

The Customs tariff proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966 Proposals No. 22 which operates from 31 May 1982, contains changes to the concessions accorded under the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement. The agreement is a preferential non- reciprocal agreement between Australia and New Zealand on the one hand and the island member countries of the South Pacific Forum on the other. Some of the changes in the proposals result from the addition of further products to the list of goods accorded concessional tariff treatment while the remaining changes are caused by an alignment of the Customs tariff on the schedules to the agreement, which has been recently ratified on the basis of the four-figure items contained in the Customs Co-operation Council's nomenclature.

Proposals No. 23 which operates from 1 July 1982, implements the Government's decision to add further goods to Schedule A of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement. The goods of New Zealand origin which will have their duties reduced are: Resistors, fixed or variable, including potentiometers; arc lamp carbons, battery carbons, carbon electrodes and other carbon articles of a kind used for electrical purposes, other than carbon brushes and goods which are already on Schedule A of the agreement; and truck trailer automatic couplings. Proposals No. 24 (1982) which operates from tomorrow introduces tariff changes arising from the Government's decision on recommendations made by the Industries Assistance Commission in its report on products of the forging, foundry, die casting, sheet metal industries and other fabricated metal products.

The Government has accepted the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendations with some minor variations to the phasing arrangements to apply and to rates for certain goods from Canada, New Zealand and some developing countries. The assistance for the goods under reference will be: A long term rate of 20 per cent for most of the goods under reference, phased in over one, two or three years in some cases; a long term rate of 25 per cent for certain industrial and other fasteners, locks and padlocks et cetera, stationery fittings etcetera, and certain lamps and lighting fittings, phased in over one year in some cases; minimum rates on goods currently receiving low levels of assistance or where local production is minimal; and, a rate of 5 per cent on cigarette, cigar and pipe lighters to accord New Zealand a margin of preference under Australia's agreement on tariffs and tariff preferences with New Zealand.

The Government has noted the IAC's conclusions that implementation of its recommendations should not have any serious adverse effects on levels of activity or employment in most areas of local production and that the reductions in duties and in disparities should provide benefits through improved resource allocation and production and consumption patterns more closely related to the dictates of the market. The proposals-and I must say that I am still getting used to 'proposals', a plural, attracting a singular verb, but that is the form of language traditionally used-also contains provisions to exempt one further category of steel which is included on Schedule A of the New Zealand Australia Free Trade Agreement from the scope of the temporary duty imposed on above quota imports as a result of the Government's decision on the Temporary Assistance Authority's report on certain flat steel products, pipes and tubes of iron or steel.

Proposals No. 24 (1982) also contains an amendment to allow textile fabrics and articles made up from textile fabric that are otherwise eligible for admission under handicraft quota to qualify when they contain not less than 90 per cent by weight of natural fibres. This change results from the Government's decision to reduce the natural fibre content requirement from the current 95 per cent by weight. I have already signed a Customs by-law making a similar change for those textile fabrics and textile articles which are eligible for unrestricted duty free entry under the handicraft by-law to item 36 of Part I of Schedule 2 to the Customs Tariff Act. A comprehensive summary of the duty changes has been prepared and is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1982

Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet

Department of the Vice-President of the Executive Council
Proposed expenditure, $105,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I say how much I regret that we will not have the opportunity by way of the Estimates committee system that operated last year and, indeed, over the last few years to question the relevant Ministers in more detail about the Estimates. However, we are back to the old form. The Estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet allow me a wide canvas. The Department has, for instance, an economics branch. Through that branch, the Department has a significant influence on the decisions taken by the Government as they relate to the level of economic activity in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I need hardly tell the House that we are suffering depression conditions in Australia at present due to the wrong economic strategy being pursued by the Government. I wish to illustrate the problems that this is causing for the people of this country by talking of one of the areas of my own responsibility as shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, namely, the small business area. I will talk in particular about that small business area whose members are known as the truckies of this nation. The truckies are being squeezed. Owner-drivers have enormous problems. If only the estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet of $68m were used a little more effectively by, hopefully, better advice being given to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) we might have a change of economic strategy which would help this group.

The Australian road transport industry, including long distance interstate and short haul intrastate transport, is facing one of its most serious recessions in 50 years. A combination of drought and recession-as well as those wrong economic policies-has led to average declines in freight tonnage movements of 12.5 per cent in the 12 months to 31 August. I emphasise 'average decline' because for many companies in many sectors the decline is much higher and their situation is correspondingly that much more serious. The road transport industry is especially vulnerable because of the very high proportion of small business operators-with up to six vehicles-and owner-drivers. Subcontractors in this industry carry an estimated 75 per cent of the freight forwarders' requirements. The remaining 25 per cent is carted by direct employees.

I acknowledge the fact that industry Australia-wide is facing difficult times. I assert that to a great extent this is due to the wrong domestic economic policies. I have stressed many times in this House and elsewhere that the responsibility for the recession overall must be laid firmly at the feet of the Government. Therefore, it is appropriate that I should talk about this matter in the estimates of such a significant Department of the Government as the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. That Department must be partly responsible for advising on the efficacy of the monetarist policies being followed.

Nowhere is the irresponsibility more evident than in the case of the road transport industry. On representative figures adopted by the Australian Road Transport Federation and Transport Workers Union of Australia, the average owner -driver on the run between Melbourne and Sydney has been pushed below the margin of viability. The result is that many hundreds of small business operators and owner-drivers are now being forced into bankruptcy. I repeat that this is just one example of what is happening to the small business sector generally. Under normal circumstances bankruptcy would be bad enough, but in this industry the liability of the business extends well beyond the assets of the business and includes the home, the private car and, indeed, anything and everything that might be appropriated to meet the debts of the business. In this industry bankruptcy means total ruin-ruin for the family, not just for the business. So much for the effects of the recession arising from the contradictionary policies of the Government.

The Government is responsible in yet another important sense; namely, the taxes which it imposes on the fuel costs of the transport industry. Freight rates, the vital source of small business revenue in this industry, are already inadequate. They have been squeezed too hard. Whatever margin they may have yielded has been eroded by the high level of and rapid increases in the Federal oil levy and the Federal excise tax on diesel fuel. I repeat that it is appropriate that this matter be brought up under these estimates. Because the economics branch of this Department will advise the Government on these matters and the effects they are having on our economy.

Federal fuel taxes currently amount to 19.65c per litre. This is made up of a 13.5c crude oil levy and a 6.15c excise. Since December 1981 the Federal Government has increased the crude oil levy by 1.94c per litre, or by a massive 17 per cent. Additionally, over the same period, the Federal Government increased its excise tax take by 19 per cent. These extraordinary and, I believe , irresponsible increases in owner-driver costs are occurring in the very same period that owner-driver revenues are collapsing because of the lack of economic activity.

I wonder whether the Government has any idea of the personal distress these policies are causing the small business sector. I have already referred to the spectre of bankruptcy which is haunting that sector and, in particular, the owner-driver industry. I wonder whether the Government has any idea of the hazards the distress causes in the wider community through, for instance, the road toll. I refer particularly to the safety factors involved here. State police forces have repeatedly drawn our attention to the dangers of unsafe vehicles and exhausted drivers, of drivers being forced to cut corners in terms of vehicle repairs and maintenance, of drivers being forced to work incredibly long hours and so on. These factors create risks for the community, especially the country areas, which any responsible government would not tolerate. This Government is not only tolerating them but is also, as I have shown, introducing yet more costs which make them worse. I refer again to the crude oil levy, the excise taxes and the other costs imposed on this small business sector as an example of the burdens being imposed on the business community generally, with such dire effects on so many families.

Anticipating the response on these matters from the Government, I say that it is no use blaming State governments for this problem. Despite the recent increases in New South Wales, the owner-driver still pays more than 80 per cent of his total fuel tax liability to the Federal Government, as I have shown. The Prime Minister would be foolish to deny that it was his policies which forced the New South Wales Government into raising fuel taxes in that State. The Premier, Mr Wran, returned from a Premiers Conference and imposed these fuel taxes because he was not given an adequate proportion of the revenue.

What can be done? A Labor government would examine seriously the possibility of a temporary exemption for the small transport operators and owner-drivers from the 6.15c Federal tax. I do not make any promises in that area at this stage because the matter has not been properly processed. But that sort of exemption was granted to farmers long before they began to face the problems of drought. We now have the absurd situation in the country of the farmer being granted an exemption and the hard pressed owner-driver who carts the farm produce having to pay the tax in full. In the longer term there is no solution to this problem which does not acknowledge the important and positive role which the Transport Workers Union has played and is playing in establishing more viable freight rates. But-again the irresponsibility of the Government is clear-the status of the owner-driver in terms of his right to join the representative organisation of his choice has been thrown into question by deliberate confrontationist amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Yet it is generally acknowledged around the industry that the freight rates negotiated by the Transport Workers Union have led to a considerable improvement in the well being of the owner-driver sector-a well being which is now being destroyed by the activities of the present Government.

If we are to have debates on the estimates in this form, we will paint a wide canvas and make these sorts of points. I welcome the opportunity to do so. I was not able to make a speech on the Budget itself. I use this example of the burdens on the smaller business sector as an example of the wrong economic policies being imposed by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, I would like to make some comments about the general direction Australia is heading economically and the need for various elements of the Australian community to seek to pull together so that in fact the productivity, profitability and way of life of this country is maintained and improved. In the year just concluded the average wage for Australians rose by about 17 per cent. Taking account of the shorter working hours as well as the additional wages paid, one can quickly identify industries which have received more, such as the printing industry, with an increase of 46 per cent, and the metal trades and building industries, with increases of 25 per cent or more.

SPEECH.PARA: In total, Australians felt that they were worth 17 per cent more in money last year than in the year before. At the same time inflation rose at a rate of about 10 per cent for the financial year. So Australians are more than maintaining their disposable income. If one assesses the income for various levels of employment and various types of employment over a long period one can readily see that the net disposable income for Australians has been more than maintained and has done so over a considerable period. In no financial year has it been more than maintained than in 1981-82. I believe that the Australian community needs to realise that there are some generous aspects of the Budget-in fact, it is a generous Budget.

The parts of the Budget that are directed to the wage and salary earner in general and to families in particular seek to provide assistance to meet increases in the cost of living over the forthcoming year. At the same time, if the Australian community continues to increase its demand on our resources, the wealth of the nation, our capacity to continue to function as an exporting nation, as a major trading nation, and to be basically self-reliant regarding basic commodities will be eroded and could be destroyed. The whole community is aware of the possibility of the loss of markets for coal, iron ore and other major commodities produced in this nation. There are two reasons for this- industrial disruption and increasing costs. The basic factor of increasing costs has been the increases in wages and salaries during the last 12 months.

The Budget sets out to alleviate the situation of families which are facing higher costs of living and to provide the basis of moderate and reasonable wage settlements for the forthcoming year. The Budget provides many families with two -thirds or more of the income increase they need to cover inflation during the coming year. I will give a couple of examples. From 1 November the disposable income of a man on an average wage of $300 a week with a dependent wife and two children and with a mortgage on his house of roughly $30,000 will rise by $18 a week. This is after allowing for increases in indirect taxes. This, if one translate it into a wage rise, is an increase of perhaps 9 per cent. A reduction in the tax that an individual pays is much more advantageous than a wage rise of a similar amount. A disposable income increase and a reduction in tax which I am talking about is of greater benefit to the family and is equivalent to a wage rise of approximately 9 per cent. The inflation rate will be 10.5 to 11 per cent at the end of the year. The wage increase such a family needs to cover the increase in the cost of living is about 5 per cent for 12 months.

It is interesting to note that members of this Parliament have settled for a salary increase of 7 per cent. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has recommended wage and salary increases for the Commonwealth Public Service of 5 or 6 per cent. I believe these are examples that should be followed by the rest of the community if we are to maintain our way of life, our competitiveness and our capacity to earn export dollars. If the community were to accept an average increase for the forthcoming year of 5, 6 or 7 per cent then I believe it would be possible for Australia to compete on world markets and resolve the economic difficulties in the nation at the moment. As I said, an increase of $18 in a family's disposable income is equivalent to a wage increase of $26 a week. Most families with incomes less than $300 per week or with more than two children will benefit even more than the family I have used as an example. They will have a greater capacity to offset inflation in 1982-83.

Those generous benefits are directed at people who most need them. They come on top of very substantial real wage increases for the past year. They will seek to supplement modest wage gains during the forthcoming year. It is to be hoped that the metal industries and the trades involved in those industries, the great manufacturing industries of Australia, the building industry and the export industries, will recognise that their employees will, as a result of this Budget , need only modest wage gains for the forthcoming year to maintain their average standard of living and, in fact, to continue the trend that has been obvious since this Government came to office. It has constantly increased real average wages. A man on average weekly earnings with a dependent wife and two children will have an estimated real net disposable income of $261 per week in 1982-83. This is an increase of $18 or 7.5 per cent from two years earlier. That is a very great increase in the take-home pay of families. This Budget has said to the Australian community: 'We need to be more moderate. We need to be more thoughtful of the eventual future of our own nation, our own employment and the employment prospects of our children'. This Budget seeks to establish a rapport with the people who contribute so much to the nation in the work place by ensuring that they will best benefit by significant moderation in wage claims in the forthcoming year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet I will confine my comments to division 516 which deals with the Public Service Board. In passing I will also make some comment on the Public Service generally. This morning the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced an inquiry into the Public Service. I can only say: ' What a farce'. Any problems in the Public Service have been caused by seven years of this Government, by its policy of reducing staff numbers, undermining morale, keeping a lid on the salaries of public servants and, now, of blaming public servants for the faults and the neglect of Ministers. The Public Service Board demonstrates in many ways what is wrong with the Public Service. I believe that the Public Service Board is reactive, with little vision, and this is directly because of the policies of this Government. It has spent so much of its resources and the time and resources of the senior staff on the Board in implementing the Government's staff ceiling policy and in dealing with one crisis after another. It is really the band-aid or crisis approach to public administration.

SPEECH.PARA: What resources and priorities has the Public Service Board or the Public Service generally been able to give in the last seven years to promoting efficiency and encouraging the adoption of modern personnel practices in the Public Service that has caused this Government to decide suddenly that they are so important? Why does the Prime Minister now suddenly see fit to introduce another inquiry into the Public Service? This is the fourth since he came into office. We had the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, the Bland Administrative Review Committee-now, of course, we will recycle one of the members of the Bland Committee into the new inquiry if he lasts out the day-the razor gang and now we have the new inquiry. When Dr Coombs, the Chairman of the Royal Commission, presented his report, he set out in great detail the problems of the Public Service. Honourable members should remember that this occurred in 1976 when this Government and this Prime Minister were in office. I will quote selectively from an article in the Canberra Times which reports Dr Coombs's speech to the Press Club. He said:

It's time that we concentrated on the defects of Government administration and on measures to improve its performance . . . Australian government administration compares favourably with that of other countries and with most large organisations in the private sector . . . The raw material with which the system has to work is of good quality . . .
However the best of the top levels of the bureaucracy are men of capacity and vigour. They compare favourably with leaders of industry, commerce and the professions . . .

Effective government requires a partnership between the political arm of government and the bureaucracy . . . I believe that within the Australian bureaucracy there are men and women of dedication and capacity struggling for a chance to serve Governments and community more effectively.

These statements were made in 1976. Dr Coombs identified problems in the Public Service-there is no doubt about that-but his recommendations tried to come to grips with those problems, particularly with the aspects of morale, trying to get the best out of individuals, and the government arm working closely with the bureaucratic arm. Those recommendations are all in his report. They are still there today and they are still as relevant. The real problem is the fault not of the bureaucracy but of the Government because it has done nothing to implement those recommendations, except to instigate, the razor gang report and now another one. The Commonwealth Public Service is over-reviewed. It has spent so much of its resources reviewing itself. Why do we not just get on with the job of doing something constructive with the Public Service and improving its morale ? In a moment I will give some recommendations on how we can do that. The problems have been there throughout the seven years of this Government. They have been reinforced by this Government. They have even been identified in the Public Service Board's annual report. Page 1 of the Public Service Board's annual report for 1980-81 states:
. . . public servants are used to being singled out for lampooning.
They ought to be used to it; they get enough of it in this Parliament. The report continues:

But it becomes at best tedious, and at worst destructive or morale, for public servants to be incessantly the target of generalised and sweeping criticism, especially when it is only too rarely that contrary views from any quarters are expressed and given publicity.

That has been one of the major problems that have led to the reduction of morale . We can solve many of the problems in the Public Service by treating public servants with respect. Sure, there are problems but many of those problems are caused by the neglect of Ministers, by the neglect of the Prime Minister and generally by the neglect of this Government. Did the Lynch razor gang, in bringing down its recommendations, do anything particularly constructive? No, its main emphasis was on cutting numbers. Then it moved in. One of its recommendations was to cut the staff numbers in the Australian Taxation Office. Of course, one year later the poor old Taxation Office is copping the blame for not telling the Treasurer (Mr Howard) about the tax avoidance and evasion schemes. However, one year ago the Taxation Office was told to cut down its numbers. Of course, a few months after that the Government realised that it had made a mistake and the numbers in the Taxation Office were reinstated.
How many people are really needed to keep reviewing the Board? In the Prime Minister's statement this morning he said:
The Review in particular should take into account--

Let us just look at some of these issues that the Review of Commonwealth Administration will take into account, and maybe with my assistance we can get this review over with in one day. The Prime Minister continued:
The need for the Public Service to have high standards and good morale;

I think we can solve that by having a few positive statements about the Public Service, by constructive leadership of the Public Service, especially from the Ministers and from the Prime Minister. The next items which the Review should take into account are:

The need for the Public Service to provide the professional managerial component of public administration; the need for the Public Service to possess management skills and to develop management structures . . .

The Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts has just spent the last nine months looking at this question. I am a member of that Committee. It will be bringing down its report to this chamber in a few weeks. Its recommendations deal specifically with this issue. The Committee looked specifically at the training of senior managers in the Public Service. We had submissions from every department. We had submissions from the Public Service Board and also from the private sector. Some of the information from the private sector was very interesting. Many members of the private sector made the point that one just cannot carry over the standards of management of the private sector to the public sector. Yet we notice that all the members of this new inquiry have private sector experience. What do they really know about the Public Service? In fact, I would much prefer to have the Vice-President of the Executive Council ( Sir James Killen), who is sitting here in front of me today, as a member of that inquiry instead of these people just from the private sector.

What we need in the Public Service is a change in attitude-not just a change in attitude of our public servants, rather a change in attitude by every member of this Parliament, especially members of this Government. We need to stop criticising public servants every time we open our mouths. We need to do something constructive in terms of their salaries. Sure, we need to look at management structures, but that is already under way. There is absolutely no point at all in having a further inquiry. Why was the Government not very frank when it made its statement this morning? Instead of giving us six pages of justification for this new review the Government should have simply said: 'Look, the public servants are going to be made the scapegoats once again for our faults and our deficiencies. It is popular throughout Australia to lampoon the Public Service, to criticise the Public Service. Let us hope we can pick up some electoral advantage by blaming the Public Service for our mistakes'.

TALK.START.PARA: —As no other honourable member has risen, the honourable member for Canberra may speak a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members. Some of the areas that this Government could give its attention to relate very much to the Public Service Board's annual report. The Public Service Board, in fact, is supposed to do the job that has been set out as the role of this new, special, three-man team which is now supposed to be conducting the fourth Fraser review into the Public Service. This is the body that is supposed to be looking at the management techniques and morale of the Public Service.The real problem is that the Public Service Board has not been able to do that because it has had to confine all its attention to looking at staff ceilings. The Board, in fact, instead of having a support role in the Public Service has taken on the role of being really a sort of enemy, the arm of the Government, there just to implement Government policies, not to be supportive.

SPEECH.PARA: One way in which I think we could constructively change the role of the Public Service Board would be by taking away from the Public Service Board its role in determining staff ceilings. I believe that there is considerable duplication in the Public Service Board looking at staff ceilings. I believe that functions to a great extent is currently carried out anyway by the Department of Finance. I would much prefer to see a system whereby the Department of Finance took sole responsibility for staff numbers in the Public Service and linked them specifically to money. I think it is a crazy system that we have today when, under staff ceilings, we see reductions not in the Third Division or the Second Division but in the Fourth Division of the Public Service. I think that in the future we should see staff numbers in the Public Service linked with salary budgets for each department. In that way there could be much greater flexibility in how each department is staffed.

A second way of improving morale within the Public Service would be for departmental heads to have more flexibility in staffing the Second Division. I think that if we were to break down some of those strict structures in the Second Division we would then see greater flexibility on the part of the departmental heads. Departmental heads might be able to manage their departments instead of having to be consistently involved in Public Service procedures in relationships with the Public Service Board. These are just two measures that I think would loosen up the Public Service management structures, making the Public Service more responsive to the community. Thirdly, I think that we must do much more for the upper levels of the Third Division. It is necessary to identify people who are potential departmental heads. They need to be encouraged . They need to be given a balanced development.

Many of these matters will be dealt with in very great detail by a report of the Public Accounts Committee which, as I foreshadowed, will be tabled in this chamber in a few weeks. I think this highlights the fact that so many of these issues have been examined and overexamined. The time has come now to stop just talking about what is wrong with the Public Service or what can be done in the Public Service. Let us do something about making our Public Service more responsive to the government arm. More importantly, let us do that in a constructive way and not use the Public Service as a scapegoat for government maladministration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of the Vice-President of the Executive Council are departments of some stark contrasts. One is a department in name and the other is a department which has very extensive responsibilities in relation to the management and leadership of the country, and the provision of co-ordinating and structural support to the Government and to the people of Australia. Unfortunately leadership is totally lacking in this country at the moment. It is lacking to such an extent that Australia is in a time of crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a period in which there is need for example to be set and leadership provided. Unfortunately that is neither forthcoming nor capable of being given by the present administrator of one of these departments, namely, the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Malcolm Fraser). He is a person whose political activities basically have division as their foundation. He promotes division. He exploits situations to the disadvantage of others and provides an example of leadership which is to the disadvantage of the nation. His example is certainly not what Australians collectively wish to do or to be seen to be doing. Occasionally good speeches are made about the need for Australians to pull together. There is a massive Government public relations unit which serves the Prime Minister. Unfortunately none of those resources can have credibility or any degree of efficiency or competence while the leadership is devoid of that credibility, and deservingly so.

This is unfortunate at a time when many Australians are suffering from burdens which they believe are unfair. Whilst it is easy for an honourable member in this House to stand up and talk about disposable incomes being increased at a rate greater than the inflation rate I suggest that that honourable member would not find many people who work for wages in this community being included in the real levels of average wages in the community as distinct from those stated by the statisticians. Some 70 per cent of people receive less than the average wage . I am sure the honourable member who makes that point will not find much support amongst those people when he states that they are now able as a result of a combination of salary increases and inflation to purchase more goods this year than last. That is humbug. It may be statistically provable, but it is not true. It is a truism that statistics lie. It is certainly not provable that those people in the lower income groups in this community as a result of the leadership-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I reluctantly interrupt the honourable member for Corio but he has not yet persuaded me that he is sufficiently relevant to the question before the House.

—Mr Chairman, I make the point that the Government speaker spoke totally about the economic circumstances of the country. I am in fact referring to the speech made by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman).
—The Chair does not dispute that circumstance. I was not in the chair at the time that that speech was allegedly made. The Chair is still obliged to adhere to its own view.

—I merely say that one would think that as the Prime Minister is the person responsible for the estimates which are ultimately provided for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet it is reasonable, in dealing with the estimates and the expenditures of his Department, also to deal with the activities of the person who makes those judgments and determines how the funds will be spent, squandered or otherwise, and the effect that that expenditure will have on the community at large. That Department is led, at least notionally , by the Prime Minister who is the senior political figure in this country. He is the person whom we would expect to provide leadership but who fails to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw attention to certain expenditures not included in the estimates of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, but spread throughout other departments. These expenditures should, but do not, appear in the estimates of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet because they are for purposes such as overseas trips. I am not arguing either for or against that expenditure. I am merely saying that it is not properly reflected in the departmental estimates. It has been the Prime Minister's practice in the past to compare the estimates of former Prime Ministers in these areas with the estimates and moneys provided for his own Department, where they are not comparable.

I suggest that there is an enormous public relations organisation which is now responsible to and operated by the Prime Minister and which has some of the highest salaries available anywhere in the community. This is occurring at a time when the Government talks about restraint and the need for minimising expenditure. The whole of that operation is not for the purpose of advancing the work of the Government of Australia but is for the purely political purpose of advancing the interests of a political party or a political group. That is not a proper expenditure of funds. It is not an expenditure of funds which appears under its proper category in the Estimates before this Parliament. Australia is in a state of crisis. On so many occasions we have seen campaigns mounted with public funds in order to mislead the Australian people. These funds have been provided out of Budgets and Estimates and put into operation by an enormous public relations organisation which is sponsored and funded under the Prime Minister's Department.

I wish to make one other point in relation to the Government's treatment of public servants. This is very specifically within this area. Over a period of time there has been a massive assault on the credibility and honesty of public servants in Australia by members of this Government. They have never failed to use public servants as a whipping boy and Aunt Sally for their own political purposes. They are now seeking to blame public servants for their own lack of credibility and responsibility. The Prime Minister recently said that senior public servants should be satisfied with a certain level of salary. I do not dispute the accuracy or otherwise of that statement. The level is certainly less than that which would have been assessed by a tribunal operating freely and not under political pressure.

Recently in this House we were told that a person would be appointed to act as a special prosecutor. I ask honourable members to remember that the levels of salary recommended by the Prime Minister for his senior public servants apply to such persons as the Solicitor-General, who is said to be the senior Public Service law officer in the land. No person could have been obtained for the position of a special prosecutor at the level of salary paid to our most senior and therefore most responsible public servants. That could suggest that the Government is prepared to misuse the capabilities and values of the Public Service but when it needs someone to cover up or to get it off the political hook it finds it necessary to pay considerable greater salaries to attract someone from outside. I suggest that if the Government wants a competent administrative structure in this country it should provide leadership and give support to the Public Service. It should not seek to pass blame from itself to the Public Service.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Department of Foreign Affairs
Proposed expenditure, $818,642,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are now debating the estimates of the Department of Foreign Affairs outside a question and answer situation, I think we will have to cover more of the general ground. The Senate appears to have the opportunity to ask detailed questions on expenditure. At the outset, I appreciate the difficulties that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) has in this area because it seems to be an area where everybody else will take the ground from him if they think that is the way to attract public attention, not least amongst those people being the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). In fact a number of areas of our foreign policy and foreign representations come under the Prime Minister's wing. On matters such as nuclear safeguards which come within the responsibility of the Department of Foreign Affairs, in my view- no doubt he will not agree with me-the Minister is overshadowed by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) who looks after overseas trade. In other words, the National Country Party takes a very keen interest in such matters. Yesterday, the Leader of the National Country Party (Mr Anthony), as Deputy Prime Minister, made a strong attack on the Australian Labor Party's uranium policy, and that was immediately followed by what was deemed to be a supportive statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on nuclear safeguards. How counter-productive that is.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Prime Minister with his persuasive powers is able to sell uranium to Finland knowing full well that it will be enriched and perhaps reprocessed in the Soviet Union. I wonder how that squares with the stance of the Government on other matters in relation to the Soviet Union? We have virtually boycotted the Soviet Union in a number of areas-quite fairly in relation to its invasion of Afghanistan-but it is a bit ridiculus to talk about trade in such a sensitive area as uranium enrichment and reprocessing and perhaps at another level to suggest that it would be wrong for our athletes and swimmers to compete in the Moscow Olympic Games. I think this question of where we stand in relation to such policies brings us into much disrepute.

I put it again to the Government that it is about time that Australia had a foreign policy which represented the aspirations and views of the Australian people. Quite clearly, by a majority the Australian people felt that we should have participated in the Moscow Olympic Games. It had nothing to do with the politics of the Soviet Union. International sporting arrangements do not have anything to do with politics. So, why did we politicise them? It was done because apparently President Carter of the United States felt that that was the way to go. I think this is the problem that I find as spokesman for the Opposition in trying to identify the role that Australia sees for itself. Its role is certainly not to follow what Presidents of the United States do because they do many things and there are many presidents.

The significant thing about the Fraser Government is that it religiously follows whatever the foreign policy of the United States may be, which is not always the policy which suits us. It does little for us to have in Moscow an ambassador whose hands are tied because our policy is virtually one of opposition to the Soviet Union. Our ambassador in Hanoi is in a hopeless position when our policy is not to give Vietnam any aid. Is that in our interest ? Do we really gain any credit from China or from anywhere else by suggesting that we will be as hostile to Vietnam as the United States wants us to be?

If that sort of consideration is to dominate our foreign policy, which in turn- in all fairness to the Minister-is dominated by the Prime Minister, should we not look at what is happening in the Department. More than 1,000 people are employed in the Department of Foreign Affairs, at a cost to the taxpayer of $25m . They expect a fair result and would get it were the Department given some strength and initiative.

I do not believe that I would be wrong to raise an article by Teresa Mannix which appeared recently in the Canberra Times. It stated that there was widespread unease about the effectiveness of the Foreign Affairs Department. The officers in that Department were so concerned about their career prospects that they wrote to the Secretary to the Department. They alleged that up to 20 per cent of ambassadors are not sufficiently competent to hold their jobs and that the speeches delivered by the Minister were sometimes lacking in vision. I agree with that, but I always thought that was due to the Minister and not to his speech writers. I am not being personal when I say that; I understand that he has a blinkered position because of the dominance of either United States policy or the Prime Minister.

Above all, the plea of Foreign Affairs employees to their own departmental head is that they want to work for a strong, sure and efficient department led by officers whom they are able to respect. I will not say any more about that view of the staff of the Foreign Affairs Department. I have no doubt that there is an answer to it. It is fairly significant in that they know full well that they have not been able to get the best out of their Department because it is superimposed by some other area. In the nuclear area it is superimposed by the National Country Party's dominance of trade. Certainly Australia's international policy seems to be devoid of any initiative because of having to be subservient, whether to the United States or somebody else.

Let us look at the problems that we are now facing. In my view, and in the view of the Opposition, it was never in our interests to commit ourselves to United States policy in the Middle East without a guarantee that there would be some solution to the Palestinian problem. Everybody is quite fairly and properly saying that the massacre of innocent women and children in Palestinian camps is dreadful, the most recent one being a few days ago in West Beirut. As the Minister knows, I made representations to him about a massacre on or about 2 July in another camp when allegedly large numbers of women and children were killed. That information came from World Vision in Australia. I think the sources were reasonable and rational. The man who made the submission to me had been there. He said that he thought there was something genocidal about the way the attacks were always on the refugee camps of the Palestinians because allegedly that was where the arms may have been.

In our view, the invasion of Lebanon cannot be pardoned at all, never mind the invasion of West Beirut. To go into Lebanon was wrong. Nobody has done anything about it except wring their hands and say how dreadful it is. I was swayed when I heard a Muslim Lebanese person saying what a dreadful thing it was for the people of the United States to have to acknowledge that all the deaths of the women and children were due to United States armaments. He asked: 'Would it not give them a sense of conscience?' He is right. The point about the Middle East policy is: Why are we always so reluctant to criticise? In my view, the best the Prime Minister could offer was to think that the only thing for the Israelis to do was to invade Lebanon. We really want to see Israel in peace as an independent state, but it will not be able to do that unless it solves the Palestinian problem. What about an Australian initiative? We were so subservient that we committed troops to a Sinai peacekeeping force, and ever since we made the commitment there has been nothing but war in that area.
