It was very clear that if Begin's southern flank were safeguarded he would invade Lebanon. The United States knew that. Everybody here expected that. Begin does not always represent the best interests of Israel. Perhaps the sooner he goes the better it will be. But how important it would have been for an Australian Foreign Minister to say to the United States: 'In the interests of peace in the Middle East, we do not think that we should agree with your short-sighted view'. That is just a sample of what happens if the Government does not understand what its own nation wants. The majority of Australians deplore the massacres and deplore war. They would offer a peacekeeping force that would guarantee the Palestinians an independent homeland on the West Bank in accordance with the Camp David provisions. But that will never happen. All we read about is the misery and the difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKenzie Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to make a few comments and observations about my recent visit to Israel, which included a period of less than a day in Lebanon. This took place in June during the recess. I had not been to Israel before. I had not really had an all-consuming interest in that country , although I had an inquisitiveness about it. I thought I would take the opportunity of visiting that country, and as it turned out my visit occurred shortly after the Israeli defence forces moved into Lebanon. The Australian Government contributes to the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon-UNIFIL-and to one other peacekeeping force in the area, in the Sinai. The latter contribution is a very real one in terms of manpower and equipment, whereas the UNIFIL contribution is one of funding.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is appropriate to re-examine our commitment to some of these peacekeeping forces. In my view, UNIFIL fell down in two areas. Firstly, the Palestine Liberation Organisation and its sympathisers continued to shell northern villages in Israel and to undertake terrorist activities despite the UNIFIL presence. That must have aggravated the Israelis to the point where they felt justified in moving into Lebanon. The second point about UNFIL is that the Israelis, having taken that decision, virtually ignored what establishments there were in the UNIFIL area. The world media produced a considerable amount of pictorial evidence that the Israelis had just swept past the UNIFIL lines. I think it was only one small contingent of Nepalese that in any way attempted to lodge an objection to their moving through. I think the Australian Government should examine the effectiveness of some of the forces that it contributes to.

I must say, as a first time visitor to Israel, that I was enormously impressed with the case that it has, just on pure geographical considerations. When one stands on the edge of the Golan Heights looking into the northern villages of Galilee and across to the Christian occupied area of Lebanon one realises what an extraordinarily short distance is involved. One has to see to believe that there are bomb shelters within virtually a few metres-walking distance-of every kibbutz, every settlement. Around the pre-schools I saw bomb shelters that had been set up to enable the children to continue their kindergarten and school education irrespective of the bombs and rockets falling. I would suggest to anybody who has not been to the area and who is interested in the question that he visit Israel if given the opportunity to see how difficult the situation must have been, particularly in the northern area. I can certainly understand the Israelis not wishing to give up the Golan Heights for purely strategic reasons. There is, of course, another force on the border there. When I visited the border area of the Golan Heights and Syria I was again struck by the outward appearance of ineffectiveness of what I think is merely an observer force.

My visit to Lebanon was not predictable. It was suddenly made possible by the IDF at very short notice. It was interesting that many of the claims made by the people I talked to in Israel-in the government, in the defence forces and in the foreign affairs area-certainly appeared to me to be confirmed. They claimed, of course, that they had made every effort to be extremely selective as to the targets that they moved in on. I visited the town of Nabatiyet. One could see with one's own eyes that the Israelis had been selective, to the point where one would find one shop front that had been completely annihilated and yet two shops away one would find a new installation of plate glass, still with the paper crosses on it to indicate that it was new glass, that had been untouched. I was there literally only 48 hours after the Israelis moved through. Inevitably some civilian targets become subject to damage. There was the odd hit on schools and hospitals but I must say that from what I saw it was borne out to me that the IDF had made every effort to concentrate on known PLO positions. There had not been-certainly in that instance-indiscriminate shelling or selection of target areas.

Likewise in visiting Beaufort Castle I got a very good appreciation of the strategic advantage that the PLO had in that area. It could launch rockets well over the Christian controlled area of Lebanon into the northern Galilean villages. Again one had to ask: What is the point of a United Nations involvement there when such a force was either incapable of preventing this sort of action by the PLO or felt disinclined to make an issue of it?

I also visited a very interesting gentleman on the recommendation of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). I refer to Mayor Freij of Bethlehem. Whilst some people said that the Israelis would not be very enthusiastic about my talking to Mayor Freij, that was certainly not the case. The Israelis were quite happy to arrange the visit if necessary, to take me there and to bring me back again. Mayor Freij is a very sensible, rational, moderate Palestinian. He is the elected Mayor of Bethlehem. On the day on which I visited him he was having a meeting with other West Bank mayors. Their attitude towards the invasion of Lebanon, whilst critical of it, was that it was somewhat inevitable given the situation that Israel had been put in and given the postering and the position that was being taken by Prime Minister Begin. Indeed, it was Mayor Freij who told me that he had recommended to Arafat that he should withdraw from Beirut. I point out that that was in the very early days of the invasion of Lebanon-some four or five days or perhaps a week after the initial action had been taken.

Israel must recognise that the Palestinian problem of finding a homeland must be reconciled. I do not believe that it is realistic for the Israelis to continue making excuses, to say that the Palestinians should be accepted by Jordan. To my mind there must inevitably be some sort of accommodation for the Palestinians on the West Bank. I do not believe that that is necessarily a position of weakness; I think it is just a fact of life that the Palestinian problem will not go away. There are moderate people in the West Bank-sensible people, non-extremists, people who are not interested in being in any way associated with the PLO or its activities-who I imagine could be consulted and with whom meaningful negotiations could occur about a homeland in that area.

I conclude by saying that the commitment of the Government and, indeed, of Australia to United Nations forces should be carefully examined. I do not think they should be taken lightly. I think the effectiveness of the forces-I refer again to UNIFIL-should be assessed very carefully before our commitment is either undertaken or necessarily continued.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to respond to remarks made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie) and also to make one or two points about an aspect of the estimates which relates to our United Nations delegation and our participation in arms control discussions. I will deal first with the question raised by the honourable member for Calare. I was very disappointed by a number of things he had to say about his visit to Israel and I will refer to them in a minute. But first of all, my specific criticism relates to remarks he made in connection with the Golan Heights.

SPEECH.PARA: I, like the honourable member, had the opportunity to visit Israel this year with a number of parliamentary colleagues, and, like the honourable member, I appreciated the assistance given to us by the Department of Foreign Affairs and also by the Israeli authorities. I agree with the honourable member in respect of some of the general propositions he made about the nature of Israel's security problems. I think however that a somewhat different perspective is required, particularly at this time. I was very concerned to hear the honourable member say that during the course of his visit he had gone to the Golan Heights. In Israel, travelling not as a member of any formal parliamentary delegation but as individual members of parliament, we had put to us very strongly that the Department of Foreign Affairs and by implication, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street), was most concerned that Australian politicians visiting Israel should appear to give de facto recognition to the seizure and incorporation of the Golan Heights which took place a few months earlier, in the latter stages of last year. This position was quite correctly strongly opposed by this Minister for Foreign Affairs. We studiously avoided invitations to go on to Golan Heights. We were perfectly well aware of their strategic significance to Israel. We did not actually need to go on to them to see that, and I am a little disappointed that the honourable member did that. I am also disappointed that he went to Lebanon. A similar offer was made to us and we were quite firmly of the view that one does not visit other people's countries unless one does it through the normal channels. A member of parliament does not do something in another country of a semi-official nature unless one has an invitation to do so. I was disappointed with his remarks on those two grounds.

I do not think one is any real friend of Israel these days if one is consistently reminding the Israelis of their difficult strategic geography. The Israelis really need an alternative perspective on where their security lies, and one or two other points need to be made to them. One of those points is that the Israeli Government presides over the fourth most effective armed force in the world. Israel's neighbours are nowhere near it on the list of effective armed services. For all practical purposes Israel can put more planes into the air at 24 hours' notice than can the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries in Europe. When we consider the incapable nature of the armed forces of countries around Israel, irrespective of the difficulties with early warning that the Israelis have, that is a very formidable capability indeed. What is required more than ever is that the people who consider themselves to be Israel' s friends start to point out quite clearly to Israel that Israel is and has been for some time perfectly secure within the region. What is now necessary from Israel's point of view is no longer the pursuit of political solutions by military means but the pursuit of a final and conclusive peace in the area by the astute efforts of Israeli diplomats exercising a degree of goodwill towards their neighbours. I regret that the honourable member for Calare-this is evident from the remarks he made here-did not point out those facts to Israel while he was there.

In Israel there is an increasingly receptive attitude to that point of view. I think that politicians who visit Israel and who share the view of the honourable member for Calare-certainly it is my own view-that Israel has a perfect right to exist within secure and recognised boundaries in that region and that its neighbours ought to recognise it, will agree that that is no longer seriously under challenge in any military way and that what is necessary for the peace of mind of Israel in the long term is a more generous attitude towards its neighbours. In this regard I congratulate the Minister on changes in his policy, even though in the last few months I have criticised some aspects of the way in which his policy has developed. In particular instances I do not think he has been fast enough off the mark with constructive suggestions, but I congratulate him for shifting Australian policy in the direction of a rational solution of Middle Eastern affairs and exercising a preparedness-evidently in the face of some abuse-to pursue this objective. I hope that he will not be put off by any gestures of contempt, of calumny or whatever, that are heaped upon his head. I think that the views which countries like Australia may put forward to the Israelis at this time-no matter what may be said in return to them publicly-in the long term will have some impact if not on their policy makers, then on their domestic political processes.

The second point I raise in relation to the estimates relates to arms control arrangements and Australian participation in arms control discussions, particularly Australia's role at the last United Nations General Assembly which discussed the matter. I have not yet seen an official report of our participation in those discussions, but it would appear that in a number of areas Australia was again obliged to press a viewpoint on to its principal ally. We were at variance in relation to nuclear test bans. I will be very interested to see whether that position was as effectively and strongly pressed as it has been in the past. The Minister may like to address himself to that point if he speaks later in this debate.

As I have mentioned before in this House, we have the certain knowledge in this country that nuclear test ban agreements can be verified. We have the capability within our own scientific establishments and resources to verify those agreements. We have pointed out that fact to the United States, to the Soviet Union and to other parties with a direct interest in the question of whether test bans are negotiated. We have also indicated this to those who have, to this point at least, tended to ignore or deny the fact that test bans are thoroughly verifiable. I very much hope that we pressed that point strongly again this year . That is only a small step, admittedly, but it is a very important step in the area of arms control.

The Minister made a statement in the House yesterday on another area of arms control related to the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Rather than see a Minister come into the House and deliver what effectively was a cheerio speech for the non-proliferation treaty, what it has achieved and Australia's role in relation to it, it would be nice to see a Minister come into this House and state in detail Australia's objective in international arms control arrangements and indicate the weaknesses in such international arms control agreements. The non-proliferation treaty, a fine concept though it is and as effective as it has been in some cases, nevertheless has very glaring weaknesses which will become much more significant in the near future. Over the next decade we will find that a substantial number of non-nuclear powers in sensitive areas will become nuclear powers. We must resist that, particularly any such developments related to any area of the Middle East. What we would like to see is evidence from this Government that it takes its obligations in the arms control area seriously, not just to the point of agreeing with the provisions of those agreements that are already in place, by taking initiatives to strengthen those agreements to make them more effective. It would be a source of considerable comfort to people in this country, and I think a source of considerable relief to a large number of people in the international community. I can think of no better way of expending a substantial proportion of our Department of Foreign Affairs estimates than in that endeavour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Australia moves closer to its south-eastern neighbour, New Zealand, through the Closer Economic Relations Scheme, following the successful New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement, I believe it is proper to remind the House of the very close association that the nation of Australia has had over many decades with the independent nation of Papua New Guinea. The success of this association between these two countries has been well documented in the past and I will not dwell upon it except to note that we do not now debate Papua New Guinea as we used to under the estimates of the Department of External Territories but we do so under the estimates of the Department of Foreign Affairs. This transfer of sovereignty was achieved with enormous good will between the two parties. People on both sides of this Parliament have played important roles in their own fashion, including I might say Prime Minister Whitlam in his thrusting fashion and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who developed such a close relationship with Michael Somare and his Cabinet. I was privileged to represent Speaker Aston at the opening of Papua New Guinea's first Parliament-an occasion I will not forget. My interest in Papua New Guinea goes back to early 1943 when I arrived at Port Moresby as a very young fighter pilot. Subsequently I flew from the Trobriand Islands, Nadzab, just out of Lae in the Marbham Valley, Cape Gloucester in New Britain, Tadji or Aitape and Hollandia, now in West Irian. I mention these areas because naturally over the last 20 years I have tended to return to see for myself the exciting developments that have taken place in areas that I knew so well. Over many years I have visited, for instance, the oil palm projects at Talasea and Cape Hosking-because I used to strafe those areas. I visited coffee and tea plantations and saw how they developed on the highlands and elsewhere. I visited cattle projects in the Markham Valley. These are just some of the examples.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make the point that today the younger generation of members of parliament, in their excitement to visit other countries on credits provided by this Parliament, tend to overfly small and important nations such as Papua New Guinea. I am perturbed that the new generation of members in Federal Parliament will not give attention to our very important neighbour. A quick look at our overseas aid program will show that many years ago 50 per cent of our overseas aid program was aimed at Papua New Guinea, and rightly so, as we helped it towards some form of economic independence. The World Bank program and its finance helped to produce rational development programs for that nation as did, for some years, financial agreements with Bougainville Copper Mines. Of course, in real terms the latter is not now donating the same proportion of funds to the Papua New Guinea economy. Today's proportion of our overseas aid to that country is probably somewhat less than 40 per cent, for good reasons which I will explain later. Obviously we expect an increase in Papua New Guinea's capacity to raise internal revenue to take up some of its total expenditure program.

How many honourable members in this chamber today would know whether the sum of $253m net bilateral aid last year-or an estimate of $264m of our aid in 1982-83- is warranted? In my opinion it is. No doubt the Department of Foreign Affairs, through our High Commission in Papua New Guinea, would say roughly the same thing. But is this chamber to be informed in the future on the progress of this important neighbour? During the 1960s and the early 1970s under the control of a previous member of parliament for the seat of North Sydney, et al, Mr Bruce Graham, groups of us returned to Papua New Guinea each Anzac Day. Originally the team of six split between Rabaul and Port Moresby after dawn services and we remained for a week to look at the development of that new nation, particularly the development in rural areas. Many of the areas we visited in those days were quite new, such as the higher rainfall areas of Mt Hagen. Each year, by repeated visits, we were able to comprehend change and more clearly see differences. A great many Australian members of parliament were able to see in those days how our aid, pumped directly into Papua New Guinea's consolidated revenue and not individually allocated to publicity seeking schemes as so frequently can be seen in other developing nations without much dovetailed planning, was successfully utilised. It perturbs me that today so few of the members of this chamber have any idea of our neighbour's progress or its difficulties, nor have they any base for comparative purposes. I believe that the Government, in consultation with the Government of Papua New Guinea, should plan frequent trips to that nation so that this chamber does not lose an important contact with a friendly and important nation.

About four years ago Sir Julius Chan perceived just this problem. At that time he invited the Government parties rural committee to visit his nation. We gratefully accepted that invitation and after a week of looking at new development projects in that area-I might add that some new and younger members of parliament on this side of the chamber were with me on that occasion-we were privileged to have a debriefing session with many officials around us before we left that nation. We discussed the difficulties of raising taxation revenue when so few of the areas had a cash economy. We discussed the repayment of World Bank Loans and other loans such as those granted by this nation. We discussed the problems and the pangs experienced by any new and developing nation.

All honourable members in this chamber have fond memories over many years of different aspects of our interests within Australia and around the world. But that debriefing session which we had in Papua New Guinea will stick in my mind for a long time to come if for no reason other than the sheer brilliance of the Prime Minister of that country at the time, Sir Julius Chan, of whom I have very fond memories and for whom I have great respect. How lucky it was for the development of that nation that when it obtained its independence its first Leader of the Opposition, that marvellous man Matt To Liman from New Britain, was so responsible and so friendly to people who came to view the problems of his country. Michael Somare was a marvellous Prime Minister in those early days. Indeed, the friendship between Michael Somare and Julius Chan assured a continuity of the democratic process so important to a developing nation where, let us face it, people in our language near enough to head hunters-people quite out of touch with their form of civilisation-were still discernible. Because of my very great interest in that area, which stretches over many years, I suggest seriously to the Government now, in case I do not have an occasion on which to do so in the future, that we must not lose the valuable contact that this nation has had with Papua New Guinea over many years.

Looking back, when I first entered this Parliament each year we could have a free trip to Papua New Guinea. Bear in mind that that country was under Australian sovereignty in those days and we could lay down such laws. Younger members of parliament went to Papua New Guinea during the winter recess imbued, no doubt, with the history of World War II. They watched that nation's development in those early days when I was a member of this Parliament. Those free tickets-if one can put it that way-do not apply any more. All honourable members, when they are able to go overseas, want to take advantage of their around the world air tickets. They want to go to Europe, to the Parliament of the European Economic Community or perhaps to South East Asia. But how many overfly Papua New Guinea on every occasion? I believe that this Parliament will be the worse if we lose the valuable contact that we have had with that nation over previous years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not talk for very long. The Opposition is not anxious to delay the time schedule. I just want to make a few comments about a general matter. I am prompted by what the previous speaker just said about New Guinea. My notes show that the present Prime Minister, Mr Michael Somare, is asking for budgetary aid support and wants it maintained at its present level which, I am told, is $253m for the next two years. He does not want it decreased-as I understand the Government may do-by 5 per cent in real terms. I understand that all that has been said is that there will be a mid-term review of that aid.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to support what the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) has just said about visits to New Guinea. I think it was very beneficial to be able to go there in those earlier days when we were first elected to this place. I think it is a shame that, apparently because of other developments, that has not been maintained. I think those visits were important and in our own interests. I want to support fully the honourable member for Wakefield in what he said. I would also like to mention that in those earlier days when we were in Opposition and about to take government there was an objection to the fact that one of our policies was to give independence to Papua New Guinea. I think the reason was that prior to that the territory had always been under the control of the National Country Party. It never seems to want to part with anything. I am happy to say that when my colleague, the present honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison), became the appropriate Minister, independence was granted. I am delighted to know that the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) is in the chamber. He carried on that task in a very excellent fashion indeed. I think that did great credit for Australia. It is rather significant that we can have immediate telephonic communications with Papua New Guinea, yet we do not seem to be able to have the visits, which we ought to try to maintain. So much for the question of aid.

Without trying to detract in any way from those essential remarks, and leaving aside Papua New Guinea, I wonder what is happening to aid programs. I really think that we have to do something about the matter in a number of ways, not the least of which is, for example, connected with the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. Fifty non-government agencies are dividing limited funds. I also mention the International Planned Parenthood Federation. We contribute to four separate population control programs. We give different sums of money. I wonder whether we could not put the money in one direction rather than trying to spread it simply because those other organisations exist. Should we conduct some review of what we do with our aid? At present we support 33 multilateral programs. It seems that we have a shot gun arrangement to try to guarantee that at least some of the money lands in the right place.

The other matters I am anxious to mention, which I also did yesterday, relate to Vietnam. I think it is important to regional stability that we talk about aid to the people of Vietnam. They need it, they are entitled to it and they certainly qualify for it. In the early part of the week we were discussing the Asian Development Bank. Again, Vietnam has been prevented from getting aid to which it is entitled. That is quite counterproductive. I reiterate that it just drives the Vietnamese into the arms of the Soviet Union. I understand that Prince Sihanouk is going to visit Australia in the next couple of months. We do not mind his making that visit. But if it is made on the basis that he effectively represents the Khmer people, I very much doubt-

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it would be in a private capacity.

—Nevertheless, there has already been a suggestion of a tripartite coalition to represent the legitimate aspirations of the Khmers. I very much doubt it. While recognising that Sihanouk was around in the time of Pol Pot, he could not do very much; in fact he was a prisoner. In my view, after discussing matters with the people in the refugee camps, I found he does not any longer have the support of the people. It is wrong and counterproductive to be suggesting that we are helping in any way Kampuchea, good future relationships, or the withdrawal of the Vietnamese Army from Kampuchea, by suggesting that there be some coalition including the Pol Pot regime. That is a genocidal regime which is not entitled to any support at all. Honourable members should bear in mind that two Australians were murdered by that regime. I think it is important that we get our priorities right. If we are to invite Sihanouk that is fine, but I think at the same time it might be helpful if we arranged a visit from Nguyen Lo Thach, the Foreign Minister of Vietnam, even on a private basis, if the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) wants to put it that way. The issue is of importance to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I like to think when we are talking about this matter that we should emphasise the responsibility we in Australia have in our own region. The matter certainly relates to Papua New Guinea first and foremost. It certainly relates to South East Asia and to the Pacific Basin communities. In the law of the sea and other essential matters we are able-and I want to see this continue-to develop leadership potential; we should not follow somebody else's view. I think we should also be talking about joining the Latin American Development Bank. Despite some of the problems there might be with regimes in Latin America, there is an opportunity across the Pacific to develop effective trade and investment. I think there is a potential in that area for our commerce. With those few comments I urge the Minister to take those remarks on board to guarantee that when we are discussing these important matters in future we can have more bipartisanship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to make some comments on the speeches made by each honourable member participating in this debate. First of all I would like to refer to a couple of points made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his first intervention. I will come to his second intervention later. I would like to assure him and the Committee that Australia's foreign policy is determined in Australia for Australians. It is not subservient to anyone. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition seems to return continually in this context to his anti-United States theme. Unfortunately that is a constant thread which seems to run through his comments on foreign affairs. There is a basic difference between being a consistent and reliable ally and being a subservient one. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition cannot bring himself or his Party to recognise or accept the difference. I think that is a great pity for the sake of Australia and her friends.

SPEECH.PARA: The other main point made by the Deputy Leader in his first intervention related to criticism of Australian participation in the Sinai Multinational Force and Observers. The fact is that the Egypt-Israel peace treaty is the outstanding achievement in the Middle East in recent years. It was crucially dependent on the return of the Sinai to Egypt. I assure the Committee and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that that plainly would not have happened without the Sinai Multinational Force and Observers being established. The greatest risk to the Egypt-Israeli peace treaty would be the collapse of the Sinai MFO. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition really does the cause of peace in the Middle East no service by his approach.

I come now to the remarks of the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie) who referred particularly to the care needed in committing Australian forces to peacekeeping operations throughout the world. I agree with the honourable member in that respect. I assure him that this is done. I was interested also in his general comments on the Middle East, particularly in relation to the Palestinian problem. This theme was taken up again by the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley). I was interested too in the comments that he made. He and I have exchanged some correspondence on the same topic. This situation-even judging by the comments that have been made in this debate-is very near the top of the table when considering issues of current foreign affairs.

The honourable member made some comments about Australia's position in arms control. This is not the time to go into detail, but I draw the honourable member's attention to the statement that I made before the United Nations special session on disarmament a month or two ago. He mentioned particularly the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and the general problems relating to the spread of nuclear weapons. He urged initiating moves to strengthen agreements in that respect. I draw his attention to Australia's specific support by way of detailed programs in the International Atomic Energy Agency. Details of those specific projects are available in the Budget Papers or from my office.

The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) referred to Papua New Guinea. He also referred, in that respect, to the smooth transfer of sovereignty. There is a great deal of good will between the two countries. In that respect he paid tribute to my predecessor, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). I have much pleasure in doing that as well. It is true that Australian members of parliament visited Papua New Guinea in earlier times a great deal more frequently than they do now. He is correct in saying that this enabled them to assess the results of Australian support to that country. I agree with him that it is important for these links to be maintained. I join with him in urging all members of this Parliament, when they have an opportunity to do so, to visit Papua New Guinea. Such a journey may require some organisation, but my office and Department would be very happy to help any members of this House in any way in making a visit to Papua New Guinea easier and more productive.

I come to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition's second series of comments in relation to this debate. I take up the point that he raised about the recent request for aid by the Papua New Guinea Government. I thought that it might be useful for the House if I made clear the foundation on which aid is presently based. A report by Sir John Crawford established the base amount. The time of the agreement was to be five years and the terms were that, on the assumption that there would be an inflation rate of 10 per cent, there would be a reduction of 5 per cent in real terms each year in the amount of aid provided by Australia to Papua New Guinea. The Papua New Guinea Government has now asked that the review of that program, that was originally scheduled after 2 1/2 years for mid- term which is the middle of next year, should be brought forward. The Government is now looking at the possibility of doing that.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also referred to population control programs. I think he said that we contributed to four of them. It is true that there are many programs. The fact is that they are not common in the sense that they cover the same ground; they cover special ground. Whether one puts all one' s eggs in one basket, as the Deputy Leader seemed to suggest, or whether one tries to pick the programs which one believes have particular relevance in the circumstances for which they are designed and helps those programs with special characteristics is a difficult judgment to make. I accept it is a judgment that has to be made. There are many demands on Australian aid and we cannot fulfil all of them. Difficult decisions have to be made in relation to the ones that we do fulfil.

The honourable members also referred to the need for aid to Vietnam. I think there is a basic difference of opinion between the Opposition and the Government . The Deputy Leader and I, I am sure, know each other's minds pretty well on this matter. The fact is that the Government will not reward Vietnam for its invasion of Cambodia. As for the Cambodian coalition, we are encouraged by its establishment. We are not clear what effect the coalition will eventually have. We have made it clear that we will not support any coalition which turned out to be the old Khmer Rouge with another face on it, or which operated as a vehicle for the return of Pol Pot to power in Cambodia. Nevertheless it includes men who are recognised as genuine nationalists and genuine patriots of Cambodia in Prince Sihanouk and Mr Son Sann. They would be welcome, as I interjected across the table to the Deputy Leader, in Australia in their private capacity. In conclusion, I make it clear that representatives of the Khmer Rouge in that capacity would not be welcome.
