SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that members of this House have not had the opportunity to go through the procedures which existed in the past couple of years whereby a committee hearing was held on these expenditures and questions could be asked of the appropriate Minister and his officials. The then Minister for Defence last year chose not to bring his officials. Information on the actual expenditures, what is expected to be achieved and what was achieved by the expenditures in the defence area could be provided directly. It was a procedure which was developing and unfortunately it has been terminated. We are in a situation now where we are making short speeches which are likely to remain unanswered.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it should be made clear that, despite claims to the contrary, there has been a significant reduction in this year's Budget. The Government has claimed an increase in real terms in defence expenditure. It has also made some exaggerated claims in respect of areas of defence expenditure where it has claimed very substantial increases in funds have been made available.

I think that we should examine the total defence vote which has dropped in its share of Budget outlays from an actual expenditure last year of 10 per cent to 9 .8 per cent. When compared with the estimates for last year, it has dropped from 10.1 per cent of its estimated share of government outlays to 9.8 per cent. There is an even more significant drop if one takes into consideration wages and salaries. Adjustments were made to Defence Force pay and conditions which had not been made for some seven years. One would think that this would have caused serious problems in any sections of the community other than the Defence Force. As a result of Government policy, those increases were in fact absorbed into the defence vote in the appropriations last year. The result was that the non-salary section of defence expenditure was reduced substantially in actual terms. The area of defence expenditure devoted to other than the payment of salaries dropped from over 50 per cent to a figure slightly below 47 per cent of the total defence expenditure.

There are very serious problems for the Defence Force in the equipment area. I am not talking about big budget glamour items which seem to get the headlines and have a greater precedence in Government thinking than the realities of defence needs. I would think the basis of an Australian defence policy would be to provide, firstly, an adequate defence capacity for Australia. That is obviously not Government policy. Some of the suggestions which have been made since the Falklands conflict seem to indicate that as long as they are able to get headlines it does not matter how irresponsible they are. In one statement the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair)-he has made about 70 statements since he became Minister in May and I find it hard to find anything of substance in most of them-suggested that we might replace HMAS Melbourne by buying an obsolete American aircraft carrier, launched in 1945, which would absorb about half our defence equipment budget in one year merely to get it steaming, and steaming is the operative word as it is not a modern vessel. It is suggested that we use the F111s as aircraft to fly off the decks. I presume we use the Army as stokers and therefore we would have a very unitary Defence Force. That is about the height of Government policy in this area.

Serious deficiencies exist in much less glamourous areas of defence. Firstly, there is no Government policy on defence, no stated guidelines and nothing for the Defence Force planners on which to plan the development of the Defence Force or base its equipment requirements. Some very big budget items have been ordered in recent times. There have been massive deferments and a series of under- expenditures in equipment items since and including 1976. The 1976 White Paper on defence was substantive. The Opposition says it was a document which reflected a reasonable plan for Australian defence. At the time of its presentation to this Parliament it ceased to have any effect on Government defence policy or commitment. It was one of the typical announcements of defence policy which have come from conservative governments in this country. The policy was announced; a program was set out; certain basic requirements of the Defence Force were clearly spelt out and immediately forgotten. Three years after the five-year plan was supposed to have commenced there was an under-expenditure of over $1,500m. By the time the plan was replaced by the post-Afghanistan hysteria statements of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) it was two years behind; that is, two years behind after a four-year period.

The Afghanistan policy resulted in such statements as: 'We'll build 10 more Fremantle class destroyers. We'll do this; we'll do that'. The only thing that really came out of it was a massive advertising campaign and an increase in manpower in the reserves. It then came to a full stop. The Government forgot about it. It cut the defence vote again. It is now talking about the post- Falklands period. I think we ought to look at what the Falklands war taught us because the realities are that if Australia is placing itself in the position of learning defence lessons from one of the combatants in the Falklands war, it should see itself in the position of the defending nation and not the attacking nation. We are remote. Any country likely to attack us would be likely to undertake the same sort of exercise as the British did. We should examine the extent of the capabilities we would have to defend ourselves against a force similar to that which the British were able to put in the field. The main attributes of the British force were that it was highly professional and reasonably well equipped. Certainly it was not equipped to the most modern standards and the British had not provided adequate protection for their naval vessels. This fact also applies to this Government which, as a cost cutting measure, had decided prior to the Falklands crisis not to put defensive weapons on our FFG destroyers, thus making them totally vulnerable to any modern missile weapons system which could be carried by a relatively simple weapons platform. Because of the lessons of the Falklands crisis it has now been decided that that will be done.

What else have we decided? Are we going to buy a 1940s aircraft carrier? Are we going to put all our defence funds into Harriers? Is that a realistic assessment of Australia's defence needs when we have no surface to air missiles, no anti- tank weapons and inadequate transport capabilities within our Army? We have no early warning radar aircraft and tankers are still in the 'we're going to do it some day' category. Basic requirements of defence come before the big budget items. The follow-on destroyer program-half of our naval surface fleet in that area is subject to obsolescence in the next 10 to 15 years-is in limbo while the Government tries to find a way round having to comply with the recommendations of the Hawke Committee which it set up. It has decided to go to a half-way house . If the Minister for Defence reads the Hawke report-I hope he has-he will find it has said that on numerous occasions solutions were found and that the Department of Defence was good at finding solutions to the problems; its problem was that it could never implement them. Now another half-baked solution is being discussed rather than full implementation of a plan that has had come success. If the Government continues on its present path, we will be talking about building those destroyers when the present fleet is obsolete, long forgotten and gone to the breakers' yards.

This year, taking into account the under-estimated increases in wages, there is an actual increase in the non-wages section of the defence vote of 2 per cent. That represents a cut in real terms of about 6 to 7 per cent in the amount of money available for all expenditures on defence, including equipment, other than manpower.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address my remarks to a hearing that was conducted by the Sub-Committee which I have the privilege of chairing of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. First of all, I wish to comment on the effect that the decision of the Government as to whether it would buy HMS Invincible and now as to whether it will purchase an aircraft carrier will have on the funding of the defence forces generally. We must look at two alternatives . The first is the purchase of an aircraft carrier and the amount of funds that would be absorbed. If we do not go ahead with the purchase of the aircraft carrier, perhaps we will go back to some of the estimates of expenditure that we had previously.

SPEECH.PARA: The job of the Sub-Committee was somewhat unique insofar as it was based on a decision by the Senate that a term of reference be handed over to the Sub- Committee to examine closely and responsibly the desirability of the purchase of a new aircraft carrier to replace HMAS Melbourne. We considered that this was a term of reference with a difference as it was based on a decision of the Senate. We made every effort to create a balance in the sort of evidence that would come before the Sub-Committee. Let me explain the situation to the House and to the people throughout the nation who have found fit either to endorse what we have done or to criticise it somewhat harshly in one or two respects. I think that if I told the House the way in which we proceeded, then that would explain, perhaps a little more clearly, the way this Sub-Committee operates and the way it operated in relation to this matter. We felt that it was desirable, first of all , to obtain evidence at a very high level from those most involved-that is, the defence forces. Our first witness was a man who was about to retire or who perhaps had just retired as Chief of Defence Force Staff, Admiral Sir Anthony Synnot. We then called Air Marshal Sir Neville McNamara, Mr Pritchett and so on- people at the very high level. Their evidence was given, I think, honestly and with a degree of balance despite the fact that they have been associated with the decision to purchase HMS Invincible.

We then branched out into other fields. One witness who created a lot of interest was Air Vice Marshal Barnes. It is on one element of his evidence that I want to spend half a minute. He was quite critical of the role played and the actual capability of the Sea Harrier aircraft. He gave his evidence in a very forthright manner. He indicated that he considered that the Sea Harriers were not aircraft that played a very important role in the whole scheme of things generally. I am speaking personally now, not on behalf of my Sub-Committee. But I rather wonder, with hindsight, whether the Sub-Committee may have gained something by delaying the presentation of that report, perhaps, for another month. I put that proposition to the Sub-Committee members. They, in their wisdom-I was quite impressed by the arguments put forward-decided that there was not much to be gained by it, and perhaps there was not. I just rather wonder whether, if we had taken evidence based on at least preliminary reports of the Falklands experience, that might have influenced us but that is only that element of the report. I am not here to apologise at all for the report. I think it set out the position, as it was indicated to us, and as we evaluated the evidence which was received, I think at the very highest possible level, from people like Dr Bob O'Neill and so on. What I would say is this: There is the possibility that had we evaluated the evidence forthcoming from people who were involved, not only with the conduct of the Falklands conflict but also who actually participated in the Falklands conflict, then maybe the matter of the role of the Harriers may have been a little different. I would like to say that the Sub-Committee had no alternative but to come forward with the proposition that perhaps the purchase of the Invincible would have been of immense value. If one were a pro-aircraft carrier supporter it was a steal. Let me put the position quite frankly. But when one leaves that proposition and looks at the alternatives of, perhaps, paying for a fully armed aircraft carrier, with the aircraft that go with it, the radar systems and so on, then one could well be looking at $2 billion in expenditure. That would have meant that funds would have not been available for other very vital elements associated with the very difficult and complex defence of this country such as forward warning aircraft and so on.

The Sub-Committee examined the evidence very closely. We had a very eminent consultant in Commodore Gray, so it was not just precisely and entirely the opinion and evaluation of the Sub-Committee members, although I must say that each man on that Sub-Committee had had a good deal of experience and was not entirely new to the process of looking at a defence situation and evaluating matters of that nature which we considered.

The next matter I mention briefly is the matter of Norforce. I indicate to the Minister for Defence Support and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence (Mr Viner) that I, and I think many people who look at the defence of Australia from the point of view of the requirements of mobility and effective strike force, hope that Norforce eventually will develop into an operation of this nature. At the moment it is more or less an operation of patrol, surveillance and of using the abilities of people who know the area and who have the capacity to defend it realistically. I always have the concept in mind of this growing into a series of units or sub-units which would have the sort of mobility, strike force and adaptability which the Israeli forces had in earlier days and, let us face it, which the Vietnamese forces had. I refer to the capacity to know an area, to exploit it, to be sufficiently armed to defend it and to be readily available in a time of emergency to move quickly. I hope that the Government, in the course of time, will adopt as a principle the expansion of such a force.

I place on record the disappointment that I feel when I look at a concept of this nature, the requirements of defence in northern Australia and the vulnerability in a first impact situation in which we find ourselves in that area. I find it a little disappointing that we would decide to sell a camp such as the Sellheim Army camp. I rather wonder, if there were an emergency, and we wanted to set up a training area again, what we would do. Would we look for a new area? Would we just say: 'There are vast spaces; there is no damn problem there'. There is a problem. Sellheim Army camp served the forces of this country faithfully and well. Tomorrow the tenders close for its sale.

The only other thing I say is that I want to expose the activities of the Sub- Committee on Defence matters because I think it is a committee that works damned hard, has a great sense of responsibility and has an extremely bipartisan attitude towards things. I want, as I said, to expose its activities. We are going to embark now on our major term of reference and that is, to examine the situation as it exists, if I might get down to simplistic terms, in relation to the capacity to expand our training programs. We will inquire into where they go , how they should develop, where the deficiencies lie and so on. As a first move we will look at the Army. It has been somewhat neglected. I am sure that many of my Army friends who may hear my comments will know that we have not forgotten the Army. Today the Sub-Committee decided unanimously that it should embark on a very close scrutiny of the Army as it exists today and where we feel the deficiencies may lie. Time does not permit me to go further into these matters. I am rather conscious of the fact that this Sub-Committee plays an important part in the role of defence in this country. Our desire is to work with our defence forces and to be an addendum to what would be the normal channels of information available to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quickly enter this debate to again draw the attention of the House to what I believe is a matter of considerable concern -that is, the future of Australia's aircraft industry. In August this year I led a deputation which consisted of blue and white collar unions to a series of meetings in this Parliament with the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and with representatives of defence committees of all parliamentary parties. We spent some considerable time with the Minister for Defence Support and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence (Mr Viner).

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of our submission was to put to the Minister that the decision of the Australian Government to phase out the production of the Nomad aircraft and to discontinue its operation with a subsequent reduction in the very skilled work force in that industry could have a very severe impact on the future of the aircraft industry. What is contemplated is that there will be a reduction in staff in October this year of some 150 people. By 1984 there will be some 370 people lost to the aircraft industry. These are people with very specialised skills who in my view cannot afford to be lost. I have some sympathy with the argument advanced by the Minister that the Government found the finances involved in the future production of the Nomad excessive. The submission from the union delegation stated that there ought to be a continuation in production of some 20 aircraft-that is all that would be needed to keep the work force intact-while the Government rethought its position on the future of that industry. I have had a very lengthy three-page letter from the Minister. What concerns me is that nowhere in that correspondence does the Minister indicate that the decision to phase out the Nomad was taken on any grounds other than the financial problems involved in its production.

What I am concerned about is that if we are looking at Australia's total defence capacity we ought not to be making on such a basis important decisions about the future of an industry which has always been conceived by this Parliament- by all governments irrespective of their political complexion-as an industry which is absolutely essential to Australia's future defence capacity. I appreciate that there have been tremendous developments in the techniques and technology of aircraft production. What I am concerned about is that what is occurring in the aircraft industry is something like what is occurring in the automobile industry. Where we once had the capacity to produce a whole motor vehicle we now have an industry that produces part of a world car.

The tradition of the Australian aircraft industry is very fine. The industry has traditionally served this country well. It certainly did in the last war when it had the capacity to design and manufacture, and to see that our Air Force was equipped with, planes which served Australia in periods of armed conflict. I am concerned that if we reduce the overall level of skill and the state of the art in Australia we will face the situation where as a nation we will have the capacity to produce only part of an aircraft instead of being able to maintain what, in my view, is an important aspect of our defence industry, and what ought to be an important aspect for any government concerned to see that we have a defence manufacturing capacity capable of meeting any future defence contingency.

I come back to the initial problem by saying that the Government has had a scathing report from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which pointed out very serious deficiencies in the organisation and structure of the Government Aircraft Factories. To date there has been no response at all from the Government to the findings of that Committee. I would have thought that the very nature and terms of that report required a fairly immediate and important response from the Minister and the Government. More importantly, if what is being urged as a result of a very detailed examination of one major aspect of aircraft production is a major restructuring, I would not want to see that restructuring taking place just in terms of the isolation of the problems that beset Government Aircraft Factories. I would want to see any restructuring and reorganising of any aspect of our manufacturing industry in this vital area as part of a total thought through and well-considered Government strategy for the future of this industry. I suppose that is the essential thrust of my plea to the chamber on this occasion.

With great respect to the Minister, there is nothing in his letter to me to go to the unions which saw him which indicates that the decisions which have thus far been made were based on anything other than a fairly immediate short term response to financial problems. I can understand the pressures of that, but where is the strategy for the future of this industry? We now have a new Minister heading a new department concerned with defence manufacturing. Does the Minister see himself as having a role in terms of plotting the future strategy of defence manufacturing or does he see his role simply as sitting on and servicing the problems as they arise on a day to day basis? I believe that if Australia is to be self-reliant in defence esentially the emphasis and thrust of ideas within the Department of Defence, and this Government, and certainly within the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence-whatever view one might take of being part of a broad alliance-increasingly should be upon self- reliance in meeting any defence contingency.

Ultimately self-reliance means not a self-reliance in terms of our capacity to put aircraft into the air, to see that our Royal Australian Air Force personnel are highly trained and competent and there is no loss of training flying hours, but a continuing and thought through strategy about the capacity of our own manufacturing base to service those contingencies. I believe that the Government ought to review its attitude. I believe there should be no dismissals involving the very highly trained personnel at Government Aircraft Factories and I believe the Government should not merely respond to the Committee report in terms of the future of GAF. I would like to see a statement of strategy by the Minister for Defence, a strategy which involves some long term policy considerations. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the document relating to the submission made to the Minister by the deputation of unions.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Need for Visible Aerospace Industry
* The Aircraft Industry in Australia was set up not just primarily but solely for Defence purposes.
* We contend that this Government has to continue this vital need.
* We have had a clear undertaking from the Defence Sub-Committee of the ALP and Caucus Foreign Affairs Committee to continue this commitment.

* We declare that the present Federal Liberal/Country party government decision to slash the Nomad project to 150 aircraft will have a serious effect on the Industry from which it is unlikely it will recover.
* It is well known that the expertise that will be lost in retrenchment will from past experience be lost to the Industry forever.
We declare that the programme should be continued to manufacture another 20 nomads.
We believe that an aggressive selling policy should be adopted by the Federal government.
The report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts 198 proves that the management structure and sales policies adopted were a disaster.
The maximum subsidy for these 20 aircraft will be a small pittance when compared to subsidies payed out to many industries and large landholders.
On the part we are prepared to co-operate in a Joint Working party so that improved work efficiency, productivity, job practices, will in fact continue to make this industry viable and ongoing.
In addition an aggressive policy should be adopted in seeking suitable socially necessary alternative work for this Industry.
This will carry the Industry into the FA18 programme.
If this programme is adopted no retrenchments will need to take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In any defence debate it is surely necessary to define what we are trying to protect before trying to decide how we are going to protect it. Our first responsibility must be to protect Australia and its Territories, which include the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Islands, 1, 300 miles and 1,000 miles respectively from the Western Australian mainland. Our second responsibility and one which most commentators decline to acknowledge is to assist, where necessary, our friends, allies and neighbours in this part of the world. If nothing else, this responsibility is conferred on us by our participation in the ANZUS agreement as far as American and New Zealand interests and territories are concerned. It is important to recognise that our regional defence responsibilities are very real indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: It is this second responsibility, that regional responsibility, that many people have trouble in understanding. Since the end of the Vietnam war 10 years ago there has been a defence philosophy in this country that Australia should withdraw to fortress Australia and ignore what is happening in neighbouring countries and territories in the nearby Pacific and Indian Oceans. Such a philosophy is fraught with danger. It ignores the realities of life in some 30 countries and territories within 3,000 miles of our shores. It is naive to believe that what happens in Papua New Guinea, Timor and Indonesia, for example, is not of vital concern to Australia. It is also foolish to believe that our defence starts at Australia's shores because the reality is that the defence starts as far as practical from the ground to be defended. Thus, the further from Australia's shores that we can commence to inflict casualties on an enemy, the further the reach we have the more difficult it becomes for that enemy and the greater the deterrent to him.

The largest of our neighbouring countries is Indonesia with a population of over 150 million people. Other major countries include Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, Taiwan, the Philippines, Singapore, Papua New Guinea and New Zealand. In the South Pacific area alone within that same 3,000 mile radius there are 21 states and territories with populations totalling more than two million people. To the south lies Antarctica with its largely unknown but no doubt important resources. To all these countries within this area we give leadership, educational and industrial assistance, trade opportunities, military training and equipment and, in most cases, friendship and assistance in times of trouble. We have a record to be proud of but, more importantly, we must face up to an increasing responsibility for the future of this area.

Let us look at the South Pacific area with its 21 states and territories. With few exceptions these islands have now acquired full or partial independence and with few exceptions they are now facing the isolation and difficulties which independence brings. They are looking for leadership and they are looking to Australia. Most importantly, recently they have sought assistance in the development of a Pacific economic community possibly along the lines of the Association of South East Asian Nations experiment, and Australia is expected to play a leading part. Papua New Guinea seeks continuing aid, and we are rightly giving it. Michael Somare has reaffirmed Papua New Guinea's dependence on Australia for military assistance should it require it. It certainly expects it and we would ignore such a call at our peril. None of the countries of the South Pacific can forget that these island states were used as stepping stones to Australia in World War II, and Australia should forget least of all as it was the eventual target. Most of these countries in the South Pacific have underdeveloped economies, limited natural resources, little skilled manpower and practically no defences. Generally they look to Australia for assistance in all these things and it is very much in our interest that their appeal be heard.

The countries to our north east are different in character. Some are more populous and more developed both in skilled manpower and natural resources. Nevertheless, they seek our aid and assistance. Malaysia, Taiwan and Singapore are becoming highly developed countries with strong economies. They require not so much aid as closer trading links and defence arrangements which are, of course, to our common advantage. The same degree of development cannot be said to exist in Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam, Kampuchea and Laos. In these countries the need for assistance is as great as ever particularly in economic matters. In military matters we have a long history of involvement in the Pacific and in South East Asia dating from the Maori wars in New Zealand through the Boxer Rebellion in China, World War I and World War II, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam. We still have Mirage fighters based in Malaysia. We take part in regional defence exercises. We have been involved in New Guinea for over 100 years.

Whilst some of our military involvement has been criticised particularly in Vietnam, the point to remember is that we have always been heavily engaged in trying to secure peace and stability in this area. That involvement will only increase as the larger nations of the world, such as the British and the French, concentrate on their domestic affairs and the Americans look more and more to Australia to shoulder an increasing share of the economic and defence burden on our own doorstep. It does not seem to be possible to do what a lot of well- meaning but naive members of the Australian community wish-to pursue our own interests entirely whilst ignoring the hopes, aspirations and requirements of countries which share our corner of the world. We have responsibilities we must face up to, and it is in our interest to do so.

Prior to World War II we relied almost totally on Britain for our defences. In the event, in World War II Britain was unable to assist us in our part of the world. Since that war we have looked to the United States in the hope that the ANZUS Treaty might prove to be the solution to our defence problems. But important as the ANZUS Treaty is to Australia, the Falklands war should be enough to disprove the theory that ANZUS is not the total solution. The United States of America is not automatically committed to any country, no matter how close the ties. The first and foremost concern of any country, including the United States of America, is the pursuance of its own interests, and that is a lesson Australia should never forget. We are part of Asia and we are part of the Pacific. It is important that we play our part in this area of the world.

If we accept, therefore, that our regional defence responsibilities are not only domestic we should look next to what sorts of threats are posed to Australia-the threat of a full scale invasion, the threat of the occupation of a particular part of the country, the threat of guerrilla activity against towns or installations and the threat of terrorist activity against people or facilities. Sitting comfortably in Australia it is hard to imagine that any of these threats will really develop, but it is pertinent to ask how many of us had ever heard of the Falkland Islands six months ago, let alone envisaged a major war there. It is also relevant to note that the cause of the Falklands war was the run down in the British defence forces and the erroneous view of the Argentine junta that Britain no longer had the capability or the will to defend those islands. In short, when a country's defences are weak aggressors will always be tempted.

The defence forces of Australia, I believe, are in reasonable shape. I must say that the total amount of money spent in the Budget is somewhat disappointing in view of the fact that the real gain is about 0.8 per cent. The point I wish to make tonight in the short time available is that our defence responsibilities not only to our country but also to our nearby allies will increase and not decrease. I make the plea to the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) and the Government that any rundown in those defences in the long term will be disastrous for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very great shame that the way in which we must discuss defence matters in connection with this Budget means that we do not have the opportunity to cross examine in detail the Ministers and the officials who are responsible for having drafted it. This Budget is perhaps the most disappointing of a series of disappointing defence budgets that have been introduced in this place over the last four or five years. It represents without any real argument or any detailed announcement a substantial reduction in the Government's commitment to improving what might be described as the sharp end of Australia's defence forces. All the increase in this Budget can be attributed to anticipated increased costs in the manpower sector of the defence forces. In fact, as has been pointed out by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), those aspects of it which relate to equipments, installations and the like have suffered a real reduction in this Budget. This is at a time when there are very considerable needs in all three armed services. It is not a Defence Budget of which the Ministers who produced it can be proud. It is a Defence Budget which will create very substantial problems for this Government's successors.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that we find in these appropriations very specific problems for my area of Australia, that is, Western Australia. While we had every reason in my home State to anticipate, as a result of the Government's decision to abandon the immediate purchase of an aircraft carrier, that there would be something for us in this Defence Budget, there is nothing in it at all that has not been announced earlier. In fact there is not even to be a speeding up of the construction of the air base at Derby, a construction which was slowed by Government decision earlier in this year precisely because it was necessary to factor into defence budgeting in the immediate future an amount for the purchase of aircraft carriers.

I suppose that you, Dr Jenkins, as a medical man and an amateur psychologist, would acknowledge, along with the rest of us, that human happiness is to a very considerable extent dependent upon a personal sense of security. One of the aspects of security, Mr Deputy Speaker, is familiarity. So, with that, and nothing else, in mind, I listened to an announcement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) in answer to a question from the honourable member for Canning (Mr Bungey) yesterday that he was giving very serious consideration to the speeding up of home porting at HMAS Stirling in Cockburn Sound. Of course, the familiarity that gave me such cause for pleasure and improved my own personal sense of security lay not in the fact that I actually believed that the Minister was going to do something about it but in the fact that it can be anticipated that, when an election is about to occur, that promise will be trotted out.

I draw the attention of the Committee to the statements made by the then Minister for Defence, the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir James Killen), in the 1977 election campaign. Two months prior to that Federal election, the Minister for Defence announced that two destroyers and two submarines would be home ported at HMAS Stirling by late 1979 or early 1980. It was then announced in the course of the 1980 election, when this had not occurred, that we could anticipate the home porting of at least one warship worth $200m by the time the next election came around. There have not been too many explanations offered by Defence Ministers over this dereliction in keeping to promises solemnly announced to the Western Australian electorate, but there has been one at least by the former Defence Minister. On 19 February 1980, when he was asked by a journalist why this hardy perennial promise had not been kept and was merely being trotted out repeatedly at elections he had this to say:

Well, you know inexorably, . . . that with the cuts, and they have been inevitable, . . . But in areas its been a matter of seeking what at the proper priorities regarding resources made available . . . I am certainly not going to say how many ships will eventually be home ported there.

We are deeply grateful for that very clear explanation as to why there ought to be no home porting in Western Australia, but still we live in hope! We live in hope that perhaps one day an election promise will be fulfilled. Who knows-this might be the one-but I can assure the Committee that no honourable members from Western Australia are holding their breath on the matter.

Another feature in the context of Western Australian defence promises that is an absent friend from this Budget feast is the promise of the appearance of a patrol boat base on the north-west coast of Western Australia. It has been solemnly intoned by successive Defence Ministers that this would in fact eventuate in Western Australia. It appeared in the 1976 Defence White Paper as a promise to be implemented by 1981. In the 1980 Budget, it even made a guest appearance in the form of a promise to expend an amount of $250,000 on the purchase of a site in the north-west, but it slipped from that Budget as a useful saving. It has not made a guest appearance at this feast and therefore must be regarded as an absent friend. It can still be included in that category, as the friendly attitude of the Government towards it was expressed in just about every town of the north-west by the Minister in his first tour as Defence Minister through the area. There are now at least four towns up there that confidently expect that they will have a patrol boat base in the near future as the Minister, with a nod as good as a wink, indicated to them that each of them would get it. I would be very grateful if we got four patrol boat bases up there but I will settle for one, and I will settle for it appearing in a Budget.

I suppose that one can expect that there will at least be a higher degree of honesty from some of the Government's advisers as to why that has not appeared than one might expect from Ministers interested in election promises. Admiral Sir Anthony Synnot, former Chief of the Defence Force Staff, was more candid on his retirement when he said:

The Navy will go without a patrol boat base in the north-west as long as they can, if money is short. I don't think the Navy has considered that a patrol boat base in WA is quite so vital as updating the base in Darwin and the base in Cairns.

I would give that argument a serious quarrel bearing in mind other priorities which have been established by the Department of Defence in public statements by Ministers over the years and which have accorded a far higher level of significance to the north-west of Western Australia than those other areas mentioned. Indeed, if one looked at the value of the offshore installations in Western Australia and how useful a patrol boat base is simply in terms of enforcing Customs regulations, if nothing else, in that area, one would see ample reason for a patrol boat base there to have priority over Cairns and Darwin-certainly enough priority to have made a little more than guest and absent friends appearances in Budgets since it was first promised in 1976. But I suppose that we can anticipate that as the next election rolls inexorably closer and the Government seeks futilely to save itself seats in Western Australia we will get more mewling and pewling performances from Ministers for defence somewhat similar to those of the Minister for Defence yesterday when he told the honourable member for Canning that the Government was looking very seriously at having ships home ported at HMAS Stirling a little earlier than 1984, but that terribly serious strategic considerations and budgetary considerations were associated with that matter.

Of the combat forces of the Royal Australian Navy, 12 destroyers, six submarines and 14 patrol boats are deployed or being refitted on the east coast of Australia. There is one patrol boat on the west coast of Australia. This Government is supposed to be reasonably committed to a two ocean naval policy. That situation is ludicrous. It certainly demands a higher level of genuine priority as opposed to deceitful promises at election time than this Government has so far been able to give it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise one or two matters which are of lesser significance than the total overall defence policy of Australia. But I want first to correct a matter which an honourable member raised earlier. Forward defence and assistance with the defence of our allies are a laudable aim. However, this is something that can be done if one has provided for one's own defence adequately first. I point to a statement made in 1938 by the then Prime Minister, Mr Joseph Lyons, about the security which Australia would enjoy because of the establishment of forward defence facilities in Singapore. I need say no more about Singapore. It is an aim but surely it is an aim of Australian defence policy that we should have at least some commitment to the basic defence of Australia, and that means a balanced development of capabilities within the likely requirements of defence.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to continue with general remarks. I want to raise one or two specific matters. They deal largely with the conditions under which Australian servicemen serve in peacetime. I mentioned a significant change in the wages and conditions of servicemen which took place last year and which was long overdue-I think everyone is aware of that-but which, we are also aware, placed extreme strains on the defence budget. Some time ago the means by which defence salaries were fixed were changed from what was previously a very cumbersome and slow process to one by which reference to a tribunal is made by the Minister. That tribunal reports to the Minister, who determines whether he will sign certain recommendations and they become a determination. I have said in the past and I reiterate that this is an improper way of fixing salaries. It should not be up to a Minister to decide whether the recommendations of an independent tribunal should become determinations. That does not apply in respect of any other set of government employees. In all other cases the Government exercises its right to dispute those decisions by moving for their disallowance in either House of the Parliament. In this case the Government is able to make a decision on the basis that the Minister has to sign a recommendation before it becomes law.

I raise one other matter in this area; that is, the question of the ability of members of the Services, or anyone on their behalf, to raise matters in which there are anomalies or disputes in relation to what are usually substantive determinations. Small groups can be significantly disadvantaged. I raised one of these matters last night. There was a very significant row a couple of years ago in respect of the Bendigo survey unit printers. There have been numerous occasions on which small numbers of servicemen have felt that they have not been adequately dealt with in respect of the determinations of tribunals. I believe that the proper approach would be for the tribunal to be given the authority to make determinations in respect of the defence forces. I also believe that, as it is highly unlikely that in the foreseeable future advocates will appear on behalf of and from the Services, a special office of defence force advocate should be established, probably as a statutory position, and that person should be responsible for taking up and presenting argument on behalf of persons or groups of persons in the Services who consider that they have been disadvantaged or that their case has not been adequately heard or presented.

At the moment the cases that go to the relevant tribunal are prepared by different sections of the Department of Defence. Whilst I do not in any way suggest that these officers do not do their best, they are not closely in contact with those whom they represent, especially in the narrower context of specialised positions. It is highly unlikely that those cases are able to be properly presented without the opportunity to present argument and to challenge the submissions made on behalf of the Department or the Government, as is the case with other tribunals before which cases can be argued. I think it is important that members of the Defence Force have their conditions fixed in a manner which parallels as closely as practicable those of other government employees. I commend to the Government that this be undertaken.

I make one other point in relation to this area. The Budget Papers show that the sum of $300,000 has been set aside for the Commonwealth Games which will take place in Brisbane over the next two or three weeks. It is a contribution from the Commonwealth, especially allocated from the defence vote-incidentally, it is not added to the defence vote but is taken from it-for the conduct of the Commonwealth Games. It is obviously of significant assistance to the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth Games authorities. There are a number of allocations in that area, including $30,000 for ammunition and special travel allowances. One of the things I find objectionable is that members of the Defence Force will be expected to carry out jobs together with and quite often paralleling jobs which will be carried out by members of other public and private bodies. They will be expected to perform duties in addition to their normal duties but will receive no additional pay or compensation for the additional time and effort required. They will be disadvantaged and will be utilised in an unpaid capacity. It is a matter of concern to me and I think it should be of concern to everyone who has a fair approach to these matters. I am aware that the commanding officer can give them time off if he decides it is warranted.

I raise another matter of concern in relation to the conditions of service. There are provisions whereby, if a serviceman is away from his home for a specified period, he will be paid an allowance for living away from home. A practice has developed whereby persons who are required to be away from home for a time which would qualify them for the living away from home allowance are in fact having the period split by spending one day at their home base, and thus are denied the allowance which would properly be paid to them if they spent the entire period away from home. These practices would not be acceptable in the Public Service and they do not add to the standing or morale of the defence forces and they should be corrected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourchier Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to talk about two matters concerning Bendigo. I refer to the Army Survey Regiment at Fortuna in Bendigo. That Regiment has been there for many years. At election times I find that people suggest that it will be moved. It seems to be being moved about every three years.
—It occupies a magnificient building.

—It is a magnificent building, and I want to make sure that the Army Survey Regiment stays in it. The Army has allocated a considerable amount this year to update and refurnish the building and to try to restore it. The honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) will be delighted to know-he is interested in these matters-that the Army is spending an immense amount of money on restoring the buildings there to their former condition in the grand old days when the gold king lived there.
—That is what armies are for.

—Of course they are. What is the point of the Army occupying a National Trust building such as that unless it is prepared to maintain it? The important point is that the Army and the Government would not be prepared to spend this sort of money if the Army is to move out of the place. I take this opportunity to make it quite clear to the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner ), although he is not in the House at the moment, and certainly to representatives of the Defence Force, that they ought to settle back cosily and forget about trying to move the Army Survey Regiment out of Bendigo. I can assure honourable members that they will have one hell of a fight on their hands if they try.
—You will not be here to defend them.

—The honourable member will not be around, but I will be here. The Army Survey Regiment has become an integral part of Bendigo life. Many of the people who have served in the Survey Regiment, at the expiration of their term of service, have become citizens of Bendigo and are employed or own businesses in Bendigo. We want to see many years of this ahead of us.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer to the other matter I wish to raise. Recently the Minister for Defence Support announced that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory is to commence the contract to supply the Army with the 1.05 millimetre Howitzer gun-that is, the Hamel project. We had much pleasure in announcing that recently. It is interesting to note that this follows a promise which the Government made some time ago when all the furore about the disposal of the factory was in the air. The Government stated then that the factory would keep going and that this contract would be one of the contracts to be continued. I am delighted to see that. I am delighted also to see the Minister return to the table because I know he is anxious to hear that the people at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory and I are particularly determined to see the management of that project come back to Bendigo.

The original story is that when the Army decided it wanted a 105 Howitzer gun two types were available for its consideration. One was the United States production and the other was the United Kingdom production. The Army had to decide which gun would be chosen and this would determine whether the management of the project would be given to the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo or the Ordnance Factory at Maribyrnong. If the United States gun were decided upon then the Ordnance Factory at Maribyrnong was to have the management of jointly supplying it. If the United Kingdom gun were decided upon the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo was to be charged with the management as it had carried out all the preliminary work.

Somewhere along the track, and for no reason that I can ascertain, Canberra decided that it wanted to get into the act. So the management sector was taken back to head office. Perhaps the pundits in Canberra believe that there was no way in which the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, which had so capably carried out all the preliminary work and conducted the negotiations, was capable of management. I assure the Minister for Defence Support that Bendigo is capable. He has visited Bendigo and the Ordnance Factory and I am certain that in his own mind he knows the situation. Whatever happened, at the present time that management decision lies in Canberra. I think that is wrong. The Bendigo Ordnance Factory will be doing the bulk of the work in regard to this United Kingdom Howitzer model. It will be working in conjunction with the Ordnance Factory, Maribyrnong. But quite rightly, under the initial agreement, it should have-I hope it will- the management returned to it. There is not a great deal of money involved in the management being returned and not a great deal of extra staff are involved. I would not think that any would be involved. But the important thing is that this project which was initiated in Bendigo should be looked after and nurtured by the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The prestige should go to it. Now that it has successfully obtained the contract I believe that in all justice it should have the management of this contract returned to it. I hope that the Minister will take note of that.

One other thing that I am rather delighted about is that the Victorian Government has decided to organise that part of the contract to supply coal dredgers and crawler tractors for the State Electricity Commission in Victoria. I believe that that part of the contract for production of the crawler treads is to be undertaken at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The State authorities are trying to take the credit for this. One does not blame them. But it should be clearly pointed out that when the first contract was let the Bendigo Ordnance Factory was not able at that time to become involved in the tender. Through my efforts in approaching the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch ) and through his efforts we were able at that time to arrange for the successful tendering company-an Australian-based German company-to negotiate with the Bendigo Ordnance Factory in the hope that it could come to some agreement whereby the expertise of the factory could be used in the manufacture of this part of the crawler tractors. This was all going on at the time people were saying that we were going to close the factory down. This just indicates how untrue it was.

A change of government occurred in Victoria and the Minister responsible for power in that Government made it quite clear that he was going to have the tractor parts made in Germany as had originally been planned. We cannot blame him for that. I am not being critical because, after all, he had to look at the economic situation of his State. But I managed to mention to the Minister for Defence Support, to the people in Bendigo and to the State members of parliament that the State Labor Government had made election promises that it would have these parts made at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. It had insisted, prior to the election, that when it got into office it would make certain that it would give preference to State manufacturers. Having reminded the Victorian Labor Government rather loudly of that fact I must admit that at last it took heart and decided that it should carry out its election promise. I congratulate it on acknowledging the fact that it made an election promise and for accepting the requests of the Minister for Defence Support and me to do the right thing and to give that contract to the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo.

Together with the Hamel project for the Howitzer gun, this will provide the Bendigo Ordnance Factory with a base load of work for some 15 years or more. This will allow the Factory to build, to provide employment, and to be certain of carrying on its good tradition. The future of the Factory is now quite assured through the efforts of the Minister and myself. We are both very modest about it. As a result, the people of Bendigo realise that the Government is determined to carry out the promise it made in the first place. The Factory will stay in Bendigo and receive all the help possible from the Government to ensure continuing employment. On behalf of the people of Bendigo I thank the Minister. More importantly, the Minister should finish off his good work by bringing the management of the Hamel project back to Bendigo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene again in this debate because I am determined, as are other member on this side of the Committee, that there will be an hour-and-a-half debate on the estimates for the Department of Defence as we were promised. Even so that compares very unfavourably with last year's situation when we had two hours in the Estimates committees and then an hour to review the reports of those committees. We were therefore able to look at the defence estimates with considerably more leisure than we have had on this occasion. I think it is a major tragedy that those committees have disappeared. As a result the consideration of the Budget has been nowhere near as thorough this session as it has been over the last couple of years.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take up one or two of the points that were made by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) on the work of the Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I refer particularly to the remarks that he made about the work of the Sub-Committee on the question of the aircraft carrier. By and large I agree with what he had to say on the matter but I do not quite agree with some of the strictures that he placed on the question of evidence. Most of the criticism of that report since it has emerged-the criticism has emanated from the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner) and it was followed up by his announcement that a carrier purchase is still under review and likely, and also by other circles outside this Parliament-has centered on a question of an assessment of the value of the Harrier aircraft. Of course, that is a very minor aspect of the report. Whether the Harrier has the capabilities ascribed to it-even in the criticisms of it the capabilities do not vary very much-the question as to whether the Harrier is a useful weapons system is close to being irrelevant to the question of whether Australia should have an aircraft carrier. Even if the Harrier were the most singing and dancing aircraft in the world, we still would not send a single aircraft carrier armed with a dozen of them against a reasonably competent air power within the range of operations of its land-based air force. The carrier simply would not have the capability of dealing with that air force.

The second point I make is that, irrespective of what advocates of the carrier may have said about the need for a carrier to be armed with Harriers, the evidence presented to us by the Department of Defence emphatically argued that any purchase of a Harrier-this was associated with the purchase of the aircraft carrier HMS Invincible-was a very long way down the line and not within the immediate consideration of the Government. The aircraft carrier was being purchased to perform specifically an anti-submarine warfare role. So we have never had placed before us by the Government a serious proposition for what might amount to a full blown aircraft carrier capacity within the Australian defence forces. One could argue, I think quite reasonably, that any full blown aircraft carrier capacity would require us to have two or three of them but, at a minimum, it would require any aircraft carrier to be armed to its fullest capability. It certainly was never an intention of the Government, at least in the foreseeable future, that this should be the case in the purchase of the aircraft carrier HMS Invincible.

We on the Committee believe that the aircraft carrier purchase bore no relationship to the immediate priorities of the Australian defence forces. It might have been useful were a substantial number of other areas of Australian defence capability properly catered for in terms of equipment and personnel. It would have had its uses. But certainly in circumstances where an aircraft carrier would have cost us a great deal more than the Invincible, as will be the case now if we purchase an aircraft carrier with anything like the capabilities of the Invincible, such a purchase would not only not be within the framework of Australia's defence priorities but also, in fact, it would seriously detract from them.

If we were to purchase a carrier and all its equipment for a price of about $1. 5 billion-that is the lowest estimate of what an aircraft carrier with the capability of the Invincible would cost us now-and pay all that off over a decade it would account for something like 50 per cent of the amount in each annual Budget devoted to equipment purchases for the armed Services, assuming that the equipment budget maintained the pattern it has established in the last few years in relation to overall expenditure on defence. That simply would be ludicrous. That would be an absolutely absurd waste of important defence funds. The Committee identified areas on which we thought the Government ought to concentrate relating to both the Fleet Air Arm and also the effective defence of Australia. I mention one area, the airborne early warning system, which the Government has actually said occasionally that it considers important too. If we are to get a decent airborne early warning capability it will cost the Government at least $300m. If the Government were to choose to do that we on this side of the chamber would strongly support that. It would be money very well spent indeed. Regardless of whether the Government chooses to purchase an airborne early warning capability there are still useful things that could be done with the Fleet Air Arm within the framework of the current Budget.

We were very upset with the situation we found in Nowra. There was low morale and real concern on the part of the officers as to what their future would be. It is an extremely distressing situation to have so many highly capable people, who have a very high sense of service to the country, in the depressed situation in which they now find themselves. I do not believe that this Government will proceed with the purchase of an aircraft carrier. It will make a promise and an announcement that perhaps the Navy will look at a couple of options in a few weeks time, particularly if an election is going to come forward. Even if the Defence Department goes ahead with the purchase of an aircraft carrier that will not resolve the immediate problem of the Fleet Air Arm. It is high time this Government started to give serious consideration to what can be done for the people in the Fleet Air Arm.

The Committee made a couple of very constructive suggestions. One of those suggestions was that as the Grumman trackers were available with all the appropriate spare parts and were capable of flying, they ought to be included in the surveillance program of the Australian defence forces. They were deployed extremely usefully from points in the north and west of Australia in the mid- 1970s when there were some real concerns about our capacity to conduct effective surveillance of our off-shore fishing zones. They did a very effective job. They could be well deployed there again. The deployment of them there would enable a massive improvement in the morale of the Fleet Air Arm. The Committee also pointed out the fact that the A4 Skyhawks have a lifetime which will take them readily to the end of this decade, that they remain a very useful ground attack aircraft and also a useful maritime strike aircraft. In those capaicities they ought to be fully utilised from land bases by the Fleet Air Arm. They would thus provide useful training in maritime operations for members of the Fleet Air Arm and also for the Royal Australian Navy generally in developing its capabilities to deal with air attacks. We believe that both those uses of those aircraft ought to be made. If the Government were to make the announcement now instead of chasing around after pipe-dreams it would do a very great deal of good to that section of the Services.

I will have to conclude on this note: One of the problems with which we are confronted in this Budget-I have essentially been talking about training of the Fleet Air Arm-is the reduction that has occurred in the fuel to be available for training purposes in all sections of the Australian armed Services. There have been substantial reductions throughout this Budget although they are not outlined in specific detail in one block, which makes criticism extremely difficult. But that reduction will have a substantial effect on the capacity to conduct training operations in Western Australia and also on the type of activity of the Fleet Air Arm about which I have been talking. I hope the Government will review that decision along with the review I have suggested of the Fleet Air Arm. That would do a great deal for the morale of the Australian armed forces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some time ago the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on behalf of the Government indicated that it would be a policy of the Government to endeavour to respond to all reports of parliamentary committees within six months of those reports being tabled. One of the most important reports tabled in this Parliament in my view was the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence entitled 'Threats to Australia's Security'. That report was tabled on 18 November 1981. To date there has been no response from the Government to that report, nor has there been any indication by the Government that it has any intention of honouring the promise made by the Prime Minister. The reason I believe it is important for there to be a Government response is that I believe it is surely time there was a debate in this Parliament on defence and foreign policy matters and the potential of threats to Australia in a politically balanced climate.
—And with the Minister present.

—With the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) and, indeed, the Prime Minister present. What has occurred in this Parliament over the last six months in relation to this matter has been the Prime Minister or some of his back bench members coming into this chamber and producing some kind of motion which might be related to what they regard as giving them some kind of perceived political advantage. They have trotted out the same old hairy logic saying that either the Russians are coming or that we are being subjected to a communist takeover. A very significant and unanimous recomendation in the threats report is significantly ignored. All that has occurred ultimately-with Government members retiring from the debate hurt and certainly unpersuaded-has been another exercise in political confrontation. The people of Australia are entitled to expect better than that from this Parliament and they are certainly entitled to expect better than that from this Government. The view of this Parliament that this Government is taking is shown by the fact that the Minister for Defence has not even seen fit to make himself present in this House while this Committee debate on the Estimates is taking place.
—He is too busy counting his stolen money.

—I do not know the reason he is not here. But it seems to me that-I regard the Leader of the House (Sir James Killen), who operates on behalf of the Government in this place, as an honourable man; he does not give assurances lightly-whereas we previously had a situation in which the Minister was present with his senior advisers and serious questions could be asked by members on all sides of the chamber, we have now gone back to a situation in which there is purportedly time for a member to make a comment. Despite what I believe were the honourable intentions of the Leader of the House, the Minister for Defence believes that whatever viewpoint is expressed by any member of this Parliament- it does not matter from what side of the chamber-he will not honour the chamber with his presence.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point out some of the comments that have been made about threats to Australia's security. I refer to a recent article appearing in the September issue of the Current Affairs Bulletin. The article raises and deals with some of the points raised in that report. The author, Andrew Mack, is a senior lecturer in politics at the School of Social Sciences at Flinders University in South Australia. This is what he says about-
Debate interrupted.
Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I shall report progress.

INTERJECT.PARA: Progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Sir James Killen-I require the question to be put forthwith without debate.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr HOLDING

TALK.START.PARA: —What Mr Mack says about the report is as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . is comprehensive-balanced, clearly written and intelligently argued- indeed, it is without doubt the best introduction yet published on the vital question of threats to our security.
He continues:

The fact that this 60-page report received so little serious examination by the media when published at the end of last year is a sad commentary on the seriousness with which the press and other media treat defence issues.

He goes on to make the point very properly that the report not merely confronted the issues as to the nature and probability of threats to Australia but in fact it reached conclusions which were largely at variance with much of the pre- conceived thinking that exists in the Australian community at large and in this Parliament in some areas.

It is important to note that this is the first time any document has emanated in this Parliament which has given consideration in any depth and detail at all to the problems that confront Australia with the threat of nuclear war between the superpowers. It analyses at some length the build-up and the awesome range of weapons which exist between the two major superpowers. It deals with the problems of so-called limited nuclear war and with the problems that would confront Australia in a situation where our hosting of joint facilities with the United States would certainly make Australia in the event of a global conflict a target for Soviet nuclear missiles. I would have thought that was just one area alone which I believe ought to be seriously engaged and subject to earnest debate in this Parliament.

The report goes on to point out on the basis of the evidence which was given by Admiral Synnot and supported by other defence analysts that no superpower except the United States of America could successfully mount an armed invasion of Australia. That is an important conclusion. One hears so often from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and other senior Ministers, when they want to talk about the threat to the Australian community, the cry: 'The Russians are coming' . That cry has been analysed by members on both sides of the House, and that concept as a concept in terms of armed invasion is rejected. I would have thought that that was a matter which would have excited some concern and some need for debate in this Parliament. The report goes on to talk about intermediate level threats and the capability that would need to be created in any regional power that was concerned to attack Australia. It deals with our capacity to defend ourselves and it rejects the widely held notion that this nation, because of its size and the geographic distances that we have to overcome, is defenceless. It rejects that notion, and it does so on the basis of a range of evidence which ought to be again, I believe, seriously considered.

The report deals with the problem of low level contingencies and raises some very serious issues which ought to be the subject of future consideration by members of this Parliament. It points out some of the important foreign policies and defence issues that need to be faced up to. I would have thought that it was no easy matter on issues as vexed as this to take a group of parliamentarians who represent every political philosophy within this community and have them make an analysis of this kind and reach a broadly unanimous agreement. Having reached that agreement and having reached what I believe are very important conclusions, I believe that this report gives an opportunity for the Government, if it is sincere and is concerned to get some sense of unanimity in this Parliament on these important issues, to provide the basis for debate. That opportunity has not been taken. It will not be taken because this Government is more concerned when the occasion suits it to try to use defence as an issue of confrontation to divide the Australian community rather than to unite it.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we ought to set a background to these death sentences. There are at least 67 political prisoners in Indonesia under sentence of death. A total of 63 were charged with alleged pro-communist subversion for political activities undertaken after the military takeover of power in October 1965. All these men have been in prison since the late 1960s and were tried and sentenced many years ago. Some have lived under the threat of their death sentences for as long as 15 years. The other four men were charged with alleged Moslem subversion and were all tried in the past five years. In all cases the prisoners have been tried on the basis of Indonesia's anti-subversion law which allows the courts to apply the term 'subversion' to any political activity deemed to be a threat to the Government.

Press Release
STATEMENT OF SETTLEMENT OF OUTSTANDING MATTERS IN WALSH GROUP OF COMPANIES

A Deed of Settlement with respect to moneys alleged to have been misappropriated by my late Father was executed yesterday between Reliance Investments Pty Ltd and its subsidiary companies, the shareholders of the companies, Sinclair Pastoral Co. Pty Ltd, and myself, the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Ian Sinclair, said in Sydney today.

The settlement involves payment by my Father's Estate and the Sinclair Pastoral Co. of $430,000 to the Reliance Investments group and the foregoing of the benefit to an amount of $141,214.43 standing to the credit of the Sinclair Pastoral Co. in the books of the Reliance Investments group, and the benefit to an amount of $45,728.55 standing to the credit of the Estate of the late George Sinclair in the books of the Reliance Investments group.

The Deed establishes liability and terms of repayment with respect to the moneys alleged to have been misappropriated by my late Father and referred to in my statement to the Parliament on 6 June last.
In addition to the settlement, Extraordinary General Meetings of Reliance Investments Pty Ltd and each of its subsidiaries were held on Friday, 15 June 1979.

At those meetings resolutions were carried unanimously by all the shareholders confirming the payment of dividends, the interest charged on shareholders loan accounts, the amount of loan accounts of shareholders in the companies records, and the directors of the companies; approving loans made to the Sinclair Pastoral Co. and myself; acknowledging amounts due to the Estate of the late George Sinclair in the books of the companies; and accepting as amounts misappropriated the amounts set out in the reports of the investigating accountants.

The Deed and the Extraordinary General Meetings settle the matters outstanding between the shareholders of the Reliance Investments group. They have been completed after independent legal advice to each of the shareholders.
A copy of the Deed of Settlement dated 1 August 1979 is attached to this press release.
