PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The matters with which this Bill and its companion measures deal have been the subject of considerable public and political debate in recent times. In bringing the measures before the Parliament the Government demonstrates once again its clear commitment to do what it can to establish and uphold a fair system of taxation in this country. As Treasurer of the Commonwealth, I have brought before the Parliament a wide range of Bills designed so that those who would seek to escape their fair share of taxation do not succeed.

Today the Government complements its earlier proscription of schemes to evade the payment of legally payable company tax by a Bill that will recover evaded company tax from the principal beneficiaries of earlier evasion of that kind. In doing this we have sought to achieve a reasonable balance between all the various, and often conflicting, interests and considerations that seem to attend the more significant of taxation issues. Our normal and general reluctance to introduce legislation having any retrospective element has, on this ocassion, been tempered by the competing consideration of overall perceptions as to the equity and fairness of our taxation system and the distribution of the tax burden. We are also dealing here with recoupment of tax which was clearly the subject of illegal evasion.

The Government believes that the public is clearly of the view that that tax evaded in the course of so-called bottom-of-the-harbour strips of untaxed company profits should be recovered for public purposes. Vendor shareholders and other former owners of stripped companies ought to be made make good the tax that remains unpaid, and from the evasion of which they have clearly enjoyed a benefit. But, in establishing by this Bill the rules under which accounts are to be settled, the Government has been anxious to ensure that the matter proceeds on a properly measured basis. I believe that the Bill I am presenting observes these principles.

The basic measures contained in the Bill were foreshadowed by me in some detail in a full statement made on 25 July 1982 and in a further statement on 17 August last. I made it clear then, and I repeat now, that the measures are designed, and will operate only, to collect evaded company tax. Tax that may have been avoided is not the subject of the legislation. That point needs to be made clear not only so that the ambit of the Bill is properly understood, but also so that some of the wilder claims about the numbers of companies that have been stripped of untaxed profits can be seen as unfounded as they are. Where companies were simply stripped of profits that have borne all the company-including undistributed profits-tax payable on them, there has been no evasion of tax and the legislation will not apply. Nor will it apply to the taxed profits element in the case of a strip of both taxed and untaxed company profits. Only the tax on the untaxed profits is the subject of the Bill.

But let me remind the House, with effect from 27 May 1981 when we brought in the new general anti-avoidance provisions of Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, Vendor-shareholders are to be taxed on any profits liberated to them in the course of a dividend strip or other similar strip of company profits . The measures to collect evaded tax are to operate on strips of untaxed profits that were carried out between 1 January 1972 and 4 December 1980 when the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 dealt a decisive blow to such schemes. Just as that legislation applies to arrangements that have a purpose of rendering a company unable to pay its tax, so the present Bill will declare that it is to operate only where there has been an arrangement that had the effect that a company was rendered unable to pay its company tax.

The other precise tests of the legislation are also of an objective nature, helping to make clear its field of operation, and I now outline them, taking first the simpler forms of company structure. I said in my statement of 25 July that the legislation would apply where all the shares in a company were sold. Scheme promoters needed to have total control of a company before they could effect the strip that was a part of the overall arrangement. However, it was possible for them to do this where less than the entire ownership was acquired and the Bill accordingly, on the basis of company law provisions, makes it a condition for its application that there was a sale of shares carrying more than 90 per cent of the voting power in the target company.

Another important test is framed so that it is clear that the legislation will apply only where the vendor-shareholder and other former owners actually derived a benefit from the evasion of the company's tax. This is achieved by a provision that requires that the total consideration for the sale of the shares in the company exceeded its net assets as reduced by any actual or contingent company tax liability on income derived up to the time of sale of the shares. To put it another way, the test is one that puts into legal terms the concept that the sale price for the company was such that it was evident that company tax on the amount of then apparent profits would not be paid. A person who pays, say, $90, 000 for shares in a company that has traded for part of the income year and earned $100,000, which is what the company has in the bank, cannot be regarded as in a position to pay the $46,000 company tax payable on a taxable income of $ 100,000.

The liability of former owners of a company under the legislation will not arise until the company's liability has been established by assessment, rights of objection and appeal against that assessment have either not been exercised or have been exhausted, and tax remains unpaid. That test is obviously as it should be, but, in the course of our detailed preparation of the legislation, we have decided that, although a delay in collection of the evaded tax will be involved, another element should be added. This is that former owners of a company will not be called on to effect recoupment of the company tax under this legislation until after they have had an opportunity to contest the basic assessment of that tax.

The Commissioner of Taxation has already issued many notices of assessment in respect of the companies concerned, but due to the fact that some have been returned unclaimed, and to other circumstances, these notices are a less than satisfactory foundation for tax claims on the former owners. As soon as practicable after this legislation is passed, therefore, a copy of the already issued notice of assessment will in each case be sent to a representative vendor -shareholder who will be able to exercise the rights of objection and appeal open to the company. The obligation of former owners to meet any late payment penalty owing by the company will be measured only from the date that would be the due date for payment if the company assessment had been served on the day that the copy is sent.

I said in my statement of 25 July that we do not want the legislation to apply where the reason for non-payment of company tax is that a company has suffered commercial misadventure in the hands of its new owners, following its sale at a commercially realistic price. To make that clear, the legislation specifies that it will apply only where the company did not, after the sale, carry on the same business as it had carried on beforehand. Where the various threshold tests are all met each vendor-shareholder will, at base, be liable to effect recoupment of his or her share of the evaded tax. That amount will be fixed according to the vendor's share of the total consideration for the sale of shares in the company.

In noting that the recovery from vendor-shareholders will be of the total amount of the evaded company tax, undiminished by the part of that tax taken as a fee by those who promoted the scheme and stripped the company, I also observe that the special legislation will not make vendors liable for penalty taxes incurred by the company in respect of lodgment of an incorrect return or of late lodgment or of non-lodgment. On review, the Government has accepted the argument that vendors should not have to bear these penalties, which can be accepted as being due more to acts or omissions on the part of those to whom the companies were transferred. The penalty taxes excluded from the scope of the recoupment measures will, however, remain as tax that is legally owing by the companies concerned.

That brings me to a discussion of the liability of promoters and other strippers to assist in making good the evasion of tax that has occurred. Our appointment of a Special Prosecutor, and the work that he will carry out, can be expected to make some contribution, but the Government is not content to let it rest there. It is the Government's wish to have legislation that will place a liability on those who were on the post-sale side of these schemes. Provisions to effect some recoupment of unpaid company taxes from these people will either be added to the Bill by an amendment on the floor of the House or made the subject of a further Bill to be considered alongside the present Bill. To return to that Bill, its recoupment obligations will extend to vendor-shareholders in a company who sold shares and thereby, in association with other shareholders concerned, transferred control in yet another company which was stripped of untaxed company profits. A sale of shares in a holding company that carried ownership of a series of subsidiary companies with untaxed profits is an example . Whether a sale of shares took place in one of these more complex situations, or in the simple case I dealt with earlier, some of the vendor-shareholders will have been companies or trusts through which people held ownership of the stripped companies, and there could also have been more lengthy chains of ownership.

The broad aim of the legislation is to effect a recoupment at the earliest practicable and appropriate stage along a chain of ownership but where, in defined circumstances, that cannot be achieved the Bill has provisions for tracing through, broadly on the basis of rights to capital, the liability from one level to another, so that ultimately it rests on the people who indirectly owned the stripped companies. Persons who at a primary or secondary level are liable to the recoupment tax that is being formally imposed as a technique for recovering the evaded tax will be issued with a notice of assessment setting out the amounts they are each liable to pay. A recipient of such a notice will of course have the usual rights of objection and appeal against a recoupment tax assessment and, if the tax remains unpaid 30 days after the notice is issued, the unpaid amount will there after attract late payment penalty at the rate of 20 per cent per annum. On review, we have concluded that that rate, rather than the earlier-announced rate of 30 per cent would be appropriate.

Associated with that, a separate Bill that I will shortly introduce will implement the earlier-announced decision to propose a doubling-from 10 per cent to 20 per cent-in the rate of penalty for late payment of income tax. This further Bill will have the effect that late payment penalty begins to accrue as soon as is practicable at the higher rate of 20 per cent in the basic assessments of company tax issued or to be re-issued in respect of the stripped companies concerned. In noting that unpaid undistributed profits tax is within the scope of the recoupment legislation, I observe that in harmony with existing provisions in the income tax law the former owners of a company may arrange instead to pay tax themselves on the same basis as if the company had distributed enough in dividends to escape a liability to undistributed profits tax. Earlier-foreshadowed provisions to guard against divestment of assets in an attempt to frustrate the operation of the recoupment legislation are another feature of the Bill.

Among further provisions of note are measures to adopt the machinery and collection provisions of the income tax law; to enable the fullest reporting to Parliament of failures to comply with the recoupment legislation; to ensure that , secrecy provisions of the tax law notwithstanding, persons liable to recoupment tax are able to get details of the basis on which their liability was calculated and, to assist them in any personal pursuit of promoters for compensation, of the ways in which their company was stripped; to make appropriate adjustments in a person's liability where other amounts of, or representing, the unpaid company tax are paid; to deal with situations where a stripped company has ceased to exist; and finally, to give the Commissioner of Taxation authority not to pursue liability in particular circumstances, including where a person's liability under the legislation is under $100. These are the broad principles of the Bill which, while it gives effect to a simple enough recoupment concept has, reflecting the difficulty and variety of situations with which it deals, emerged as a somewhat complex piece of legislation.

As is usual with taxation legislation a comprehensive explanatory memorandum giving further and fuller explanations of the Bill and three associated Bills that I will introduce shortly is being made available to honourable members. Part 1 of the memorandum is being circulated today and Part 2, which will be a clause by clause explanation of the Bills, will be made available to honourable members next week. The Government believes that the Parliament will give this package of legislation the speedy approval that it deserves. While we are committed to implementation of the policies that the Bills express, we are of course ready to review particular provisions of them at a more technical level, having regard to any constructive comments that are put to us. With those introductory remarks I commend this Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Dawkins) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill formally imposes a tax on the taxable amount established by the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill which I have just introduced. That Bill provides the parameters within which vendor-shareholders and other former owners of shares in stripped companies will be called to account for their share of tax evaded by companies with which they were formerly associated. As I explained in introducing that Bill, liability for the recoupment tax will fall initially on the persons who sold their shares, but where it is impracticable or inappropriate to levy the tax at that primary level it will be possible to trace through to more remote links in the ownership chain and levy the tax at levels below the primary level. This Bill imposes on the taxable amount-which in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill is called the eligible taxable amount-fixed for each former owner a recoupment tax equal to that taxable amount . It is by this means that the evaded company tax is to be recovered. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Dawkins) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This third Bill in the legislative package to recover tax illegally evaded in company stripping schemes proposes amendments to several Acts, consequential upon the two Bills I have already introduced. The first amendment is that of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Decisions under certain Acts are precluded from review through the system of review provided for by that Act. Decisions under the new recoupment tax legislation are also to be excluded from the purview of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. However, a person liable to recoupment tax who receives an assessment in respect of his or her liability will have available full rights or objection and appeal to a Taxation Board or Review or a Supreme Court and ultimately, if the matter warrants it, to the Federal and High Courts.

Other taxation laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation that provide similar rights to contest liability are also exluded from review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Amendments of the other Acts-the Pay-roll Tax (Territories) Assessment Act, the Sale Tax Assessment Act (No. 1), the Stevedoring Industry Charge Assessment Act, the Tobacco Charges Assessment Act and the Wool Tax (Administration) Act are of a more technical nature. As a result of amendments made to these Acts in 1980 by the Taxation Debts (Abolition of Crown Priority) Act, a liquidator or receiver of a company is permitted to satisfy secured debts and preferential debts under Commonwealth or State laws before payment of taxation debts. Having made such payments a liquidator or receiver is required to set aside a proportionate part of the remaining assets for payment of income tax and various other taxes payable under the Acts I have referred to. The effect of the remaining consequential amendments is to include in the calculation of the amount a liquidator or receiver of a company must set aside any liability of the company to recoupment tax. I also commend this Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Dawkins) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (ADDITIONAL TAX) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In speaking to the Bill I have just introduced to recover tax evaded in the course of 'bottom-of-the-harbour' strips of untaxed company profits I mentioned that I would be introducing a further Bill to double the rate of penalty for late payment of income tax. This Bill will achieve that purpose, not just for companies that were stripped of assets but also for all individuals and other companies that are late in paying their income tax. On 10 August 1982 I announced the Government's intention to propose an increase from 10 per cent per annum to 20 per cent per annum in the rate of penalties payable under the various taxation laws for late payment of tax. At the same time I gave some details of the Government's intention to introduce a system for payment of interest on a refund of tax that occurs as a result of a successful objection or appeal by a taxpayer.

By this Bill, the income tax law will be amended to increase the rate of late payment penalty for late payment of income tax and related amounts. The increase to 20 per cent will not, however, take effect until two months after this Bill has become law. The new rate of penalty tax provided in this Bill will apply in respect of the late payment of assessed income tax, withholding tax on interest and dividends paid to non-residents of Australia, mining withholding tax and tax instalment deductions made by an employer from salaries or wages paid to employees.

The Bill also proposes a corresponding increase in the rate of additional tax payable where the taxable income of a company has been underestimated and the company has thereby been enabled to pay reduced instalments of company tax. The existing income tax law empowers the Commissioner of Taxation to remit all or part of an amount of late payment penalty where that is judged to be appropriate . Where there is an objection or appeal against an assessment and the Commissioner accepts that the taxpayer has a genuine difference of opinion about his or her tax liability, the present general administrative practice of the Commissioner is, in the exercise of that power to remit, to enter into an arrangement with the taxpayer to remit all late payment penalty in the event that the taxpayer is not successful in his objection or appeal. This arrangement is on the basis that the taxpayer pays one-half of the tax in dispute pending the outcome of the objection or appeal-it has been called a 50-50 arrangement.

This Bill will re-express the power given to the Commissioner of Taxation to remit late payment penalty, so that this particular approach to the handling of disputed income tax liabilities will not be available in future. The Commissioner will of course continue to be empowered to remit late payment penalty where there are special circumstances, such as adverse business conditions or other factors beyond the control of the taxpayer. Although the remission power is to be altered for the future, existing 50-50 arrangements will be allowed to continue according to their terms. I also make the point that under the legislation we propose that a person who has a genuine dispute about liability will be able to pay to the Commissioner one-half of the disputed tax and obtain an extension of time for payment of the balance on the basis that, if the taxpayer wins the contest, he or she will be paid interest when the 50 per cent is refunded but, if the taxpayer loses, the Commissioner will be entitled to recover the remaining 50 per cent subject to late payment penalty of 20 per cent from the date when the assessment became payable.

It has not been practicable to include in this Bill the measures necessary to provide for the payment of interest to taxpayers. However, we are committed to these measures and they will be introduced after the forthcoming break in sittings. It also remains the Government's intention to introduce as soon as practicable legislation dealing with late payment penalties and payment of interest in respect of sales tax and other taxes administered by the Commissioner.

Finally, I mention the review that has been going on in recent months of monetary and other penalties contained in the various taxation laws. I intend to introduce further legislation as soon as I can to increase the effectiveness of the other penalty provisions of the taxation laws. Part of the review of penalties has focused on the rate of additional tax payable in cases involving international profit shifting arrangements, where avoidance that would otherwise occur has been eliminated by the new legislation brought in by this Government.

The Government has not overlooked its undertaking given in the Senate earlier this year that the level of additional tax applicable to such profit shifting arrangements would be reviewed, and the results of that review will be announced shortly. An explanatory memorandum giving technical explanations of provisions of the Bill will be made available to honourable members, and I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr McVEIGH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—He may proceed.

—The honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West), in his speech to the House yesterday on the Code of Practice on the Management of Radioactive Waste, in a most mischievous and irresponsible way made a number of inaccurate statements in relation to the Ranger tailings dam. I now wish to set the record straight and attempt to undo the untold damage that the wild assertions by the honourable member for Cunningham have created. I would quote from his statement yesterday as reported at page 1721 of Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been informed today by the staff of the National Parks and Wildlife Service that a major fault exists within the tailings dam at Ranger.
Today in this Parliament he said:
My own notes that I had shown him regarding information from the Parks and Wildlife Service and the Office of the Supervising Scientist . . .

First, I can confirm, as I did yesterday, that the Supervising Scientist has reported to me that a potential problem has been indicated by the monitoring systems installed adjacent to the Ranger tailings dam. A limited zone in the natural rock below part of the foundations of the dam wall has a higher permeability than expected and increased water pressures have been detected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Will the Minister come to the point on which he has been misrepresented?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order.
—The Minister will resume his seat
—My point of order is that we are all a little unclear as to what the Minister is about. Is it a personal explanation or a statment to the House as requested by me this morning?
—The Minister has sought the indulgence of the Chair to make an explanation on the basis that he had been misrepresented.
—Will he come to the point?
—Order! I must admit that the Chair is becoming increasingly curious to find out just what point has been misrepresented. I ask the Minister to come quickly to that point.
—There is, however, no adverse environmental effect at present and appropriate action has been taken to ensure that no adverse effects will arise in the future.
—Is this a personal explanation or a statement?
—Order! The honourable member for Cunningham will resume his seat. The Minister must immediately come to the matter on which he has been misrepresented. He is engaging in debate at this stage.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, part of the--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister is obviously not making a personal explanation. I would be quite happy to give him leave to make a statement to the House on this very important matter as long as the Opposition is given leave to reply.
—Does the proposition prove amenable to the Minister?
—I am quite happy.

DEBATE.TITLE: CODE OF PRACTICE ON THE MANAGEMENT OF RADIOACTIVE WASTE FROM THE MINING AND MILLING OF RADIOACTIVE ORES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister seek leave to make a statement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr McVEIGH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated that it is necessary to put into proper perspective some of the irrational statements made by the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West). I repeat for his information what I said yesterday. The problem is not unusual in constructions of this kind. The claim that the dam has failed is absolute nonsense and irresponsible in the extreme. This matter has been seized upon by the honourable member for Cunningham to further his emotional anti- uranium cause. I take this opportunity of assuring the House that there is nothing unusual in the problem and that the actions taken will be conventional engineering in large earth and rock dams. I also point out that I have been aware of the matter for some time but due to its relative insignificance have not sought to dramatise, over-emphasise or draw unnecessary attention to it. Interested parties including the Northern Land Council, the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government have been kept fully informed by the company through the mechanism of the Alligator Rivers Region Co-ordinating Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: It therefore reflects badly on the honourable member for Cunningham to seek such cheap political capital from the matter. Let me say of the problem that since 10.30 on the morning of 8 June when I attended a meeting of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the Co-ordinating Committee in Darwin I have been kept fully informed on a regular basis. This has been done at my request. The Office of the Supervising Scientist has been closely involved and through the agency of the Co-ordinating Committee has taken measures to ensure that the situation is closely monitored and that suitable action is taken to deal with the situation. It is important to point out what Mr West said yesterday. I once again quote from page 1721 of yesterday's Hansard. He said:
I have been informed today by the staff of the National Parks and Wildlife Service that a major fault exists within the tailings dam at Ranger.
That information was incorrect; the staff have pulled his little leg. Earlier today the honourable member for Cunningham made further allegations. He said:

It perturbed me greatly to learn this morning from sources within his Department . . . the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Office of the Supervising Scientist that the Minister has now in fact instigated a sort of witch hunt over a mythical letter which he claims was sent to me.

It is true that I have contacted the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to advise him that if officers, members of his service, have passed misleading and incorrect information to the honourable member for Cuningham or any other person then that practice requires attention. I am not, as a Minister, going to allow officers of my Department to pass incorrect information to anyone. I have absolutely no objection whatsoever to the passing of information so long as the information that is passed is correct. As of half an hour ago Professor Ovington advised me that today he has been in contact with many officers of the National Parks and Wildlife Service in the Northern Territory. They have advised him that at no stage have they passed information to the honourable member for Cunningham. If he has that information, if he is fair dinkum, let him get up in this Parliament and name the officer who is supposed to have conveyed information to him yesterday. He does not have the intestinal fortitude to do that; he would rather live in dreamland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think that the Chair has given a lot of latitude to the Minister. The Minister is now abusing the forms of the House. It is very late at night. We want a fair go. I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, want to do the right thing, but I really think that the Minister is abusing the privileges of the House.

—The honourable member for Reid has made his point . Ironically, if honourable members on my left had not granted leave to the Minister to make a speech instead of a personal explanation I would have ruled him out of order five minutes ago. I suggest that the Minister bring his remarks to a close.
—I have leave to make a statement, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—That is understood, but I seek the co-operation of the Minister.
—Members of the Opposition do not like it very much when I tell them the truth, do they? It really hurts them because they cannot take it.
—You are an idiot.
—Coming from a fool, that is-
—Order! We will regard the attributes as being self-cancelling . I suggest that the Minister should immediately bring his remarks to a conclusion.

—I am particularly interested to learn that the honourable member for Cunningham is under the misapprehension that I have been in contact with my own Department and the Office of the Supervising Scientist in an effort to conduct a witch hunt. Again, nothing could be further from the truth. The honourable member for Cunningham has again tried to cloud this issue by making false allegations in respect of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Yesterday during the debate on the introduction of the Code of Practice on the Management of Radioactive Waste from the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores I took the opportunity, it is true, to relay to the House some information that had been passed on to me from informants inside the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and inside the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Just to check the information I rang the Office of the Supervising Scientist. All of the information I received was the same, and it was this: The tailings dam at Ranger had not been constructed down to bedrock as it should have been and that the rising pressure of ground water which rose from underneath the dam was lifting the pressure and at least posing the very grave risk that it would force contaminated water out from under the dam into the very sensitive environment of Kakadu National Park. Furthermore, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) had been in receipt of this information for some two months but had not relayed it to the House. I thought that was quite serious, and I quite legitimately informed the House of that information and gave the Minister an opportunity-in fact, I challenged him-to table the report that I knew he had already received. He has not as yet done so.

SPEECH.PARA: I raised the matter this morning as a personal explanation simply because people within the Minister's own Department had telephoned me saying: 'This Minister has already started a witch hunt. In his paranoia he thinks that we sent you a letter and documents about all this'. Of course they did not. I want to put the record straight. The integrity of the service was intact and officers in that service did not send records to me. I conclude my remarks by saying that there is a potentially grave problem. It has been identified. The project has been in operation for only one year and it is expected to last for some 20 or 30 years. This is a fair example of what we can expect in the future. The Minister should have made a statement about the matter before. We are still waiting on the report from the Supervising Scientist and the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy.

TALKER.NAME: Mr McVEIGH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented by the recent remarks of the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West). He stated that an officer of my Department rang him today. In fact, a Mr McCormick of his office rang an officer of my Department.
—There is no misrepresentation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Thomson, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill provides for the amendment of the Repatriation Act and associated Acts to give effect to the Government's Budget decisions, to formalise the basis for certain 'act of grace' payments, to extend the liability provision 'arisen out of or attributable to' to members of the forces who do not have the benefit of this liability, and to make certain machinery amendments.

In the Budget context, repatriation benefits are to be extended to members of peacekeeping forces who served prior to 2 November 1981; service pension eligibility is to be extended to merchant mariners of Commonwealth and allied countries; disability pension at the 100 per cent general rate is to be restored to veterans who received a pension for pulmonary tuberculosis prior to 2 November 1978; eligibility for double orphan's pension is to be extended; increases are to be made in the amount of income permitted for determination of eligibility for service pension and fringe benefits; disability pension is to be discontinued totally in determining a veteran's elegibility for service pension and fringe benefits; and certain decisions relating to social security beneficiaries are also to apply to repatriation pensioners.

In addition, Mr Deputy Speaker, the pensions payable for amputations or loss of vision and the levels of the amounts payable for many other benefits including supplementary assistance, also known as rent allowance, are to be increased. The legislation will also be amended to incorporate provision for certain types of payments that have been made on an 'act of grace' basis.

As announced in the Budget, eligibility for repatriation benefits is to be extended to members of peacekeeping forces who served as representatives of Australia prior to 2 November 1981. Honourable members will recall that the Repatriation Act was amended following the 1981-82 Budget to provide benefits to representatives of this country who served overseas after 2 November 1981 with peacekeeping, observation and monitoring forces raised or organised by the United Nations or other international bodies. These provisions were further extended earlier this year to cover Australian members of the multinational force now serving in Sinai.

The amendment proposed by the Bill will provide eligibility for repatriation benefits for defence force personnel who have, since 1948, been involved overseas in peacekeeping and monitoring roles and for the Australian police contingents on Cyprus which have been carrying out a similar role since 1964. The Bill also provides for the extension of what is commonly known as the ' arisen out of or attributable to' provision to members of the forces who participated in conflicts other than World War II.

Some publicity has been given recently to contentions that Vietnam veterans have been disadvantaged by not having applicable to them the arisen out of or attributable to provision which has been applicable to World War II forces. In practice the provision appears to give little eligibility coverage that is not included by the occurrence and other provisions applicable to these groups. Very few instances have come to attention where eligibility for disability pension would arise because of the application of the arisen out of or attributable to provision apart from the occurrence provision. As a general principle, the Government considers that the same principles of eligibility should apply to all veterans for all conflicts unless there is good reason to introduce specific principles and provisions for particular conflicts or for particular groups of veterans.

It is intended to undertake a review of these provisions as part of the thorough review of all repatriation legislation now about to be undertaken. This review which will be concerned with a wide range of complex provisions and will take some time will apply the principles I have mentioned and be undertaken on the basis that there will be no watering down of existing standards of eligibility. In the short term, the Government has taken the view that the comparatively simple amendment to introduce the arisen out of or attributable to provision to all veterans should be introduced at the first opportunity to amend the legislation. This we are now doing.

The Government has also decided to extend eligibility for service pension to Commonwealth and allied mariners who served in a theatre of war during World War II. The basis of eligibility is similar to that applied under the Repatriation Act to Australian mariners and members of the armed forces of Commonwealth and allied countries. Last year eligibility for service pension was extended to include Australian mariners. The proposed amendment extends the service pension to those living in Australia who served against the enemy or assisted the Allied cause during World War II. I am sure all honourable members are aware of the great hardships suffered by merchant mariners during the war and of the important role they played in the war effort. The Bill includes provisions which exclude any mariner who in any way assisted the enemy.

Another provision gives effect to the decision of the Government to restore to veterans who were in receipt of a pension prior to November 1978 in respect of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB), the 100 per cent general rate, irrespective of the actual assessment of their condition. This will restore them to the position prevailing prior to 2 November 1978 at which time pensions were frozen and reassessed according to actual incapacity. Restoration of the pension will be to a minimum of 100 per cent of the general rate from 6 January 1983. As with other disability pension rates, pension will be increased in line with movements in the consumer price index. These arrangements which do not include retrospective payments have been agreed to by the Federated TB Sailors, Soldiers and Airmen's Association of Australia.

The Government has decided that, from 11 November 1982, any disability pension received by a veteran or dependant will be totally disregarded as income when assessing levels of service pension and fringe benefits. This initiative that has been described as historic by the Returned Services League, will, I am sure, be welcomed by all honourable members. The proportion of disability pension disregarded for this purpose at present is 60 per cent.

In line with social security amendments, the income level used to determine a veteran's eligibility to receive the maximum rate of service pension will be raised from $20 a week to $30 a week for a single pensioner and from $34.50 a week to $50 a week for married pensioners. In addition, the fringe benefits limits will be raised from $40 a week to $54 a week for a single pensioner and from $68 a week to $90 a week for a married couple. These changes which will apply from 11 November this year will assist veterans who receive small increases in their income to retain their benefits.

The Bill provides for an increase in the maximum amount of supplementary allowance-that is, rent allowance-payable to a service pensioner from $8 a week to $10 a week from 11 November 1982. Provision has been made in the Bill for increases in many other repatriation benefits to severely disabled veterans and in pensions paid to orphans. They are intended to have effect from 11 November 1982. The increases in benefits are in line with movements in the consumer price index in the twelve-month period since the previous increase.

The pension paid for amputations or loss of vision, which is payable in addition to the repatriation disability pension, is to be increased by approximately 11 per cent for the various categories of disablement. The rate of attendant's allowance is to be increased from $21.02 a week to $23.30 a week in the case of a veteran who is blind or suffering a cerebro-spinal injury. In the case of a veteran who has had both arms amputated or who is blind and has lost hearing or speech, the allowance is to be increased from $42.05 a week to $46.60 a week.

The present eligibility criteria for a double orphan's pension provide that it can be paid only if a parent veteran's death was due to an accepted war-caused disability or the veteran was at the time of death in receipt of a special rate pension or pension as a double amputee. This requirement will be widened by the Bill and will mean that the Department of Veterans' Affairs will be able to assist the children of veterans who served in a theatre of war but who died from causes not accepted as due to service, by making available to them the double orphan's pension. Other increases affecting veterans announced in the Budget, including increases in the funeral benefit, clothing allowance and recreation transport allowance, will be provided for by amendment of the regulations.

I come now to the amendment in the Bill which relates to act of grace payments. By way of background I explain that, since 1942, special arrangements have existed for the payment of pensions and benefits to certain persons who were not members of the forces as defined in the Repatriation Act and associated legislation, but who were exposed to the risk of injury or death through their employment in connection with World War II or later conflicts or war-like operations. In the main, these arrangements have applied to certain persons with part time service during World War II, representatives of various philanthropic organisations who were attached to the forces and accredited by the relevant service department and certain Commonwealth employees. The benefits available are largely the same as those applicable under the Repatriation Act to members of the forces.

The special arrangements I have mentioned do not have legislative authority. Traditionally, the benefits have been conferred as acts of grace but are not in accord with formal act of grace payments under section 34A of the Audit Act. Eligibility will be conferred by amending the definition of member of the forces to include these people. The action taken will also provide them with the appeal rights applicable to members of the forces which they do not have now. I am sure that honourable members will agree that this group of pensioners who provided such valuable service in war should have their rights formally perpetuated by being incorporated into repatriation legislation. This Bill demonstrates in a formal way the Government's continuing concern to ensure that those who have served Australia, our Commonwealth partners, and allies, in war or war-like conflicts can be certain of being adequately compensated for the losses which they have suffered and the sacrifices they have made. I commend the Bill to the House.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Vietnam War Service: Claims for Disability

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many claims for disabilities related to war service in Vietnam have been made in each year from 1961-62 to the date of preparation of the answer to this question.
(2) How many of those claims (a) have rested, in whole or in part, on exposure to toxic chemicals and (b) have been determined in each year over the period referred to in part (1).
(3) How many of the claims determined have been accepted on the basis of exposure to chemicals.

(4) How many Vietnam veterans have been advised, in each year, that decisions of various repatriation tribunals unfavourable to them, where the claims mentioned exposure to chemicals in whole or part, would be reviewed at the completion of the Commonwealth Institute of Health (CIH) epidemiological study.
(5) On what date was the CIH epidemiological study terminated.
(6) Have steps been taken to review the claims of those Vietnam veterans mentioned in part (4); if so, what steps have been taken; if not, why not.

(7) What are the details of the methodology for each of the medical and scientific study programs which have replaced the CIH epidemiological study, when did those programs commence and what is the proposed completion date for each one.
(8) Will the Minister release the findings of the pilot study conducted by the CIH; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Set out below are the numbers of new claims and claims for new disabilities which have been determined by Repatriation Boards in respect of Special Overseas Service in the years indicated. New claims refer to claims lodged by veterans who have not previously lodged a claim with the Department. New disability claims refer to cases where a veteran with an accepted disability lodges a subsequent claim. The figures do not relate to numbers of veterans.
Number of new claims and new disability claims
Equivalent figures are not available for the period before 1 July 1971. Between 1 July 1965 and 30 June 1971, 9,185 new claims were determined.

(2) Statistics concerning chemical claims have been maintained since Januaray 1980. To 31 August 1982 a total of 1,224 claims had been lodged in which there was some reference by the claimant to exposure to chemicals. Of the total, 991 claims had been determined by Repatriation Boards and the balance, 233, were undetermined as at 31 August 1982.

(3) According to the figures provided by the State Branches of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, one claim was accepted specifically on that basis. Of the 991 claims determined referred to in (2), 393 were accepted.

(4), (5) and (6) These questions appear to rest on a misunderstanding of my announcement of 15 February 1982 on revision of the study program. Since early in 1980, in unsuccessful claims or appeal cases, veterans who mentioned a possible link between chemicals and their claimed disability have been advised of review arrangements to apply after study activity was completed. In that advice it was pointed out that the veteran continued to have the right of immediate appeal and that action in this regard would not jeopardise any future review of the claim which might be found necessary as a result of the findings of the study. My predecessor clarified this issue further when he told the House of Representatives on 21 February 1980 that rejected claims would be reviewed if a study revealed a connection between reported disabilities and exposure to herbicides in Vietnam.

Although the Commonwealth Institute of Health (CIH) survey as originally envisaged has been modified, the revised program provides for the conduct of important epidemiological study activity in relation to Vietnam veterans. CIH epidemiological study activity has not terminated; in the absence of study results revealing a connection between disabilities and herbicide exposure in Vietnam, it follows that steps have not been taken to review the claims mentioned. It is open to the veterans concerned to appeal or to lodge a further claim at any time and some have done so.

(7) Details of the revised scientific study program were given in my announcement of 15 February 1982. The announcement was made shortly after the Government had formally decided on the total program. Work which had commenced earlier in order to prepare individual elements of the program for submission for Government approval has contributed to progress made. The two studies for which designs were approved and which are currently proceeding are:

A case control study of congenital anomalies, commencing with hospital records of malformed and healthy children, which will enable the incidence of major birth defects in Vietnam veterans' children to be compared with the incidence in children of members of the Australian Army in the Vietnam era who did not serve in Vietnam and in children of the community. Completion is expected by the end of 1982.

A retrospective mortality study which will investigate the causes and incidence of death among Vietnam veterans and a control group of Vietnam-era ex-servicemen who did not serve in Vietnam. Completion is expected by late in 1983.
(8) The final reports on the pilot study will be released.

(2) If so, did the judge invalidate Illinois Revised Statutes, sections 121a- 121n of 1967 requiring fluoridation of public water supplies.

(3) Did the judgment state that a conclusion that fluoride is a safe and effective means of promoting dental health cannot be supported 'by this record', that the state must take a 'hard look' and be able to demonstrate to the highest degree that the public is safe.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) On 17 March 1982 the Attorney-General, State of Illinois, filed with the Illinois Supreme Court a motion for a stay of Judge Niemann's ruling, pending appeal. On 23 March 1982 an order for a stay was granted. Until the appeal against Judge Niemann's decision is heard, the mandatory fluoridation law in Illinois will remain in effect.
(3) Yes.
(4) The following papers have been placed in the Parliamentary Library:
(a) The judgment by Judge Ronald Niemann dated 24 February 1982.
(b) The submissions to the Illinois Supreme Court by-
(i) The Plaintiffs, the Illinois Pure Water Committee, Inc., et al.
(ii) The Defendants, the Department of Public Health of the State of Illinois, et al.
(iii) The American Dental Association.
(c) A copy of advice of the decision of the Illinois Supreme Court dated 23 March 1982, granting a stay of Judge Niemann's order.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Airbus Aircraft: Safety

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an incident in March 1982, in which an Airbus taking off at Sanaa's Airport in the Yemen had one of its two CF6-50C2 engines disintegrate during the take-off roll and the take-off was successfully aborted.
(2) If so, is he able to say (a) what is the length of the runway at Sanaa and (b) what is the clearance from the end of the runway to the nearest building.

(3) Could an Airbus, taking off from Adelaide runway with a load of 154 tonnes, a 5 knot headwind and in a temperature of 28* C survive an engine disintegration after take-off; if so what would be the height of the aircraft above the ground 400 metres past the end of the runway.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the occurrence to which the honourable member refers. It involved an Air France Airbus which suffered an engine failure when a turbine disc disintegrated during take-off. The take-off was aborted and the aircraft was stopped on the runway after travelling 1,900 metres. There were no injuries but the aircraft suffered substantial damage.

(2) (a) The runway at Sanaa is 3,252 metres long and 2,206 metres above sea level; and (b) My Department does not hold information on the position of buildings relative to the Sanaa runway-nor is it required to do so: the airport is neither a destination nor a designated alternative for any Australian operator.

(3) A TAA Airbus could take-off from Adelaide Runway 05, the more limiting runway, at a weight slightly greater than 159 tonnes under the conditions specified, experience an engine failure at the most critical point and still clear all obstacles in the take-off area by at least 35 feet (10.7 metres), the minimum legal requirement. The height of the aircraft above the ground at a point 400 metres beyond the runway end would not be less than 17 metres in the most adverse case based upon certification performance data but more probably the height would be closer to 26 metres. This latter figure is derived empirically from a series of exercises conducted in the Airbus flight simulator.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Shared Environment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article published in the Courier Mail of 12 May 1982 in which the United Nations Environment Program executive director, Dr Mostafa Tolba, said that in the last decade on almost every front there had been marked deterioration in the quality of our shared environment and that the world faced an ecological disaster as final as nuclear war within a couple of decades unless governments take action now.
(2) Is there a marked deterioration in the quality of Australia's shared environment and does Australia face an ecological disaster.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Media reports of opening speeches at the United Nations Environment Programme Governing Council Session of a Special Character in Nairobi, 10-18 May 1982, such as contained in the newspaper article referred to by the honourable member, have tended to emphasise the more critical environmental problems facing the international community. The following extract from the statement by the Leader of the Australian Delegation to this meeting puts the Australian situation into perspective.

. . . In considering the environmental achievements and failures since Stockholm and the state of the world environment now, some of our thoughts inevitably turn to our own countries. We reflect on the progress we have achieved. We recognise the problems still outstanding and the efforts still to be made. We hope that our own experiences, faltering as they may have been, may offer some contribution or understanding, in support of our collective efforts to make an environmentally better world for future generations.

Looking back over the past ten years of environment protection and nature conservation in Australia, some encouraging progress can be reported. Environmental agencies are firmly established in all our governments Federal and State. Sound laws exist and are well administered in all the main fields of pollution control. Extensive areas of parks and reserves have been permanently secured. Much has been done to protect our wildlife on land and in the sea. Environment assessment procedures are applied to major development projects. Our communities are alert to environmental problems and communicate their view freely to governments. Arrangements have been made for collaboration between governments within our country. We derive much benefit as a party to many international environmental agreements and conventions. Looking ahead, we are well advanced with the preparation of a National Conservation Strategy, which has provided a unique opportunity to assess the current state of the whole Australian environment, and to plan effectively for the future.

Even so, we would not for one moment wish to diminish the challenges that lie ahead of us. In a global perspective Australia's environmental problems may appear small and manageable. But we remain concerned about the fragility of our huge arid lands-with maintaining the productive capacity of our soils, with arresting the decline in trees and forest cover, and with saving our unique flora and fauna from extinction. We are concerned to maintain, and improve where necessary, the quality of our inland and coastal waters. We must improve our arrangements for controlling chemicals in the environment, and improve our land planning and land management practices.

Our desire in Australia for careful management of our natural and man-made environment is clear. Yet it is no less matched by concern which we share with other countries for the establishment of effective international mechanisms and programs designed to deal resolutely with environmental problems of global as well as local character. In the ten years since the establishment of the Stockholm Action Plan and the creation of UNEP much has been done to give effect to this goal. As we have heard from the Executive Director in recent days, various international conventions have been established, international meetings, workshops and demonstration projects conducted and a wide range of information, monitoring and assessment networks developed.

A major lesson to be learned from the achievements of international environmental cooperation over the past ten years, is surely that the cause for urgency associated with the Stockholm Conference has not diminished. Some of the recommendations of the Stockholm Plan remain to be fully implemented. Many of the specific environmental problems which achieved prominence in 1972 are still with us. New issues of growing concern have arisen.

In addressing these issues we recognise the acute difficulties faced by developing countries in providing the necessary resources and in harmonising environmental protection and development. We all share these problems to a greater or lesser extent and have a common perception of the urgent need to resolve them.

I would like to mention one of the environmental insights which has recently gained widespread recognition in Australia. Until very recent times, there has been a near idyllic balance between population and resources which could be drawn from the land. This balance was no accident. Earlier societies evolved a life style and social customs that allowed people to live in permanent harmony with their environment. The ancient inhabitants of our country had a complete identification, as a people, and as individuals, with the land itself. The life of the people, all other living things and the land use were all seen as part of an inextricably related whole. It was recognised that if the land and its natural resources were harmed or destroyed, the people would suffer likewise.

We are drawing from this long experience, which no doubt is shared by other early societies, and my delegation hopes that the declaration and resolutions of this special session will record, in some meaningful way, the need for countries of the world consciously to achieve an equilibrium between population, resources and the environment. An equilibrium which will be stable in perpetuity and established at a level where all the people can live in health and dignity while still maintaining viable co-existence with the other forms of life which share this planet with us.

In this respect the words of President Moi were especially pertinent in drawing attention to the direct relationship between rapidly increasing populations and the environment. I believe we are all becoming more aware that the world's less intensively used areas and resources are small and finite, when viewed in the perspective of all the centuries which lie ahead. These unexpended resources may help provide, at best, a relatively few years of additional time for the countries of the world to each achieve equilibrium between mankind and the environment.

The Second Report (1981) of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation on the adequacy of legislative and administrative arrangements for environment protection included a recommendation that regular comprehensive reports on the state of and changes in the Australian environment be prepared and tabled in this Parliament. The Government is still examining the Committee's recommendations and its response will be announced in due course.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Library Distribution of Films on Behalf of the South African Embassy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the National Library, through the National Film Lending Collection, distribute films on behalf of the South African Embassy.

(2) Do some of these films, notably The Solution to the Dilemma of a Plural Society, To Act a Lie and The Vital Link, seek to defend South African doctrine on race relations and to advocate South Africa's strategic significance to the west.

(3) Is it common practice for the National Library to circulate films on behalf of foreign Embassies; if so, (a) which Embassies have had films circulated, (b) what charges are levied on the Embassies for the service performed, (c) have any films been barred from circulation because of their political and social content and (d) how are Embassies advised of the availability of the service.

(4) If it is not common practice for the Library to do this (a) why has an exception been made in the case of the South African Embassy and (b) has there been any vetting of the content of the films circulated.
(5) What, if any, consultation takes place between the Library and the Department of Foreign Affairs on the service provided and the circulation of the films.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) It is characteristic of Government-sponsored films that they seek to portray a positive image of their country and society.
(3) Yes. The Library has done so for over 20 years.

(a) 34 Embassies and High Commissions have had films handled by the National Film Lending Collection. They are: Argentina, Belgium, Brazil, Bulgaria, Canada, Denmark, Federal Republic of Germany, Finland, German Democratic Republic, India , Indonesia, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Pakistan, Poland, Portugal, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, South Korea, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Arab Republic, United Kingdom, Soviet Union, United States of America and Vietnam.

(b) No charges are levied on the Embassies because the arrangement has advantages for both parties. The Embassies receive access to the Film Lending Collection's well-developed distribution system, the Film Lending Collection can thereby substantially extend the size of its collection without cost; and Australian film users have efficient access to a much wider range of films than would be otherwise possible.

(c) The National Library is a non-partisan provider of information. It is not a censor of ideas nor does it identify with particular viewpoints. This applies to films as well as to books or other media. Hence, it has not barred any films because of political or social content, though it has refused to accept films on other grounds, such as insufficient audience appeal or poor technical standard. It also tries to ensure, as far as possible, that multiple viewpoints on major issues are represented.

(d) The Department of Foreign Affairs occasionally circularises Embassies to advise them of the service provided by the National Film Lending Collection. As opportunity arises in day-to-day business, Library staff advise Embassy officials of the service also. However, there is no active canvassing of Embassies by the Library. Normally Embassies take the initiative and make the first approach.
(4) Not applicable.

(5) Consultation between the Department of Foreign Affairs and the National Library is not frequent but an awareness is maintained of the possibility of the Library being unduly used as an overt propaganda channel for foreign governments to the potential embarrassment of the Australian Government. No Embassy has yet attempted to do this.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aborigines: Housing Loans

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: How many housing loans were approved by the Aboriginal Development Commission in 1981-82 and what was the total value of loans during that period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed by the Aboriginal Development Commission that during 1981-82 the Aboriginal Development Commission approved 238 housing loans to the total value of $8,881,361.

The total housing loans funds disbursed by the Commission in 1981-82 was $10, 076,300. This comprised $7.0m in respect of loans approved in 1981-82, $2.4m for loans approved in the previous year and $0.6m in payment of agency fees to building societies and banks which assist the Commission in the administration of housing loans.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force Reserves

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Director of Reserves resigned his commission; if so, was this because the Department of Defence refused to implement his recommendations regarding the Royal Australian Air Force Reserves.
(2) Whilst holding the position of Director of Reserves what recommendations did the last Director make which (a) were implemented and (b) were not implemented.

(3) Why are adult instructor members of the Air Training Corps throughout Australia, most of whom are former members of regular Commonwealth Armed Forces, not allowed to be full members of the R.A.A.F. Reserve.
(4) If allowed to join the R.A.A.F. Reserve as full members, would instructors be entitled to full pay, allowances, conditions and uniform entitlements.
(5) When will the new all-seasons uniform be made available to cadets in Western Australia.
(6) Is there to be a delay in the provision of new uniforms; if so, why.
(7) When will uniforms be available for female cadets.
(8) Why are female cadets required to wear the male uniforms when there are insufficient uniforms available for male cadet members.
(9) Has the Commanding Officer of the R.A.A.F. Base, Pearce, Western Australia, refused to have female cadets in his unit; if so, why.
(10) Is the Commanding Officer using lack of accommodation as an excuse.
(11) When will female cadets enlisted in Western Australia, be kitted and able to join in fully in visiting R.A.A.F. Bases and partake in all activities similar to male members.
(12) When will Air Training Corps adult instructors be entitled to the issue of two pairs of trousers and additional jackets.
(13) Can instructors purchase from stores necessary equipment not on issue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Director of Reserves-Air Force has resigned his appointment in the Permanent Air Force but has elected to continue to serve on the R.A.A.F. General Reserve in the Reserve management area. The Officer did not resign because the Department of Defence refused to implement his recommendations regarding the R.A .A.F. Reserves.
(2) The major recommendations that the Director of Reserves has made concerned:
(a) the formation of a Reserve Staff Group,
(b) the utilisation of Reserve aircrew on R.A.A.F. flying duties, and
(c) the utilisation of Reserve personnel in the management of Reserve activities.

These and other minor recommendations have been, or are being, implemented. There have been no significant recommendations from the Director of Reserves that have been rejected by the Department of Defence.
(3) All Air Training Corps Officers and Instructors who possess the normal R.A. A.F. entry criteria are eligible and are encouraged to join the R.A.A.F. General Reserve.

(4) The Air Training Corps while being administered by the R.A.A.F. is not part of that Service. Air Training Corps Officers and Instructors are paid, entitled to certain travelling allowances, and provided with uniforms by the Department of Defence.
(5) The all season uniform will be made available to Western Australia Squadron Air Training Corps by the end of 1982.
(7) Uniforms for female cadets will be available by the end of 1982.
(8) Female cadets are not permitted to wear male uniforms.
(9) No; female AIRTC instructors attended a camp at R.A.A.F. Base Pearce during August-September 1982.
(11) Female cadets will be enlisted into the Western Australia Squadron Air Training Corps during this current month.
(12) The current scale of uniform entitlements has been effective over the past six years. There have been no requests received at the Department of Defence to increase the scale of issue.
(13) Air Training Corps Instructors are able to purchase additional items of uniform which they are entitled to wear but which is additional to the laid down scale.
